   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading">Venezuela</h1> 
   <div id="bodyContent" class="vector-body"> 
    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div> 
    <div id="contentSub"></div> 
    <div id="contentSub2"></div> 
    <div id="jump-to-nav"></div> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a> 
    <div id="mw-content-text" class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" lang="en" dir="ltr">
     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       "Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela" redirects here. For the period when it was known as the "Republic of Venezuela" from 1953 to 1999, see <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Venezuela" title="Republic of Venezuela">Republic of Venezuela</a>.
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       This article is about the country. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Venezuela_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Venezuela (disambiguation)">Venezuela (disambiguation)</a>.
      </div> 
      <p class="mw-empty-elt"> </p> 
      <div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">
       Country in South America
      </div> 
      <p> <span style="font-size: small;"><span id="coordinates"><a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">Coordinates</a>: <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r994658806">.mw-parser-output .geo-default,.mw-parser-output .geo-dms,.mw-parser-output .geo-dec{display:inline}.mw-parser-output .geo-nondefault,.mw-parser-output .geo-multi-punct{display:none}.mw-parser-output .longitude,.mw-parser-output .latitude{white-space:nowrap}</style><span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Venezuela&amp;params=7_N_65_W_type:country_region:VE"><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">7°N</span> <span class="longitude">65°W</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">﻿ / ﻿</span><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">7°N 65°W</span><span style="display:none">﻿ / <span class="geo">7; -65</span></span></span></a></span></span></span> </p>

        <tr>
         <td colspan="2" class="infobox-full-data">
          <div style="text-align:left;margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto;">
           <ol style="list-style-type: lower-alpha; margin-left: 1em;"> 
            <li value="1"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_namenone"><a href="#ref_namenone"><b><sup>^</sup></b></a></span> The "Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela" has been the full official title since the adoption of the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Venezuela" title="Constitution of Venezuela">Constitution of 1999</a>, when the state was renamed in honor of <a href="/wiki/Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar" title="Simón Bolívar">Simón Bolívar</a>.</li>
            <li value="2"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_languagesnone"><a href="#ref_languagesnone"><b><sup>^</sup></b></a></span> The Constitution also recognizes all <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_languages_of_the_Americas" title="Indigenous languages of the Americas">indigenous languages</a> spoken in the country.</li>
            <li value="3"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_groupsnone"><a href="#ref_groupsnone"><b><sup>^</sup></b></a></span> Some important subgroups include those of <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Venezuelan" class="mw-redirect" title="Spanish Venezuelan">Spanish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Venezuelan" class="mw-redirect" title="Portuguese Venezuelan">Portuguese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italo-Venezuelans" class="mw-redirect" title="Italo-Venezuelans">Italian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Venezuela" title="Indigenous peoples in Venezuela">Amerindian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Afro-Venezuelan" class="mw-redirect" title="Afro-Venezuelan">African</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arab_Venezuelan" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab Venezuelan">Arab</a> and <a href="/wiki/German_Venezuelan" class="mw-redirect" title="German Venezuelan">German</a> descent.</li>
            <li value="4"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_areanone"><a href="#ref_areanone"><b><sup>^</sup></b></a></span> Area totals include only Venezuelan-administered territory.</li>
            <li value="5"><span class="citation wikicite" id="endnote_currencynone"><a href="#ref_currencynone"><b><sup>^</sup></b></a></span> On 20 August 2018, a new bolivar was introduced, the <i>Bolívar soberano</i> (ISO 4217 code VES) worth 100,000 VEF.</li> 
           </ol>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p><b>Venezuela</b> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˌ/: secondary stress follows">ˌ</span><span title="'v' in 'vie'">v</span><span title="/ɛ/: 'e' in 'dress'">ɛ</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span><span title="/ə/: 'a' in 'about'">ə</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'z' in 'zoom'">z</span><span title="'w' in 'wind'">w</span><span title="/eɪ/: 'a' in 'face'">eɪ</span><span title="'l' in 'lie'">l</span><span title="/ə/: 'a' in 'about'">ə</span></span>/</a></span></span>; <small>American Spanish:&nbsp;</small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Spanish" title="Help:IPA/Spanish">[beneˈswela]</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:Venezuela.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20"></a></span><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/37/Venezuela.ogg" class="internal" title="Venezuela.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span>), officially the <b>Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela</b> (Spanish: <i lang="es">República Bolivariana de Venezuela</i>),<sup id="cite_ref-const_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-const-14">[12]</a></sup> is a country on the northern coast of South America, consisting of a <a href="/wiki/Continent" title="Continent">continental</a> landmass and many <a href="/wiki/Federal_Dependencies_of_Venezuela" title="Federal Dependencies of Venezuela">islands and islets</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean_Sea" title="Caribbean Sea">Caribbean Sea</a>. It has a territorial extension of 916,445&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (353,841 sq mi), and the population of Venezuela was estimated at 28 million in 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-9">[7]</a></sup> The capital and largest urban agglomeration is the city of <a href="/wiki/Caracas" title="Caracas">Caracas</a>. </p>
      <p>The continental territory is bordered on the north by the Caribbean Sea and the Atlantic Ocean, on the west by <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a> on the south, <a href="/wiki/Trinidad_and_Tobago" title="Trinidad and Tobago">Trinidad and Tobago</a> to the north-east and on the east by <a href="/wiki/Guyana" title="Guyana">Guyana</a>. The Venezuelan government maintains a claim against Guyana to <a href="/wiki/Guayana_Esequiba" title="Guayana Esequiba">Guayana Esequiba</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Geneva_Agreement,_17_February_1966_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Geneva_Agreement,_17_February_1966-15">[13]</a></sup> Venezuela is a <a href="/wiki/Federation" title="Federation">federal</a> <a href="/wiki/Presidential_republic" class="mw-redirect" title="Presidential republic">presidential republic</a> consisting of <a href="/wiki/States_of_Venezuela" title="States of Venezuela">23 states</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Venezuelan_Capital_District" class="mw-redirect" title="Venezuelan Capital District">Capital District</a> and <a href="/wiki/Federal_Dependencies_of_Venezuela" title="Federal Dependencies of Venezuela">federal dependencies</a> covering Venezuela's offshore islands. Venezuela is among the most urbanized countries in Latin America;<sup id="cite_ref-encartaSA_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-encartaSA-16">[14]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-UNpopstats_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNpopstats-17">[15]</a></sup> the vast majority of Venezuelans live in the cities of the north and in the capital. </p>
      <p>The territory of Venezuela was <a href="/wiki/Spanish_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="Spanish colonization of the Americas">colonized by Spain</a> in 1522 amid resistance from indigenous peoples. In 1811, it became one of the first Spanish-American territories to <a href="/wiki/First_Republic_of_Venezuela" title="First Republic of Venezuela">declare independence</a> from the Spanish and to form part, as a department, of the first federal Republic of Colombia (historiographically known as <a href="/wiki/Gran_Colombia" title="Gran Colombia">Gran Colombia</a>). It separated as a full sovereign country in 1830. During the 19th century, Venezuela suffered political turmoil and autocracy, remaining dominated by regional <a href="/wiki/Caudillo" title="Caudillo">military dictators</a> until the mid-20th century. Since 1958, the country has had a series of democratic governments, as an exception where most of the region was ruled by military dictatorships, and the period was characterized by economic prosperity. Economic shocks in the <a href="/wiki/1980s_oil_glut" title="1980s oil glut">1980s</a> and 1990s led to major political crises and widespread social unrest, including the deadly <a href="/wiki/Caracazo" title="Caracazo">Caracazo</a> riots of 1989, <a href="/wiki/1992_Venezuelan_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat_attempts" title="1992 Venezuelan coup d'état attempts">two attempted coups in 1992</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Andr%C3%A9s_P%C3%A9rez#Impeachment" title="Carlos Andrés Pérez">impeachment of a President</a> for embezzlement of public funds charges in 1993. The collapse in confidence in the existing parties saw the <a href="/wiki/1998_Venezuelan_presidential_election" title="1998 Venezuelan presidential election">1998 Venezuelan presidential election</a>, the catalyst for the <a href="/wiki/Bolivarian_Revolution" title="Bolivarian Revolution">Bolivarian Revolution</a>, which began with a <a href="/wiki/1999_Constituent_Assembly_of_Venezuela" class="mw-redirect" title="1999 Constituent Assembly of Venezuela">1999 Constituent Assembly</a>, where a new <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Venezuela" title="Constitution of Venezuela">Constitution of Venezuela</a> was imposed. The government <a href="/wiki/Populist" class="mw-redirect" title="Populist">populist</a> <a href="/wiki/Social_welfare" class="mw-redirect" title="Social welfare">social welfare</a> policies were bolstered by soaring oil prices,<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[16]</a></sup> temporarily increasing social spending,<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[17]</a></sup> and reducing <a href="/wiki/Economic_inequality" title="Economic inequality">economic inequality</a> and poverty in the early years of the regime.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[18]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/2013_Venezuelan_presidential_election" title="2013 Venezuelan presidential election">2013 Venezuelan presidential election</a> was widely disputed leading to <a href="/wiki/2013_Venezuelan_presidential_election_protests" title="2013 Venezuelan presidential election protests">widespread protest</a>, which triggered another nationwide <a href="/wiki/Crisis_in_Venezuela" title="Crisis in Venezuela">crisis</a> that continues to this day.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[19]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Venezuela is a <a href="/wiki/Developing_country" title="Developing country">developing country</a> and ranks 113th on the <a href="/wiki/Human_Development_Index" title="Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a>. It has the world's <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_proven_oil_reserves" title="List of countries by proven oil reserves">largest known oil reserves</a> and has been one of the world's leading <a href="/wiki/Oil_exporter" class="mw-redirect" title="Oil exporter">exporters of oil</a>. Previously, the country was an underdeveloped exporter of agricultural commodities such as coffee and <a href="/wiki/Cocoa_bean" title="Cocoa bean">cocoa</a>, but oil quickly came to dominate exports and government revenues. The excesses and poor policies of the incumbent government led to the collapse of Venezuela's entire economy.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[20]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ELPAISfeb2015_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ELPAISfeb2015-23">[21]</a></sup> The country struggles with record <a href="/wiki/Hyperinflation" title="Hyperinflation">hyperinflation</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[22]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[23]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Shortages_in_Venezuela" title="Shortages in Venezuela">shortages of basic goods</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[24]</a></sup> unemployment,<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[25]</a></sup> poverty,<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[26]</a></sup> disease, high child mortality, <a href="/wiki/Malnutrition" title="Malnutrition">malnutrition</a>, severe crime and corruption. These factors have precipitated the <a href="/wiki/Bolivarian_diaspora" class="mw-redirect" title="Bolivarian diaspora">Venezuelan migrant crisis</a> where more than three million people have fled the country.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[27]</a></sup> By 2017, Venezuela was declared to be in <a href="/wiki/Default_(finance)" title="Default (finance)">default</a> regarding debt payments by <a href="/wiki/Credit_rating_agency" title="Credit rating agency">credit rating agencies</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[28]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[29]</a></sup> The crisis in Venezuela has contributed to a rapidly deteriorating <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Venezuela" title="Human rights in Venezuela">human rights situation</a>, including increased abuses such as torture, arbitrary imprisonment, extrajudicial killings and attacks on human rights advocates. Venezuela is a charter member of the UN, <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_American_States" title="Organization of American States">OAS</a>, <a href="/wiki/Union_of_South_American_Nations" title="Union of South American Nations">UNASUR</a>, <a href="/wiki/ALBA" title="ALBA">ALBA</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mercosur" title="Mercosur">Mercosur</a>, <a href="/wiki/Latin_American_Integration_Association" title="Latin American Integration Association">LAIA</a> and <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_Ibero-American_States" title="Organization of Ibero-American States">OEI</a>. </p> 
      <div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading">

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2> 
      <p>According to the most popular and accepted version, in 1499, an expedition led by <a href="/wiki/Alonso_de_Ojeda" title="Alonso de Ojeda">Alonso de Ojeda</a> visited the Venezuelan coast. The <a href="/wiki/Stilt_houses" class="mw-redirect" title="Stilt houses">stilt houses</a> in the area of <a href="/wiki/Lake_Maracaibo" title="Lake Maracaibo">Lake Maracaibo</a> reminded the Italian navigator, <a href="/wiki/Amerigo_Vespucci" title="Amerigo Vespucci">Amerigo Vespucci</a>, of the city of <a href="/wiki/Venice" title="Venice">Venice</a>, Italy, so he named the region <i>Veneziola</i>, or "Little Venice".<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMassabié2008153_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMassabié2008153-32">[30]</a></sup> The Spanish version of <i>Veneziola</i> is <i>Venezuela</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThomas2005189_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThomas2005189-33">[31]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Mart%C3%ADn_Fern%C3%A1ndez_de_Enciso" title="Martín Fernández de Enciso">Martín Fernández de Enciso</a>, a member of the Vespucci and Ojeda crew, gave a different account. In his work <i>Summa de geografía</i>, he states that the crew found <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Indigenous people">indigenous people</a> who called themselves the <i>Veneciuela.</i> Thus, the name "Venezuela" may have evolved from the native word.<sup id="cite_ref-ICH_1958_386_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ICH_1958_386-34">[32]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Previously, the official name was <a href="/wiki/State_of_Venezuela" title="State of Venezuela"><i>Estado de Venezuela</i></a> (1830–1856), <i>República de Venezuela</i> (1856–1864), <a href="/wiki/United_States_of_Venezuela" title="United States of Venezuela"><i>Estados Unidos de Venezuela</i></a> (1864–1953), and again <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Venezuela" title="Republic of Venezuela"><i>República de Venezuela</i></a> (1953–1999). </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Venezuela" title="History of Venezuela">History of Venezuela</a>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pre-Columbian_history">Pre-Columbian history</span></h3> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">

          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px">

       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Evidence exists of human habitation in the area now known as Venezuela from about 15,000 years ago. <a href="/wiki/Leaf" title="Leaf">Leaf</a>-shaped tools from this period, together with chopping and <a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/plano-convex" class="extiw" title="wikt:plano-convex">plano-convex</a> scraping implements, have been found exposed on the high riverine terraces of the Rio Pedregal in western Venezuela.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKipfer200091_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKipfer200091-35">[33]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Late_Pleistocene" title="Late Pleistocene">Late Pleistocene</a> hunting artifacts, including spear tips, have been found at a similar series of sites in northwestern Venezuela known as "El Jobo"; according to <a href="/wiki/Radiocarbon_dating" title="Radiocarbon dating">radiocarbon dating</a>, these date from 13,000 to 7,000 BC.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKipfer2000172_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKipfer2000172-36">[34]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>It is not known how many people lived in Venezuela before the Spanish conquest; it has been estimated at around one million.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWunder2003130_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWunder2003130-37">[35]</a></sup> In addition to indigenous peoples known today, the population included historical groups such as the <a href="/wiki/Kalina_people" title="Kalina people">Kalina</a> (Caribs), <a href="/wiki/Auak%C3%A9_people" title="Auaké people">Auaké</a>, <a href="/wiki/Caquetio" title="Caquetio">Caquetio</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mariche" class="mw-redirect" title="Mariche">Mariche</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Timoto%E2%80%93Cuica_people" title="Timoto–Cuica people">Timoto–Cuicas</a>. The Timoto–Cuica culture was the most complex society in Pre-Columbian Venezuela, with pre-planned permanent villages, surrounded by irrigated, terraced fields. They also stored water in tanks.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMahoney89_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMahoney89-38">[36]</a></sup> Their houses were made primarily of stone and wood with thatched roofs. They were peaceful, for the most part, and depended on growing crops. Regional crops included potatoes and <a href="/wiki/Ulluco" class="mw-redirect" title="Ulluco">ullucos</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-art_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-art-39">[37]</a></sup> They left behind works of art, particularly anthropomorphic ceramics, but no major monuments. They spun vegetable fibers to weave into textiles and mats for housing. They are credited with having invented the <a href="/wiki/Arepa" title="Arepa">arepa</a>, a staple in <a href="/wiki/Venezuelan_cuisine" title="Venezuelan cuisine">Venezuelan cuisine</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESalas2004[httpsbooksgooglecombooksid6-1QnKS6xG4CpgPA142_142]_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESalas2004[httpsbooksgooglecombooksid6-1QnKS6xG4CpgPA142_142]-40">[38]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>After the conquest, the population dropped markedly, mainly through the spread of new infectious diseases from Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWunder2003130_37-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWunder2003130-37">[35]</a></sup> Two main north–south axes of pre-Columbian population were present, who cultivated maize in the west and <a href="/wiki/Manioc" class="mw-redirect" title="Manioc">manioc</a> in the east.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWunder2003130_37-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWunder2003130-37">[35]</a></sup> Large parts of the <i>llanos</i> were cultivated through a combination of <a href="/wiki/Slash_and_burn" class="mw-redirect" title="Slash and burn">slash and burn</a> and permanent settled agriculture.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWunder2003130_37-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWunder2003130-37">[35]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Colonization">Colonization</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Spanish_colonization_of_the_Americas" title="Spanish colonization of the Americas">Spanish colonization of the Americas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Colonial_Venezuela" title="Colonial Venezuela">Colonial Venezuela</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Musterung-Welser-Armada.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Musterung-Welser-Armada.png/220px-Musterung-Welser-Armada.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="167" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Musterung-Welser-Armada.png/330px-Musterung-Welser-Armada.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Musterung-Welser-Armada.png/440px-Musterung-Welser-Armada.png 2x" data-file-width="678" data-file-height="515"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Musterung-Welser-Armada.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The German <a href="/wiki/Welser" class="mw-redirect" title="Welser">Welser</a> Armada exploring Venezuela.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 1498, during his third voyage to the Americas, <a href="/wiki/Christopher_Columbus" title="Christopher Columbus">Christopher Columbus</a> sailed near the Orinoco Delta and landed in the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Paria" title="Gulf of Paria">Gulf of Paria</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDickey1892103_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDickey1892103-41">[39]</a></sup> Amazed by the great offshore current of freshwater which deflected his course eastward, Columbus expressed in a letter to Isabella and Ferdinand that he must have reached Heaven on Earth (terrestrial paradise): </p> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r996844942">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style>
      <blockquote class="templatequote">
       <p>Great signs are these of the Terrestrial Paradise, for the site conforms to the opinion of the holy and wise theologians whom I have mentioned. And likewise, the [other] signs conform very well, for I have never read or heard of such a large quantity of fresh water being inside and in such close proximity to salt water; the very mild temperateness also corroborates this; and if the water of which I speak does not proceed from Paradise then it is an even greater marvel, because I do not believe such a large and deep river has ever been known to exist in this world.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZamora1993Voyage_to_Paradise_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZamora1993Voyage_to_Paradise-42">[40]</a></sup></p>
      </blockquote> 
      <p>Spain's colonization of mainland Venezuela started in 1522, establishing its first permanent South American settlement in the present-day<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Venezuela&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> city of <a href="/wiki/Cuman%C3%A1" title="Cumaná">Cumaná</a>. In the 16th century, Venezuela was contracted as a concession by the King of Spain to the German <a href="/wiki/Welser" class="mw-redirect" title="Welser">Welser</a> banking family (<a href="/wiki/Klein-Venedig" title="Klein-Venedig">Klein-Venedig</a>, 1528–1546). Native <i><a href="/wiki/Cacique" title="Cacique">caciques</a></i> (leaders) such as <a href="/wiki/Guaicaipuro" title="Guaicaipuro">Guaicaipuro</a> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 1530–1568</span>) and <a href="/wiki/Tamanaco" title="Tamanaco">Tamanaco</a> (died 1573) attempted to resist Spanish incursions, but the newcomers ultimately subdued them; Tamanaco was put to death by order of Caracas' founder, <a href="/wiki/Diego_de_Losada" title="Diego de Losada">Diego de Losada</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-UNE_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNE-43">[41]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the 16th century, during the Spanish colonization, indigenous peoples such as many of the <a href="/wiki/Mariches" class="mw-redirect" title="Mariches">Mariches</a>, themselves descendants of the Kalina, converted to <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholicism">Roman Catholicism</a>. Some of the resisting tribes or leaders are commemorated in place names, including Caracas, <a href="/wiki/Chacao_Municipality" title="Chacao Municipality">Chacao</a> and <a href="/wiki/Los_Teques" title="Los Teques">Los Teques</a>. The early colonial settlements focused on the northern coast,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWunder2003130_37-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWunder2003130-37">[35]</a></sup> but in the mid-18th century, the Spanish pushed farther inland along the <a href="/wiki/Orinoco_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Orinoco River">Orinoco River</a>. Here, the <a href="/wiki/Ye%27kuana" title="Ye'kuana">Ye'kuana</a> (then known as the Makiritare) organized serious resistance in 1775 and 1776.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGott2005203_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGott2005203-44">[42]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Spain's eastern Venezuelan settlements were incorporated into <a href="/wiki/New_Andalusia_Province" title="New Andalusia Province">New Andalusia Province</a>. Administered by the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Audiencia_of_Santo_Domingo" class="mw-redirect" title="Royal Audiencia of Santo Domingo">Royal Audiencia of Santo Domingo</a> from the early 16th century, most of Venezuela became part of the <a href="/wiki/Viceroyalty_of_New_Granada" title="Viceroyalty of New Granada">Viceroyalty of New Granada</a> in the early 18th century, and was then reorganized as an autonomous <a href="/wiki/Captaincy_General_of_Venezuela" title="Captaincy General of Venezuela">Captaincy General</a> starting in 1777. The town of Caracas, founded in the central coastal region in 1567, was well-placed to become a key location, being near the coastal port of <a href="/wiki/La_Guaira" title="La Guaira">La Guaira</a> whilst itself being located in a valley in a mountain range, providing defensive strength against <a href="/wiki/Pirate" class="mw-redirect" title="Pirate">pirates</a> and a more fertile and healthy climate.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEwell19844_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEwell19844-45">[43]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Independence_and_19th_century">Independence and 19th century</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Venezuelan_War_of_Independence" title="Venezuelan War of Independence">Venezuelan War of Independence</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar_2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar_2.jpg/170px-Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar_2.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="222" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar_2.jpg/255px-Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar_2.jpg/340px-Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar_2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1525" data-file-height="1990"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar_2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><i>El Libertador</i>, <a href="/wiki/Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar" title="Simón Bolívar">Simón Bolívar</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>After a series of unsuccessful uprisings, Venezuela, under the leadership of <a href="/wiki/Francisco_de_Miranda" title="Francisco de Miranda">Francisco de Miranda</a>, a Venezuelan marshal who had fought in the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolution" title="American Revolution">American Revolution</a> and the <a href="/wiki/French_Revolution" title="French Revolution">French Revolution</a>, <a href="/wiki/Venezuelan_Declaration_of_Independence" title="Venezuelan Declaration of Independence">declared independence</a> as the <a href="/wiki/First_Republic_of_Venezuela" title="First Republic of Venezuela">First Republic of Venezuela</a> on 5 July 1811.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[44]</a></sup> This began the <a href="/wiki/Venezuelan_War_of_Independence" title="Venezuelan War of Independence">Venezuelan War of Independence</a>. A devastating <a href="/wiki/1812_Caracas_earthquake" title="1812 Caracas earthquake">earthquake that struck Caracas in 1812</a>, together with the rebellion of the Venezuelan <i><a href="/wiki/Llanero" title="Llanero">llaneros</a></i>, helped bring down the republic.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChasteen2001103_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChasteen2001103-47">[45]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar" title="Simón Bolívar">Simón Bolívar</a>, new leader of the independentist forces, launched his <a href="/wiki/Admirable_Campaign" title="Admirable Campaign">Admirable Campaign</a> in 1813 from <a href="/wiki/United_Provinces_of_New_Granada" title="United Provinces of New Granada">New Granada</a>, retaking most of the territory and being proclaimed as <i>El Libertador</i> ("The Liberator"). A <a href="/wiki/Second_Republic_of_Venezuela" title="Second Republic of Venezuela">second Venezuelan republic</a> was proclaimed on 7 August 1813, but lasted only a few months before being crushed at the hands of <a href="/wiki/Royalist_(Spanish_American_independence)" title="Royalist (Spanish American independence)">royalist</a> caudillo <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Tom%C3%A1s_Boves" title="José Tomás Boves">José Tomás Boves</a> and his personal army of llaneros.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[46]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The end of the <a href="/wiki/Peninsular_War" title="Peninsular War">French invasion</a> of homeland Spain in 1814 allowed the preparation of a large expeditionary force to the American provinces under general <a href="/wiki/Pablo_Morillo" title="Pablo Morillo">Pablo Morillo</a>, with the goal to regain the lost territory in Venezuela and New Granada. As the war reached a stalemate on 1817, Bolívar reestablished the <a href="/wiki/Third_Republic_of_Venezuela" title="Third Republic of Venezuela">Third Republic of Venezuela</a> on the territory still controlled by the patriots, mainly in the <a href="/wiki/Guayana_Province" title="Guayana Province">Guayana</a> and <a href="/wiki/Llanos" title="Llanos">Llanos</a> regions. This republic was short-lived as only two years later, during the <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Angostura" title="Congress of Angostura">Congress of Angostura</a> of 1819, the union of Venezuela with New Granada was decreed to form the Republic of Colombia (historiographically <a href="/wiki/Gran_Colombia" title="Gran Colombia">Republic of Gran Colombia</a>). The war continued for some years, until full victory and <a href="/wiki/Sovereignty" title="Sovereignty">sovereignty</a> was attained after Bolívar, aided by <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Antonio_P%C3%A1ez" title="José Antonio Páez">José Antonio Páez</a> and <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Jos%C3%A9_de_Sucre" title="Antonio José de Sucre">Antonio José de Sucre</a>, won the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Carabobo" title="Battle of Carabobo">Battle of Carabobo</a> on 24 June 1821.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGregory199289–90_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGregory199289–90-49">[47]</a></sup> On 24 July 1823, <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Prudencio_Padilla" title="José Prudencio Padilla">José Prudencio Padilla</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rafael_Urdaneta" title="Rafael Urdaneta">Rafael Urdaneta</a> helped seal Venezuelan independence with their victory in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Lake_Maracaibo" title="Battle of Lake Maracaibo">Battle of Lake Maracaibo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ciawfb_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ciawfb-50">[48]</a></sup> New Granada's congress gave Bolívar control of the Granadian army; leading it, he liberated several countries and founded the Republic of Colombia (<a href="/wiki/Gran_Colombia" title="Gran Colombia">Gran Colombia</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGregory199289–90_49-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGregory199289–90-49">[47]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:19_de_abril.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/19_de_abril.jpg/220px-19_de_abril.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="139" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/19_de_abril.jpg/330px-19_de_abril.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/19_de_abril.jpg/440px-19_de_abril.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1260" data-file-height="795"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:19_de_abril.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><i>Revolution of 19 April 1810</i>, the beginning of Venezuela's independence, by <a href="/wiki/Mart%C3%ADn_Tovar_y_Tovar" title="Martín Tovar y Tovar">Martín Tovar y Tovar</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Sucre, who won many battles for Bolívar, went on to liberate <a href="/wiki/Ecuador" title="Ecuador">Ecuador</a> and later become the second president of <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a>. Venezuela remained part of Gran Colombia until 1830, when a rebellion led by Páez allowed the proclamation of a newly independent Venezuela; Páez became the first president of the new <a href="/wiki/State_of_Venezuela" title="State of Venezuela">State of Venezuela</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[49]</a></sup> Between one-quarter and one-third of Venezuela's population was lost during these two decades of warfare (including perhaps one-half of the <a href="/wiki/Venezuelans_of_European_descent" title="Venezuelans of European descent">white</a> population),<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[50]</a></sup> which by 1830, was estimated at about 800,000.<sup id="cite_ref-Caudillismo_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Caudillismo-53">[51]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The colors of the <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_Venezuela" title="Flag of Venezuela">Venezuelan flag</a> are yellow, blue, and red: the yellow stands for land wealth, the blue for the sea that separates Venezuela from Spain, and the red for the blood shed by the heroes of independence.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[52]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Slavery" title="Slavery">Slavery</a> in Venezuela was abolished in 1854.<sup id="cite_ref-Caudillismo_53-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Caudillismo-53">[51]</a></sup> Much of Venezuela's 19th-century history was characterized by political turmoil and dictatorial rule, including the Independence leader José Antonio Páez, who gained the presidency three times and served a total of 11 years between 1830 and 1863. This culminated in the <a href="/wiki/Federal_War" title="Federal War">Federal War</a> (1859–1863), a civil war in which hundreds of thousands died in a country with a population of not much more than a million people. In the latter half of the century, <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Guzm%C3%A1n_Blanco" title="Antonio Guzmán Blanco">Antonio Guzmán Blanco</a>, another <i>caudillo</i>, served a total of 13 years between 1870 and 1887, with three other presidents interspersed. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Martin_Tovar_y_Tovar_02.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Martin_Tovar_y_Tovar_02.jpg/220px-Martin_Tovar_y_Tovar_02.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="148" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Martin_Tovar_y_Tovar_02.jpg/330px-Martin_Tovar_y_Tovar_02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/Martin_Tovar_y_Tovar_02.jpg/440px-Martin_Tovar_y_Tovar_02.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1455" data-file-height="980"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Martin_Tovar_y_Tovar_02.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The signing of Venezuela's independence, by <a href="/wiki/Mart%C3%ADn_Tovar_y_Tovar" title="Martín Tovar y Tovar">Martín Tovar y Tovar</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 1895, a longstanding dispute with Great Britain about the territory of Guayana Esequiba, which Britain claimed as part of <a href="/wiki/British_Guiana" title="British Guiana">British Guiana</a> and Venezuela saw as Venezuelan territory, erupted into the <a href="/wiki/Venezuela_Crisis_of_1895" class="mw-redirect" title="Venezuela Crisis of 1895">Venezuela Crisis of 1895</a>. The dispute became a diplomatic crisis when Venezuela's lobbyist, <a href="/wiki/William_Lindsay_Scruggs" title="William Lindsay Scruggs">William L. Scruggs</a>, sought to argue that British behavior over the issue violated the United States' <a href="/wiki/Monroe_Doctrine" title="Monroe Doctrine">Monroe Doctrine</a> of 1823, and used his influence in Washington, D.C., to pursue the matter. Then, U.S. president <a href="/wiki/Grover_Cleveland" title="Grover Cleveland">Grover Cleveland</a> adopted a broad interpretation of the doctrine that did not just simply forbid new European colonies, but declared an American interest in any matter within the hemisphere.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEZakaria1999145–146_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEZakaria1999145–146-55">[53]</a></sup> Britain ultimately accepted arbitration, but in negotiations over its terms was able to persuade the U.S. on many of the details. A tribunal convened in Paris in 1898 to decide the issue and in 1899 awarded the bulk of the disputed territory to British Guiana.<sup id="cite_ref-Humphreys_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Humphreys-56">[54]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 1899, <a href="/wiki/Cipriano_Castro" title="Cipriano Castro">Cipriano Castro</a>, assisted by his friend <a href="/wiki/Juan_Vicente_G%C3%B3mez" title="Juan Vicente Gómez">Juan Vicente Gómez</a>, seized power in Caracas, marching an army from his base in the Andean state of <a href="/wiki/T%C3%A1chira" title="Táchira">Táchira</a>. Castro defaulted on Venezuela's considerable foreign debts and declined to pay compensation to foreigners caught up in Venezuela's civil wars. This led to the <a href="/wiki/Venezuela_Crisis_of_1902%E2%80%931903" class="mw-redirect" title="Venezuela Crisis of 1902–1903">Venezuela Crisis of 1902–1903</a>, in which Britain, Germany and Italy imposed a naval blockade of several months before international arbitration at the new <a href="/wiki/Permanent_Court_of_Arbitration" title="Permanent Court of Arbitration">Permanent Court of Arbitration</a> in <a href="/wiki/The_Hague" title="The Hague">The Hague</a> was agreed. In 1908, <a href="/wiki/Dutch-Venezuela_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Dutch-Venezuela War">another dispute</a> broke out with the Netherlands, which was resolved when Castro left for medical treatment in Germany and was promptly overthrown by Juan Vicente Gómez (1908–1935). </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="20th_century">20th century</span></h3> 
      <table class="box-POV plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-POV" role="presentation">
       <tbody>
        <tr>
         <td class="mbox-image">
          <div style="width:52px">
           <img alt="Unbalanced scales.svg" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Unbalanced_scales.svg/45px-Unbalanced_scales.svg.png" decoding="async" width="45" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Unbalanced_scales.svg/68px-Unbalanced_scales.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Unbalanced_scales.svg/90px-Unbalanced_scales.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="400" data-file-height="354">
          </div></td>
         <td class="mbox-text">
          <div class="mbox-text-span">
           The <b><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Neutral_point_of_view" title="Wikipedia:Neutral point of view">neutrality</a> of this section is <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NPOV_dispute" title="Wikipedia:NPOV dispute">disputed</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Relevant discussion may be found on the <a href="/wiki/Talk:Venezuela##" title="Talk:Venezuela">talk page</a>. Please do not remove this message until <a href="/wiki/Template:POV#When_to_remove" title="Template:POV">conditions to do so are met</a>.</span> <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">December 2018</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <table class="box-More_citations_needed_section plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-Refimprove" role="presentation">
       <tbody>
        <tr>
         <td class="mbox-image">
          <div style="width:52px">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="39" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/75px-Question_book-new.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/100px-Question_book-new.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="399"></a>
          </div></td>
         <td class="mbox-text">
          <div class="mbox-text-span">
           This section <b>needs additional citations for <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">verification</a></b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help <a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Venezuela&amp;action=edit">improve this article</a> by <a href="/wiki/Help:Referencing_for_beginners" title="Help:Referencing for beginners">adding citations to reliable sources</a>. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.</span> <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">July 2017</span>)</i></small><small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:State_flag_of_Venezuela_(1954%E2%80%932006).svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/State_flag_of_Venezuela_%281954%E2%80%932006%29.svg/220px-State_flag_of_Venezuela_%281954%E2%80%932006%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/State_flag_of_Venezuela_%281954%E2%80%932006%29.svg/330px-State_flag_of_Venezuela_%281954%E2%80%932006%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/State_flag_of_Venezuela_%281954%E2%80%932006%29.svg/440px-State_flag_of_Venezuela_%281954%E2%80%932006%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="600"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Flag_of_Venezuela_(1954-2006).svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Flag of Venezuela between 1954 and 2006.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The discovery of massive <a href="/wiki/Oil_field" class="mw-redirect" title="Oil field">oil deposits</a> in Lake Maracaibo during World War I<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[55]</a></sup> proved to be pivotal for Venezuela and transformed the basis of its economy from a heavy dependence on agricultural exports. It prompted an economic boom that lasted into the 1980s; by 1935, Venezuela's per capita gross domestic product was Latin America's highest.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECrow1980616–617_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrow1980616–617-58">[56]</a></sup> Gómez benefited handsomely from this, as corruption thrived, but at the same time, the new source of income helped him centralize the Venezuelan state and develop its authority. </p>
      <p>He remained the most powerful man in Venezuela until his death in 1935, although at times he ceded the presidency to others. The <i>gomecista</i> dictatorship (1935–1945) system largely continued under <a href="/wiki/Eleazar_L%C3%B3pez_Contreras" title="Eleazar López Contreras">Eleazar López Contreras</a>, but from 1941, under <a href="/wiki/Isa%C3%ADas_Medina_Angarita" title="Isaías Medina Angarita">Isaías Medina Angarita</a>, was relaxed. Angarita granted a range of reforms, including the legalization of all political parties. After <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, immigration from Southern Europe (mainly from Spain, <a href="/wiki/Italo-venezuelans" class="mw-redirect" title="Italo-venezuelans">Italy</a>, Portugal, and France) and poorer Latin American countries markedly diversified Venezuelan society. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:R%C3%B3mulo_Betancourt,_1961.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/R%C3%B3mulo_Betancourt%2C_1961.jpg/220px-R%C3%B3mulo_Betancourt%2C_1961.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="210" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/86/R%C3%B3mulo_Betancourt%2C_1961.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="244" data-file-height="233"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:R%C3%B3mulo_Betancourt,_1961.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/R%C3%B3mulo_Betancourt" title="Rómulo Betancourt">Rómulo Betancourt</a> (president 1945–1948 / 1959–1964), one of the major democracy activists of Venezuela.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 1945, a civilian-military coup overthrew Medina Angarita and ushered in <a href="/wiki/El_Trienio_Adeco" title="El Trienio Adeco">a three-year period of democratic rule</a> (1945–1948) under the mass membership party <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Action_(Venezuela)" title="Democratic Action (Venezuela)">Democratic Action</a>, initially under <a href="/wiki/R%C3%B3mulo_Betancourt" title="Rómulo Betancourt">Rómulo Betancourt</a>, until <a href="/wiki/R%C3%B3mulo_Gallegos" title="Rómulo Gallegos">Rómulo Gallegos</a> won the <a href="/wiki/1947_Venezuelan_presidential_election" class="mw-redirect" title="1947 Venezuelan presidential election">1947 Venezuelan presidential election</a> (generally believed to be the first free and fair elections in Venezuela).<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[57]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[58]</a></sup> Gallegos governed until overthrown by a military junta led by the triumvirate Luis Felipe Llovera Páez, <a href="/wiki/Marcos_P%C3%A9rez_Jim%C3%A9nez" title="Marcos Pérez Jiménez">Marcos Pérez Jiménez</a>, and Gallegos' Defense Minister, <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Delgado_Chalbaud" title="Carlos Delgado Chalbaud">Carlos Delgado Chalbaud</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/1948_Venezuelan_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1948 Venezuelan coup d'état">1948 Venezuelan <i>coup d'état</i></a>. </p>
      <p>The most powerful man in the military <i>junta</i> (1948–1958) was Pérez Jiménez (though Chalbaud was its titular president) and was suspected of being behind the death in office of Chalbaud, who died in a bungled kidnapping in 1950. When the junta unexpectedly lost the <a href="/wiki/1952_Venezuelan_presidential_election" class="mw-redirect" title="1952 Venezuelan presidential election">election it held in 1952</a>, it ignored the results and Pérez Jiménez was installed as president, where he remained until 1958. The expansion of the Venezuelan economy in this period was based on the indebtedness of the Venezuelan nation and that was one of the causes of the economic crisis in Venezuela in the 1960s,<sup id="cite_ref-:03_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:03-61">[59]</a></sup> in which important projects such as the Urban Center El Recreo de Marcel Brauer on Avenida Casanova in <a href="/wiki/Sabana_Grande,_Caracas" title="Sabana Grande, Caracas">Sabana Grande</a> district were paralyzed.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[60]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>During the years of Pérez Jiménez's administration, the State intervened in areas of the economy that were traditionally carried out by private companies. The Pérez Jiménez government was characterized by its state capitalism and not by liberal capitalism. It was an antecedent of the populist and paternalistic economic regime of the later democratic regimes.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[61]</a></sup> The national private entrepreneurship increasingly had less space to grow and prosper. The State was the great capitalist in the Venezuela of Pérez Jiménez and was the largest national shareholder of major hotel chains such as Sheraton.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[62]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the government of <a href="/wiki/Marcos_P%C3%A9rez_Jim%C3%A9nez" title="Marcos Pérez Jiménez">Pérez Jiménez</a>, Venezuela's debt grew more than 25 times and went from 175 million to more than 4,500&nbsp;million bolivares in just 5 years (approximately 15&nbsp;billion dollars in 2018). The malaise over the debts of Venezuela reached the barracks and the national business. Pérez Jiménez responded that: "there is no debt, but commitments". The Finance Minister failed to convince Pérez Jiménez to order the cancellation of debts.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[63]</a></sup> As of 14 January 1958, the Venezuelan business community decided to divorce itself completely from the regime, nine days before the collapse of the government.<sup id="cite_ref-:03_61-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:03-61">[59]</a></sup> The military dictator Pérez Jiménez was forced out on 23 January 1958.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-66">[64]</a></sup> In an effort to consolidate a young democracy, the three major political parties (<a href="/wiki/Acci%C3%B3n_Democr%C3%A1tica" class="mw-redirect" title="Acción Democrática">Acción Democrática</a> (AD), <a href="/wiki/COPEI" class="mw-redirect" title="COPEI">COPEI</a> and <a href="/wiki/Uni%C3%B3n_Republicana_Democr%C3%A1tica" class="mw-redirect" title="Unión Republicana Democrática">Unión Republicana Democrática</a> (URD), with the notable exception of the <a href="/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Venezuela" title="Communist Party of Venezuela">Communist Party of Venezuela</a>) signed the <a href="/wiki/Puntofijo_Pact" title="Puntofijo Pact">Puntofijo Pact</a> power-sharing agreement. The two first parties would dominate the political landscape for four decades. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Mesa_donde_se_firm%C3%B3_el_Pacto_de_Punto_Fijo.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Mesa_donde_se_firm%C3%B3_el_Pacto_de_Punto_Fijo.jpg/220px-Mesa_donde_se_firm%C3%B3_el_Pacto_de_Punto_Fijo.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="158" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Mesa_donde_se_firm%C3%B3_el_Pacto_de_Punto_Fijo.jpg/330px-Mesa_donde_se_firm%C3%B3_el_Pacto_de_Punto_Fijo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Mesa_donde_se_firm%C3%B3_el_Pacto_de_Punto_Fijo.jpg/440px-Mesa_donde_se_firm%C3%B3_el_Pacto_de_Punto_Fijo.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1510" data-file-height="1086"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Mesa_donde_se_firm%C3%B3_el_Pacto_de_Punto_Fijo.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Table where the <a href="/wiki/Puntofijo_Pact" title="Puntofijo Pact">Puntofijo Pact</a> was signed on 31 October 1958
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>During the presidencies of <a href="/wiki/R%C3%B3mulo_Betancourt" title="Rómulo Betancourt">Rómulo Ernesto Betancourt Bello</a> (1959–1964, his second time) and <a href="/wiki/Ra%C3%BAl_Leoni" title="Raúl Leoni">Raúl Leoni</a> Otero (1964–1969) in the 1960s, substantial guerilla movements occurred, including the <a href="/wiki/Armed_Forces_of_National_Liberation_(Venezuela)" title="Armed Forces of National Liberation (Venezuela)">Armed Forces of National Liberation</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Revolutionary_Left_Movement_(Venezuela)" title="Revolutionary Left Movement (Venezuela)">Revolutionary Left Movement</a>, which had split from AD in 1960. Most of these movements laid down their arms under <a href="/wiki/Rafael_Caldera" title="Rafael Caldera">Rafael Caldera</a>'s first presidency (1969–1974); Caldera had won the <a href="/wiki/1968_Venezuelan_presidential_election" class="mw-redirect" title="1968 Venezuelan presidential election">1968 election</a> for COPEI, being the first time a party other than Democratic Action took the presidency through a democratic election. The new democratic order had its antagonists. Betancourt suffered an attack planned by the Dominican dictator Rafael Trujillo in 1960, and the leftists excluded from the Pact initiated an armed insurgency by organizing themselves in the Armed Forces of National Liberation, sponsored by the Communist Party and Fidel Castro. In 1962 they tried to destabilize the military corps, with failed revolts in Carúpano and Puerto Cabello. At the same time, Betancourt promoted a foreign policy, the <a href="/wiki/Betancourt_Doctrine" class="mw-redirect" title="Betancourt Doctrine">Betancourt Doctrine</a>, in which he only recognized elected governments by popular vote.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="Quotation needed from source to verify. (April 2018)">need quotation to verify</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>As a result of the debt that Marcos Pérez Jiménez had left, an economic adjustment program was necessary in Venezuela. The Economic Recovery Plan of 1960 was formulated by Tomás Enrique Carrillo Batalla. The construction industry was revitalized through the "rediscount" of the Central Bank of Venezuela. The Economic Recovery Plan fulfilled its objectives and in 1964, Venezuela was able to return to an anchored exchange rate, with free purchase and sale of foreign currency. This system lasted until the <a href="/wiki/Viernes_Negro" title="Viernes Negro">Venezuelan Black Friday of 1983</a>, although the model was already running out at the end of the seventies.<sup id="cite_ref-:132_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:132-67">[65]</a></sup> The consolidation of the democratic system and the dissipation of fears of political radicalization of the country contributed to normalize the demand for foreign currency, stabilizing the parallel exchange rate. </p>
      <p>For much of the period between 1950 and 1973, the Venezuelan economy was characterized by its stability and sustained strength, factors that contributed decisively to being able to maintain a fixed exchange rate without major inconveniences. In the period of <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Andr%C3%A9s_P%C3%A9rez" title="Carlos Andrés Pérez">Carlos Andrés Pérez</a> (1974–1979, his first time as president), as a result of the Arab-Israeli war (the <a href="/wiki/Yom_Kippur_War" title="Yom Kippur War">Yom Kippur War</a>), the average price of a barrel of oil went from 3.71 to 10.53 dollars and continued to rise to exceed 29 dollars in 1981.<sup id="cite_ref-:132_67-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:132-67">[65]</a></sup> The income of the public sector went from 18,960 million bolivars in 1973 to 45.564&nbsp;million in 1974. The economic bonanza also had the characteristics of an economic bubble, but Venezuelans remember the "Ta barato, dame dos".<sup id="cite_ref-:152_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:152-68">[66]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:05_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:05-69">[67]</a></sup> The increased inflow of funds to savings and loan entities and mortgage banks allowed an increase in the mortgage loan portfolio, which also tripled. In general, Venezuela was a prosperous country in the governments of Rómulo Betancourt (1945&nbsp;– <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 1948</span>; 1959–1964), Rafael Caldera (1969–1974; 1994&nbsp;– <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 1999</span>) and Carlos Andrés Pérez (1974–1979; 1989&nbsp;– <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 1993</span>)<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (August 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>. In 1975 the iron industry was nationalized and the following year the oil industry, creating Petróleos de Venezuela, S.A. (PDVSA). Both Caldera and Pérez partially broke with the <a href="/wiki/Betancourt_Doctrine" class="mw-redirect" title="Betancourt Doctrine">Betancourt Doctrine</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Sabana_Grande._Caracas._A%C3%B1o_1954.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Sabana_Grande._Caracas._A%C3%B1o_1954.png/220px-Sabana_Grande._Caracas._A%C3%B1o_1954.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Sabana_Grande._Caracas._A%C3%B1o_1954.png/330px-Sabana_Grande._Caracas._A%C3%B1o_1954.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b0/Sabana_Grande._Caracas._A%C3%B1o_1954.png 2x" data-file-width="400" data-file-height="300"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Sabana_Grande._Caracas._A%C3%B1o_1954.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Sabana_Grande,_Caracas" title="Sabana Grande, Caracas">Sabana Grande</a> district, <a href="/wiki/Caracas" title="Caracas">Caracas</a> (1954)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/1973_Venezuelan_presidential_election" class="mw-redirect" title="1973 Venezuelan presidential election">The election in 1973</a> of <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Andr%C3%A9s_P%C3%A9rez" title="Carlos Andrés Pérez">Carlos Andrés Pérez</a> coincided with an <a href="/wiki/1973_oil_crisis" title="1973 oil crisis">oil crisis</a>, in which Venezuela's income exploded as <a href="/wiki/Oil_prices" class="mw-redirect" title="Oil prices">oil prices</a> soared; oil industries were nationalized in 1976. This led to massive increases in public spending, but also increases in external debts, which continued into the 1980s when the collapse of oil prices during the 1980s crippled the Venezuelan economy. As the government started to devalue the currency in February 1983 to face its financial obligations, Venezuelans' real standards of living fell dramatically. A number of failed economic policies and increasing corruption in government led to rising poverty and crime, worsening social indicators, and increased political instability.<sup id="cite_ref-Schuyler_2001_10_70-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Schuyler_2001_10-70">[68]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>During the presidency of <a href="/wiki/Luis_Herrera_Campins" title="Luis Herrera Campins">Luis Herrera Campins</a> (1979–1984), important infrastructure works were completed, such as the <a href="/wiki/Parque_Central_Complex" title="Parque Central Complex">Parque Central Complex</a> (which became the largest housing complex and the tallest towers in Latin America), Teresa Carreño Cultural Complex (the largest cultural center in South America at that time), the Brígido Iriarte Stadium and the United Nations Park. Most of these works had been previously planned.<sup id="cite_ref-:152_68-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:152-68">[66]</a></sup> Until the mid-eighties, the Venezuelan economy showed a very positive behavior, characterized by the absence of internal or external imbalances, high economic growth, largely due to the sustained and very high gross fixed investment of those years, 10 under unemployment and great price stability. This translated into sustained increases in the average real wage and an improvement in the condition of life.<sup id="cite_ref-:132_67-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:132-67">[65]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Carlos_Andr%C3%A9s_P%C3%A9rez.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Carlos_Andr%C3%A9s_P%C3%A9rez.jpg/170px-Carlos_Andr%C3%A9s_P%C3%A9rez.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="213" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/08/Carlos_Andr%C3%A9s_P%C3%A9rez.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="240" data-file-height="300"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Carlos_Andr%C3%A9s_P%C3%A9rez.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>President <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Andr%C3%A9s_P%C3%A9rez" title="Carlos Andrés Pérez">Carlos Andrés Pérez</a> was <a href="/wiki/Impeachment" title="Impeachment">impeached</a> on corruption charges in 1993.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The bolivar was devalued in February 1983, unleashing a strong economic crisis, which hit investments in the most important financial centers of the Venezuelan capital, such as <a href="/wiki/Sabana_Grande,_Caracas" title="Sabana Grande, Caracas">Sabana Grande</a>. In the government of <a href="/wiki/Jaime_Lusinchi" title="Jaime Lusinchi">Jaime Lusinchi</a> (1984–1989), an attempt was made to solve the problem. Unfortunately, the measures failed. After a long period of accelerated economic expansion that lasts for six decades (value of the stock of homes by families), an extreme higher value is reached towards 1982. From this historical value begins then a systematic fall that mounts to 26 hundred up to 2006, and that configures a genuine unique experience in contemporary economic life.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[69]</a></sup> However, the economic deactivation of the country had begun to show its first signs in 1978.<sup id="cite_ref-:32_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:32-72">[70]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the 1980s, the Presidential Commission for State Reform (COPRE) emerged as a mechanism of political innovation. Venezuela was preparing for the decentralization of its political system and the diversification of its economy, reducing the large size of the State. The COPRE operated as an innovation mechanism, also by incorporating issues into the political agenda that were generally excluded from public deliberation by the main actors of the Venezuelan democratic system. The most discussed topics were incorporated into the public agenda: decentralization, political participation, municipalization, judicial oder reforms and the role of the State in a new economic strategy. Unfortunately, the social reality of the country made the changes difficult to apply.<sup id="cite_ref-:32_72-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:32-72">[70]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Economic crises in the 1980s and 1990s led to a political crisis in which hundreds died in the <i><a href="/wiki/Caracazo" title="Caracazo">Caracazo</a></i> riots of 1989 during the presidency of Carlos Andres Pérez (1989–1993, his second time), <a href="/wiki/1992_Venezuelan_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat_attempts" title="1992 Venezuelan coup d'état attempts">two attempted coups d'état in 1992 (February and November)</a> by <a href="/wiki/Hugo_Ch%C3%A1vez" title="Hugo Chávez">Hugo Chávez</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-BBCprofile_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBCprofile-73">[71]</a></sup> and the impeachment of President Carlos Andrés Pérez (re-elected in 1988) for corruption in 1993 and the interim presidency of <a href="/wiki/Ram%C3%B3n_Jos%C3%A9_Vel%C3%A1squez" title="Ramón José Velásquez">Ramón José Velásquez</a> (1993–1994). Coup leader Hugo Chávez <a href="/wiki/Rafael_Caldera#Amnesty_to_the_1992_coup_participants" title="Rafael Caldera">was pardoned in March 1994</a> by president Rafael Caldera (1994–1999, his second time), with a clean slate and his political rights reinstated. This let him later get the presidency continuously from 1999 until his death in 2013, winning the elections of 1998, 2000, 2006 and 2012 and the presidential referendum of 2004, with the only exception in 2002 of <a href="/wiki/Pedro_Carmona_Estanga" class="mw-redirect" title="Pedro Carmona Estanga">Pedro Carmona Estanga</a> as a <a href="/wiki/2002_Venezuelan_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat_attempt" title="2002 Venezuelan coup d'état attempt">two-day de facto government</a> and <a href="/wiki/Diosdado_Cabello_Rond%C3%B3n" class="mw-redirect" title="Diosdado Cabello Rondón">Diosdado Cabello Rondón</a> as a few-hours interim president. </p> 
      <h3><span id="Bolivarian_government:_1999.E2.80.93present"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Bolivarian_government:_1999–present">Bolivarian government: 1999–present</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Bolivarian_Revolution" title="Bolivarian Revolution">Bolivarian Revolution</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The Bolivarian Revolution refers to a <a href="/wiki/Left-wing_populism" title="Left-wing populism">left-wing populism</a> <a href="/wiki/Social_movement" title="Social movement">social movement</a> and political process in Venezuela led by Venezuelan president <a href="/wiki/Hugo_Ch%C3%A1vez" title="Hugo Chávez">Hugo Chávez</a>, who founded the <a href="/wiki/Fifth_Republic_Movement" title="Fifth Republic Movement">Fifth Republic Movement</a> in 1997 and the <a href="/wiki/United_Socialist_Party_of_Venezuela" title="United Socialist Party of Venezuela">United Socialist Party of Venezuela</a> in 2007. The "Bolivarian Revolution" is named after <a href="/wiki/Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar" title="Simón Bolívar">Simón Bolívar</a>, an early 19th-century Venezuelan and Latin American revolutionary leader, prominent in the <a href="/wiki/Spanish_American_wars_of_independence" title="Spanish American wars of independence">Spanish American wars of independence</a> in achieving the independence of most of northern South America from Spanish rule. According to Chávez and other supporters, the "Bolivarian Revolution" seeks to build a mass movement to implement <a href="/wiki/Bolivarianism" title="Bolivarianism">Bolivarianism</a>—<a href="/wiki/Popular_democracy" title="Popular democracy">popular democracy</a>, economic independence, equitable distribution of revenues, and an end to political corruption—in Venezuela. They interpret Bolívar's ideas from a <a href="/wiki/Populism" title="Populism">populist</a> perspective, using <a href="/wiki/Socialism" title="Socialism">socialist</a> rhetoric. </p> 
      <h4><span id="Hugo_Ch.C3.A1vez:_1999.E2.80.932013"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Hugo_Chávez:_1999–2013">Hugo Chávez: 1999–2013</span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Hugo_Ch%C3%A1vez" class="mw-redirect" title="Presidency of Hugo Chávez">Presidency of Hugo Chávez</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Chavez_Kirch_Lula141597.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Chavez_Kirch_Lula141597.jpg/220px-Chavez_Kirch_Lula141597.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="111" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Chavez_Kirch_Lula141597.jpg/330px-Chavez_Kirch_Lula141597.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Chavez_Kirch_Lula141597.jpg/440px-Chavez_Kirch_Lula141597.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3506" data-file-height="1769"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Chavez_Kirch_Lula141597.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Chávez with fellow South American presidents <a href="/wiki/N%C3%A9stor_Kirchner" title="Néstor Kirchner">Néstor Kirchner</a> of Argentina and <a href="/wiki/Luiz_In%C3%A1cio_Lula_da_Silva" title="Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva">Lula da Silva</a> of Brazil
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>A collapse in confidence in the existing parties led to Chávez being elected president in 1998 and the subsequent launch of a "Bolivarian Revolution", beginning with a 1999 Constituent Assembly to write a new Constitution of Venezuela. Chávez also initiated <a href="/wiki/Bolivarian_missions" title="Bolivarian missions">Bolivarian missions</a>, programs aimed at helping the poor.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[72]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In April 2002, Chávez was briefly ousted from power in the <a href="/wiki/2002_Venezuelan_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat_attempt" title="2002 Venezuelan coup d'état attempt">2002 Venezuelan coup d'état attempt</a> following popular demonstrations by his opponents,<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[73]</a></sup> but he returned to power after two days as a result of demonstrations by poor Chávez supporters in Caracas and actions by the military.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECannon2004295_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECannon2004295-76">[74]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELópez_Maya200516_77-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELópez_Maya200516-77">[75]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Chávez also remained in power after an all-out national strike that lasted <a href="/wiki/Venezuelan_general_strike_of_2002%E2%80%932003" title="Venezuelan general strike of 2002–2003">from December 2002 to February 2003</a>, including a strike/lockout in the state oil company <a href="/wiki/PDVSA" title="PDVSA">PDVSA</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[76]</a></sup> The strike produced severe economic dislocation, with the country's GDP falling 27% during the first four months of 2003, and costing the oil industry $13.3&nbsp;billion.<sup id="cite_ref-J386_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-J386-79">[77]</a></sup> Capital flight before and during the strike led to the reimposition of currency controls (which had been abolished in 1989), managed by the <a href="/wiki/CADIVI" class="mw-redirect" title="CADIVI">CADIVI</a> agency. In the subsequent decade, the government was forced into several currency devaluations.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[78]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[79]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[80]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Economist_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Economist-83">[81]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Businessweek_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Businessweek-84">[82]</a></sup> These devaluations have done little to improve the situation of the Venezuelan people who rely on imported products or locally produced products that depend on imported inputs while dollar-denominated oil sales account for the vast majority of Venezuela's exports.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[83]</a></sup> According to Sebastian Boyd writing at <a href="/wiki/Bloomberg_News" title="Bloomberg News">Bloomberg News</a>, the profits of the oil industry have been lost to "social engineering" and corruption, instead of investments needed to maintain oil production.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[84]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Chávez survived several further political tests, including an <a href="/wiki/2004_Venezuelan_recall_referendum" title="2004 Venezuelan recall referendum">August 2004 recall referendum</a>. He was elected for another term <a href="/wiki/2006_Venezuelan_presidential_election" title="2006 Venezuelan presidential election">in December 2006</a> and re-elected for a third term in October 2012. However, he was never sworn in for his third period, due to medical complications. Chávez died on 5 March 2013 after a nearly two-year fight with cancer.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[85]</a></sup> The presidential election that took place on Sunday, 14 April 2013, was the first since Chávez took office in 1999 in which his name did not appear on the ballot.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[86]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h4><span id="Nicol.C3.A1s_Maduro:_2013.E2.80.93present"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Nicolás_Maduro:_2013–present">Nicolás Maduro: 2013–present</span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_Nicol%C3%A1s_Maduro" title="Presidency of Nicolás Maduro">Presidency of Nicolás Maduro</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Crisis_in_Venezuela" title="Crisis in Venezuela">Crisis in Venezuela</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Dilma_Rousseff_and_Nicol%C3%A1s_Maduro_at_48th_Mercosur_Summit_(2).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Dilma_Rousseff_and_Nicol%C3%A1s_Maduro_at_48th_Mercosur_Summit_%282%29.jpg/220px-Dilma_Rousseff_and_Nicol%C3%A1s_Maduro_at_48th_Mercosur_Summit_%282%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="160" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Dilma_Rousseff_and_Nicol%C3%A1s_Maduro_at_48th_Mercosur_Summit_%282%29.jpg/330px-Dilma_Rousseff_and_Nicol%C3%A1s_Maduro_at_48th_Mercosur_Summit_%282%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Dilma_Rousseff_and_Nicol%C3%A1s_Maduro_at_48th_Mercosur_Summit_%282%29.jpg/440px-Dilma_Rousseff_and_Nicol%C3%A1s_Maduro_at_48th_Mercosur_Summit_%282%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3518" data-file-height="2558"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Dilma_Rousseff_and_Nicol%C3%A1s_Maduro_at_48th_Mercosur_Summit_(2).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
