         </div><a href="/wiki/Nicol%C3%A1s_Maduro" title="Nicolás Maduro">Nicolás Maduro</a> with Brazilian President <a href="/wiki/Dilma_Rousseff" title="Dilma Rousseff">Dilma Rousseff</a> at the 48th <a href="/wiki/Mercosur" title="Mercosur">Mercosur</a> Summit in Brazil in 2015.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Poverty and inflation began to increase into the 2010s.<sup id="cite_ref-UN_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UN-89">[87]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Nicol%C3%A1s_Maduro" title="Nicolás Maduro">Nicolás Maduro</a> was elected in 2013 after the death of Chavez. Chavez picked Maduro as his successor and appointed him vice president in 2013. Maduro was elected president in a shortened election in 2013 following Chavez's death.<sup id="cite_ref-Economist_83-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Economist-83">[81]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[88]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[89]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Nicolás Maduro has been the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Venezuela" title="President of Venezuela">president of Venezuela</a> since 14 April 2013, when he won the <a href="/wiki/2013_Venezuelan_presidential_election" title="2013 Venezuelan presidential election">second presidential election after Chávez's death</a>, with 50.61% of the votes against the opposition's candidate <a href="/wiki/Henrique_Capriles_Radonski" class="mw-redirect" title="Henrique Capriles Radonski">Henrique Capriles Radonski</a>, who had 49.12% of the votes. The <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Unity_Roundtable" title="Democratic Unity Roundtable">Democratic Unity Roundtable</a> contested his election as fraud and as a violation of the constitution. An audit of 56% of the vote showed no discrepancies,<sup id="cite_ref-BBC12June_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC12June-92">[90]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Venezuela" class="mw-redirect" title="Supreme Court of Venezuela">Supreme Court of Venezuela</a> ruled that under Venezuela's Constitution, Nicolás Maduro was the legitimate president and was invested as such by the Venezuelan <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_(Venezuela)" title="National Assembly (Venezuela)">National Assembly</a> (Asamblea Nacional).<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[91]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[92]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[93]</a></sup> Opposition leaders and some international media consider the government of Maduro to be a dictatorship.<sup id="cite_ref-reuters-maduro_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-reuters-maduro-96">[94]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-hrw-maduro_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hrw-maduro-97">[95]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-wpo-maduro_98-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wpo-maduro-98">[96]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-nyt-maduro_99-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nyt-maduro-99">[97]</a></sup> Since February 2014, hundreds of thousands of Venezuelans have protested over high levels of criminal violence, corruption, hyperinflation, and chronic scarcity of basic goods due to policies of the federal government.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[98]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[99]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[100]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[101]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[102]</a></sup> Demonstrations and riots have resulted in over 40 fatalities in the unrest between Chavistas and opposition protesters<sup id="cite_ref-2014protests_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2014protests-105">[103]</a></sup> and opposition leaders, including <a href="/wiki/Leopoldo_L%C3%B3pez" title="Leopoldo López">Leopoldo López</a> and <a href="/wiki/Antonio_Ledezma" title="Antonio Ledezma">Antonio Ledezma</a> were arrested.<sup id="cite_ref-2014protests_105-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2014protests-105">[103]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[104]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-INDEPENDENT_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-INDEPENDENT-107">[105]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[106]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[107]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[108]</a></sup> Human rights groups condemned the arrest of Leopoldo López.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[109]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/2015_Venezuelan_parliamentary_election" title="2015 Venezuelan parliamentary election">2015 Venezuelan parliamentary election</a>, the opposition gained a majority.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[110]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Venezuela devalued its currency in February 2013 due to rising shortages in the country,<sup id="cite_ref-Businessweek_84-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Businessweek-84">[82]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[111]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Shortages_in_Venezuela" title="Shortages in Venezuela">which included those of</a> milk, flour, and other necessities. This led to an increase in malnutrition, especially among children.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[112]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ECONeatCHAVISMO_115-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ECONeatCHAVISMO-115">[113]</a></sup> Venezuela's economy had become strongly dependent on the exportation of oil, with crude accounting for 86% of exports,<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[114]</a></sup> and a high price per barrel to support social programs. Beginning in 2014 the <a href="/wiki/Price_of_oil" title="Price of oil">price of oil</a> plummeted from over $100/bbl to $40/bbl a year and a half later. This placed pressure on the Venezuelan economy, which was no longer able to afford vast social programs. To counter the decrease in oil prices, the Venezuelan Government began taking more money from <a href="/wiki/Petr%C3%B3leos_de_Venezuela,_S.A." class="mw-redirect" title="Petróleos de Venezuela, S.A.">PDVSA</a>, the state oil company, to meet budgets, resulting in a lack of reinvestment in fields and employees. Venezuela's oil production decreased from its height of nearly 3 to 1&nbsp;million <a href="/wiki/Barrel_(unit)#Oil_barrel" title="Barrel (unit)">barrels</a> (480 to 160&nbsp;thousand <a href="/wiki/Cubic_metre" title="Cubic metre">cubic metres</a>) per day.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[115]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[116]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[117]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[118]</a></sup> In 2014, Venezuela entered an <a href="/wiki/Economic_recession" class="mw-redirect" title="Economic recession">economic recession</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[119]</a></sup> In 2015, Venezuela had the world's highest inflation rate with the rate surpassing 100%, which was the highest in the country's history.<sup id="cite_ref-FPblackbox_122-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FPblackbox-122">[120]</a></sup> In 2017, <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a>'s administration imposed more <a href="/wiki/Economic_sanctions" title="Economic sanctions">economic sanctions</a> against Venezuela's state-owned oil company <a href="/wiki/PDVSA" title="PDVSA">PDVSA</a> and Venezuelan officials.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[121]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[122]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[123]</a></sup> Economic problems, as well as crime and corruption, were some of the main causes of the <a href="/wiki/Venezuelan_protests_(2014%E2%80%93present)" title="Venezuelan protests (2014–present)">2014–present Venezuelan protests</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[124]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[125]</a></sup> Since 2015 nearly 2 million people have <a href="/wiki/Bolivarian_diaspora" class="mw-redirect" title="Bolivarian diaspora">fled Venezuela</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[126]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In January 2016, President Maduro decreed an "economic emergency", revealing the extent of the crisis and expanding his powers.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[127]</a></sup> In July 2016, Colombian border crossings were temporarily opened to allow Venezuelans to purchase food and basic household and health items in Colombia.<sup id="cite_ref-Venezuelans_Cross_Into_Colombia_In_Search_Of_Food_130-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Venezuelans_Cross_Into_Colombia_In_Search_Of_Food-130">[128]</a></sup> In September 2016, a study published in the Spanish-language <i><a href="/wiki/Diario_Las_Am%C3%A9ricas" title="Diario Las Américas">Diario Las Américas</a></i><sup id="cite_ref-Hambre_en_Venezuela:_El_15.7%_de_los_venezolanos_se_ha_alimentado_de_residuos_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hambre_en_Venezuela:_El_15.7%_de_los_venezolanos_se_ha_alimentado_de_residuos-131">[129]</a></sup> indicated that 15% of Venezuelans are eating "<a href="/wiki/Food_waste" class="mw-redirect" title="Food waste">food waste</a> discarded by commercial establishments". </p>
      <p>Close to 200 riots had occurred in Venezuelan prisons by October 2016, according to Una Ventana a la Libertad, an advocacy group for better prison conditions. The father of an inmate at Táchira Detention Center in Caracas alleged that his son was cannibalized by other inmates during a month-long riot, a claim corroborated by an anonymous police source but denied by the Minister of Correctional Affairs.<sup id="cite_ref-Man_claims_son_was_eaten_by_fellow_inmates_during_riot_in_Venezuelan_prison_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Man_claims_son_was_eaten_by_fellow_inmates_during_riot_in_Venezuelan_prison-132">[130]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:The_TSJ_chamber_at_Maduro_2019_inauguration.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/The_TSJ_chamber_at_Maduro_2019_inauguration.jpg/220px-The_TSJ_chamber_at_Maduro_2019_inauguration.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/The_TSJ_chamber_at_Maduro_2019_inauguration.jpg/330px-The_TSJ_chamber_at_Maduro_2019_inauguration.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/The_TSJ_chamber_at_Maduro_2019_inauguration.jpg/440px-The_TSJ_chamber_at_Maduro_2019_inauguration.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2953" data-file-height="1969"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:The_TSJ_chamber_at_Maduro_2019_inauguration.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Maduro was <a href="/wiki/Second_inauguration_of_Nicol%C3%A1s_Maduro" title="Second inauguration of Nicolás Maduro">inaugurated</a> for a <a href="/wiki/2019_Venezuelan_presidential_crisis" class="mw-redirect" title="2019 Venezuelan presidential crisis">contested</a> and controversial second term on 10 January 2019.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 2017, Venezuela experienced <a href="/wiki/2017_Venezuelan_constitutional_crisis" title="2017 Venezuelan constitutional crisis">a constitutional crisis in the country</a>. In March 2017, opposition leaders branded President Nicolas Maduro a dictator after the Maduro-aligned Supreme Tribunal, which had been overturning most National Assembly decisions since the opposition took control of the body, took over the functions of the assembly, pushing a lengthy political standoff to new heights.<sup id="cite_ref-reuters-maduro_96-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-reuters-maduro-96">[94]</a></sup> The Supreme Court backed down and reversed its decision on 1 April 2017.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> A month later, President Maduro announced the <a href="/wiki/2017_Venezuelan_Constituent_Assembly_election" title="2017 Venezuelan Constituent Assembly election">2017 Venezuelan Constituent Assembly election</a> and on 30 August 2017, the <a href="/wiki/2017_Constituent_National_Assembly" title="2017 Constituent National Assembly">2017 Constituent National Assembly</a> was elected into office and quickly stripped the National Assembly of its powers.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (March 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>In December 2017, President Maduro declared that leading opposition parties would be barred from taking part in following year's presidential vote after they boycotted mayoral polls.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[131]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Maduro won the <a href="/wiki/2018_Venezuelan_presidential_election" title="2018 Venezuelan presidential election">2018 election</a> with 67.8% of the vote. The result was challenged by countries including <a href="/wiki/Argentina" title="Argentina">Argentina</a>, Chile, <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a>, Brazil, Canada, Germany, France and the United States who deemed it fraudulent and moved to recognize <a href="/wiki/Juan_Guaid%C3%B3" title="Juan Guaidó">Juan Guaidó</a> as president.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[132]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[133]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[134]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[135]</a></sup> Other countries including <a href="/wiki/Cuba" title="Cuba">Cuba</a>, China, Russia, <a href="/wiki/Turkey" title="Turkey">Turkey</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Iran" title="Iran">Iran</a> continued to recognize Maduro as president,<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[136]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[137]</a></sup> although China, facing financial pressure over its position, reportedly began hedging its position by decreasing loans given, cancelling joint ventures, and signaling willingness to work with all parties.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[138]</a></sup> A Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokeswoman denied the reports, describing them as "false information".<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[139]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In January 2019 the Permanent Council of the <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_American_States" title="Organization of American States">Organization of American States</a> (OAS) approved a resolution "to not recognize the legitimacy of Nicolas Maduro's new term as of the 10th of January of 2019,"<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[140]</a></sup> while the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly" title="United Nations General Assembly">United Nations General Assembly</a> formally recognized the Maduro government as the only legitimate representative of Venezuela at the United Nations<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[141]</a></sup> and in October 2019, Venezuela was elected to the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Human_Rights_Council" title="United Nations Human Rights Council">United Nations Human Rights Council</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[142]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In August 2019, United States President Donald Trump signed an executive order to impose a total economic embargo against Venezuela.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[143]</a></sup> In March 2020, the Trump administration indicted Maduro and several Venezuelan officials on charges of drug trafficking.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[144]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research#Primary,_secondary_and_tertiary_sources" title="Wikipedia:No original research"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable secondary sources. (March 2021)">non-primary source needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>In June 2020, a report by the US organisation <a href="/wiki/Robert_F._Kennedy_Human_Rights" title="Robert F. Kennedy Human Rights">Robert F. Kennedy Human Rights</a> documented enforced disappearances in Venezuela that occurred in the years 2018 and 2019. During the period, 724 enforced disappearances of <a href="/wiki/Political_prisoner" title="Political prisoner">political detainees</a> were reported. The report stated that Venezuelan security forces subjected victims, who had been disappeared, to illegal interrogation processes accompanied by torture and cruel or inhuman treatment. The report stated that the Venezuelan government strategically used enforced disappearances to silence political opponents and other critical voices it deemed a threat.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[145]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[146]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Venezuela" title="Geography of Venezuela">Geography of Venezuela</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Venezuela_Topography.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Venezuela_Topography.png/300px-Venezuela_Topography.png" decoding="async" width="300" height="258" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Venezuela_Topography.png/450px-Venezuela_Topography.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/Venezuela_Topography.png/600px-Venezuela_Topography.png 2x" data-file-width="2101" data-file-height="1809"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Venezuela_Topography.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Topographic map of Venezuela
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Venezuela is located in the north of South America; geologically, its mainland rests on the <a href="/wiki/South_American_Plate" title="South American Plate">South American Plate</a>. It has a total area of 916,445&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (353,841&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi) and a land area of 882,050&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (340,560&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi), making Venezuela the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_outlying_territories_by_total_area" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries and outlying territories by total area">33rd largest country in the world</a>. The territory it controls lies between latitudes <a href="/wiki/Equator" title="Equator">0°</a> and <a href="/wiki/13th_parallel_north" title="13th parallel north">13°N</a> and longitudes <a href="/wiki/59th_meridian_west" title="59th meridian west">59°</a> and <a href="/wiki/74th_meridian_west" title="74th meridian west">74°W</a>. </p>
      <p>Shaped roughly like a triangle, the country has a 2,800&nbsp;km (1,700&nbsp;mi) coastline in the north, which includes numerous islands in the Caribbean and the northeast borders the northern Atlantic Ocean. Most observers describe Venezuela in terms of four fairly well defined <a href="/wiki/Topography" title="Topography">topographical</a> regions: the <a href="/wiki/Maracaibo_Basin" title="Maracaibo Basin">Maracaibo lowlands</a> in the northwest, the northern mountains extending in a broad east–west arc from the Colombian border along the northern Caribbean coast, the wide plains in central Venezuela, and the <a href="/wiki/Guiana_Highlands" class="mw-redirect" title="Guiana Highlands">Guiana Highlands</a> in the southeast. </p>
      <p>The northern mountains are the extreme northeastern extensions of South America's Andes mountain range. <a href="/wiki/Pico_Bol%C3%ADvar" title="Pico Bolívar">Pico Bolívar</a>, the nation's highest point at 4,979&nbsp;m (16,335&nbsp;ft), lies in this region. To the south, the dissected <a href="/wiki/Guayana_Region" class="mw-redirect" title="Guayana Region">Guiana Highlands</a> contain the northern fringes of the Amazon Basin and <a href="/wiki/Angel_Falls" title="Angel Falls">Angel Falls</a>, the world's highest waterfall, as well as <i><a href="/wiki/Tepui" title="Tepui">tepuis</a></i>, large table-like mountains. The country's center is characterized by the <i>llanos</i>, which are extensive plains that stretch from the Colombian border in the far west to the Orinoco River <a href="/wiki/River_delta" title="River delta">delta</a> in the east. The Orinoco, with its rich <a href="/wiki/Alluvium" title="Alluvium">alluvial soils</a>, binds the largest and most important <a href="/wiki/Drainage_system_(geomorphology)" title="Drainage system (geomorphology)">river system</a> of the country; it originates in one of the largest <a href="/wiki/Drainage_basin" title="Drainage basin">watersheds</a> in Latin America. The <a href="/wiki/Caron%C3%AD_River_(Venezuela)" class="mw-redirect" title="Caroní River (Venezuela)">Caroní</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Apure_River" title="Apure River">Apure</a> are other major rivers. </p>
      <p>Venezuela borders <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a> to the west, <a href="/wiki/Guyana" title="Guyana">Guyana</a> to the east, and <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a> to the south. Caribbean islands such as <a href="/wiki/Trinidad_and_Tobago" title="Trinidad and Tobago">Trinidad and Tobago</a>, <a href="/wiki/Grenada" title="Grenada">Grenada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cura%C3%A7ao" title="Curaçao">Curaçao</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aruba" title="Aruba">Aruba</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Leeward_Antilles" title="Leeward Antilles">Leeward Antilles</a> lie near the Venezuelan coast. Venezuela has territorial disputes with Guyana, formerly United Kingdom, largely concerning the <a href="/wiki/Guayana_Esequiba" title="Guayana Esequiba">Essequibo area</a> and with Colombia concerning the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Venezuela" title="Gulf of Venezuela">Gulf of Venezuela</a>. In 1895, after years of diplomatic attempts to solve the border dispute, the dispute over the Essequibo River border flared up. It was submitted to a "neutral" commission (composed of British, American, and Russian representatives and without a direct Venezuelan representative), which in 1899 decided mostly against Venezuela's claim.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[147]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Venezuela's most significant natural resources are petroleum and natural gas, iron ore, gold, and other minerals. It also has large areas of <a href="/wiki/Arable_land" title="Arable land">arable land</a> and water. </p> 
      <div class="center">
       <div class="thumb tnone">
        <div class="thumbinner" style="width:662px;">
         <a href="/wiki/File:Kukenan_Roraima_GS.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Kukenan_Roraima_GS.jpg/660px-Kukenan_Roraima_GS.jpg" decoding="async" width="660" height="209" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Kukenan_Roraima_GS.jpg/990px-Kukenan_Roraima_GS.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/Kukenan_Roraima_GS.jpg/1320px-Kukenan_Roraima_GS.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4851" data-file-height="1533"></a> 
         <div class="thumbcaption">
          <div class="magnify">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Kukenan_Roraima_GS.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="center" style="width:auto; margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto;">
           View of the tepuis, <a href="/wiki/Kuken%C3%A1n-tepui" title="Kukenán-tepui">Kukenan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mount_Roraima" title="Mount Roraima">Roraima</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/Gran_Sabana" title="Gran Sabana">Gran Sabana</a>. <a href="/wiki/Canaima_National_Park" title="Canaima National Park">Canaima National Park</a>. Tepuis are among the attractions of the park, these mountains are among the oldest exposed formations on the planet.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[148]</a></sup>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Venezuela" title="Climate of Venezuela">Climate of Venezuela</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Venezuela_K%C3%B6ppen.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Venezuela_K%C3%B6ppen.png/220px-Venezuela_K%C3%B6ppen.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="179" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Venezuela_K%C3%B6ppen.png/330px-Venezuela_K%C3%B6ppen.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Venezuela_K%C3%B6ppen.png/440px-Venezuela_K%C3%B6ppen.png 2x" data-file-width="4782" data-file-height="3891"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Venezuela_K%C3%B6ppen.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Venezuela map of Köppen climate classification
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Venezuela is entirely located in the tropics over the Equator to around 12° N. Its climate varies from humid low-elevation plains, where average annual temperatures range as high as 35&nbsp;°C (95.0&nbsp;°F), to glaciers and highlands (the <i><a href="/wiki/P%C3%A1ramo" title="Páramo">páramos</a></i>) with an average yearly temperature of 8&nbsp;°C (46.4&nbsp;°F). Annual rainfall varies from 430&nbsp;mm (16.9&nbsp;in) in the semiarid portions of the northwest to over 1,000&nbsp;mm (39.4&nbsp;in) in the Orinoco Delta of the far east and the Amazonian Jungle in the south. The precipitation level is lower in the period from August through April. These periods are referred to as hot-humid and cold-dry seasons. Another characteristic of the climate is this variation throughout the country by the existence of a mountain range called "Cordillera de la Costa" which crosses the country from east to west. The majority of the population lives in these mountains.<sup id="cite_ref-LOC_2005_151-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LOC_2005-151">[149]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:ClimateZones_Venezuela.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/ClimateZones_Venezuela.png/220px-ClimateZones_Venezuela.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="183" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/ClimateZones_Venezuela.png/330px-ClimateZones_Venezuela.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/ClimateZones_Venezuela.png/440px-ClimateZones_Venezuela.png 2x" data-file-width="5266" data-file-height="4377"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:ClimateZones_Venezuela.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Venezuelan climatic types, according to their thermal floors
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The country falls into four horizontal temperature zones based primarily on elevation, having tropical, dry, temperate with dry winters, and polar (<a href="/wiki/Alpine_tundra" title="Alpine tundra">alpine tundra</a>) climates, amongst others.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWarhol200665_152-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWarhol200665-152">[150]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Geografía_–_Clima_153-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Geografía_–_Clima-153">[151]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[152]</a></sup> In the tropical zone—below 800&nbsp;m (2,625&nbsp;ft)—temperatures are hot, with yearly averages ranging between 26 and 28&nbsp;°C (78.8 and 82.4&nbsp;°F). The temperate zone ranges between 800 and 2,000&nbsp;m (2,625 and 6,562&nbsp;ft) with averages from 12 to 25&nbsp;°C (53.6 to 77.0&nbsp;°F); many of Venezuela's cities, including the capital, lie in this region. Colder conditions with temperatures from 9 to 11&nbsp;°C (48.2 to 51.8&nbsp;°F) are found in the cool zone between 2,000 and 3,000&nbsp;m (6,562 and 9,843&nbsp;ft), especially in the Venezuelan Andes, where pastureland and permanent snowfield with yearly averages below 8&nbsp;°C (46&nbsp;°F) cover land above 3,000 meters (9,843&nbsp;ft) in the <i>páramos</i>. </p>
      <p>The highest temperature recorded was 42&nbsp;°C (108&nbsp;°F) in <a href="/wiki/Machiques" title="Machiques">Machiques</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[153]</a></sup> and the lowest temperature recorded was −11&nbsp;°C (12&nbsp;°F), it has been reported from an uninhabited high altitude at <a href="/wiki/Pico_Piedras_Blancas" title="Pico Piedras Blancas">Páramo de Piedras Blancas</a> (<a href="/wiki/M%C3%A9rida_state" class="mw-redirect" title="Mérida state">Mérida state</a>),<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[154]</a></sup> even though no official reports exist, lower temperatures in the mountains of the Sierra Nevada de Mérida are known. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Natural_regions_of_Venezuela" title="Natural regions of Venezuela">Natural regions of Venezuela</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fauna_of_Venezuela" title="Fauna of Venezuela">Fauna of Venezuela</a>, <a href="/wiki/Flora_of_Venezuela" title="Flora of Venezuela">Flora of Venezuela</a>, <a href="/wiki/National_symbols_of_Venezuela" title="National symbols of Venezuela">National symbols of Venezuela</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_birds_of_Venezuela" title="List of birds of Venezuela">List of birds of Venezuela</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Mapa_de_regiones_naturales_(Venezuela).png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Mapa_de_regiones_naturales_%28Venezuela%29.png/220px-Mapa_de_regiones_naturales_%28Venezuela%29.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="170" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Mapa_de_regiones_naturales_%28Venezuela%29.png/330px-Mapa_de_regiones_naturales_%28Venezuela%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Mapa_de_regiones_naturales_%28Venezuela%29.png/440px-Mapa_de_regiones_naturales_%28Venezuela%29.png 2x" data-file-width="4400" data-file-height="3400"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Mapa_de_regiones_naturales_(Venezuela).png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Map of <a href="/wiki/Natural_regions_of_Venezuela" title="Natural regions of Venezuela">Natural regions of Venezuela</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:El_Magn%C3%ADfico_Salto_%C3%81ngel.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/El_Magn%C3%ADfico_Salto_%C3%81ngel.jpg/220px-El_Magn%C3%ADfico_Salto_%C3%81ngel.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="293" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/El_Magn%C3%ADfico_Salto_%C3%81ngel.jpg/330px-El_Magn%C3%ADfico_Salto_%C3%81ngel.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/El_Magn%C3%ADfico_Salto_%C3%81ngel.jpg/440px-El_Magn%C3%ADfico_Salto_%C3%81ngel.jpg 2x" data-file-width="612" data-file-height="816"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:El_Magn%C3%ADfico_Salto_%C3%81ngel.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Angel_Falls" title="Angel Falls">Ángel Falls</a>, the world's highest uninterrupted waterfall, in <a href="/wiki/Canaima_National_Park" title="Canaima National Park">Canaima National Park</a>, Bolívar state
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Venezuela lies within the <a href="/wiki/Neotropical_realm" title="Neotropical realm">Neotropical realm</a>; large portions of the country were originally covered by <a href="/wiki/Tropical_and_subtropical_moist_broadleaf_forests" title="Tropical and subtropical moist broadleaf forests">moist broadleaf forests</a>. One of 17 <a href="/wiki/Megadiverse_countries" title="Megadiverse countries">megadiverse countries</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[155]</a></sup> Venezuela's <a href="/wiki/Habitat" title="Habitat">habitats</a> range from the Andes Mountains in the west to the Amazon Basin rainforest in the south, via extensive <i>llanos</i> plains and Caribbean coast in the center and the Orinoco River Delta in the east. They include <a href="/wiki/Deserts_and_xeric_shrublands" title="Deserts and xeric shrublands">xeric scrublands</a> in the extreme northwest and coastal <a href="/wiki/Mangrove" title="Mangrove">mangrove</a> forests in the northeast.<sup id="cite_ref-LOC_2005_151-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LOC_2005-151">[149]</a></sup> Its <a href="/wiki/Cloud_forest" title="Cloud forest">cloud forests</a> and lowland <a href="/wiki/Rainforest" title="Rainforest">rainforests</a> are particularly rich.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDydynskiBeech200442_158-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDydynskiBeech200442-158">[156]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Fauna_of_Venezuela" title="Fauna of Venezuela">Animals</a> of Venezuela are diverse and include <a href="/wiki/Manatee" title="Manatee">manatees</a>, <a href="/wiki/Three-toed_sloth" title="Three-toed sloth">three-toed sloth</a>, <a href="/wiki/Two-toed_sloth" title="Two-toed sloth">two-toed sloth</a>, <a href="/wiki/Amazon_river_dolphin" title="Amazon river dolphin">Amazon river dolphins</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Orinoco_Crocodile" class="mw-redirect" title="Orinoco Crocodile">Orinoco Crocodiles</a>, which have been reported to reach up to 6.6&nbsp;m (22&nbsp;ft) in length. Venezuela hosts a total of 1,417 bird species, 48 of which are endemic.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[157]</a></sup> Important birds include <a href="/wiki/Ibis" title="Ibis">ibises</a>, <a href="/wiki/Osprey" title="Osprey">ospreys</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kingfisher" title="Kingfisher">kingfishers</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDydynskiBeech200442_158-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDydynskiBeech200442-158">[156]</a></sup> and the yellow-orange <a href="/wiki/Venezuelan_troupial" title="Venezuelan troupial">Venezuelan troupial</a>, the national bird. Notable <a href="/wiki/Mammal" title="Mammal">mammals</a> include the <a href="/wiki/Giant_anteater" title="Giant anteater">giant anteater</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jaguar" title="Jaguar">jaguar</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Capybara" title="Capybara">capybara</a>, the world's largest <a href="/wiki/Rodent" title="Rodent">rodent</a>. More than half of Venezuelan avian and mammalian species are found in the <a href="/wiki/Amazon_Rainforest" class="mw-redirect" title="Amazon Rainforest">Amazonian forests</a> south of the Orinoco.<sup id="cite_ref-Bevilacqua_2002_160-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bevilacqua_2002-160">[158]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>For the fungi, an account was provided by R.W.G. Dennis<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[159]</a></sup> which has been digitized and the records made available on-line as part of the Cybertruffle Robigalia database.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[160]</a></sup> That database includes nearly 3,900 species of fungi recorded from Venezuela, but is far from complete, and the true total number of fungal species already known from Venezuela is likely higher, given the generally accepted estimate that only about 7% of all fungi worldwide have so far been discovered.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE''Georgia_Country_Study_Guide_Volume_1_Strategic_Information_and_Developments''201336_163-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE''Georgia_Country_Study_Guide_Volume_1_Strategic_Information_and_Developments''201336-163">[161]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Among plants of Venezuela, over 25,000 species of <a href="/wiki/Orchidaceae" title="Orchidaceae">orchids</a> are found in the country's cloud forest and lowland rainforest ecosystems.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDydynskiBeech200442_158-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDydynskiBeech200442-158">[156]</a></sup> These include the <i>flor de mayo</i> orchid (<i><a href="/wiki/Cattleya_mossiae" title="Cattleya mossiae">Cattleya mossiae</a></i>), the national flower. Venezuela's national tree is the <a href="/wiki/Tabebuia_chrysantha" class="mw-redirect" title="Tabebuia chrysantha">araguaney</a>, whose characteristic lushness after the rainy season led novelist <a href="/wiki/R%C3%B3mulo_Gallegos" title="Rómulo Gallegos">Rómulo Gallegos</a> to name it "<i>[l]a primavera de oro de los araguaneyes</i>" (the golden spring of the araguaneyes). The tops of the tepuis are also home to several carnivorous plants including the marsh pitcher plant, <a href="/wiki/Heliamphora" title="Heliamphora">Heliamphora</a>, and the insectivorous bromeliad, <a href="/wiki/Brocchinia_reducta" title="Brocchinia reducta">Brocchinia reducta</a>. </p>
      <p>Venezuela is among the top 20 countries in terms of <a href="/wiki/Endemism" title="Endemism">endemism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-GFW_164-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GFW-164">[162]</a></sup> Among its animals, 23% of <a href="/wiki/Reptile" title="Reptile">reptilian</a> and 50% of <a href="/wiki/Amphibian" title="Amphibian">amphibian</a> species are endemic.<sup id="cite_ref-GFW_164-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GFW-164">[162]</a></sup> Although the available information is still very small, a first effort has been made to estimate the number of fungal species endemic to Venezuela: 1334 species of fungi have been tentatively identified as possible endemics of the country.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[163]</a></sup> Some 38% of the over 21,000 plant species known from Venezuela are unique to the country.<sup id="cite_ref-GFW_164-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GFW-164">[162]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Environment">Environment</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_Venezuela" title="Environmental issues in Venezuela">Environmental issues in Venezuela</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:392px;max-width:392px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:194px;max-width:194px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:117px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Venezuela_-_Vista_desde_Acop%C3%A1n_tepui.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Venezuela_-_Vista_desde_Acop%C3%A1n_tepui.jpg/192px-Venezuela_-_Vista_desde_Acop%C3%A1n_tepui.jpg" decoding="async" width="192" height="117" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Venezuela_-_Vista_desde_Acop%C3%A1n_tepui.jpg/288px-Venezuela_-_Vista_desde_Acop%C3%A1n_tepui.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Venezuela_-_Vista_desde_Acop%C3%A1n_tepui.jpg/384px-Venezuela_-_Vista_desde_Acop%C3%A1n_tepui.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4177" data-file-height="2552"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:194px;max-width:194px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:117px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Curiara_al_Meru.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Curiara_al_Meru.jpg/192px-Curiara_al_Meru.jpg" decoding="async" width="192" height="118" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Curiara_al_Meru.jpg/288px-Curiara_al_Meru.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Curiara_al_Meru.jpg/384px-Curiara_al_Meru.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4928" data-file-height="3021"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:205px;max-width:205px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:135px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Tepuy_Yuruan%C3%AD_(20561438491).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Tepuy_Yuruan%C3%AD_%2820561438491%29.jpg/203px-Tepuy_Yuruan%C3%AD_%2820561438491%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="203" height="135" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Tepuy_Yuruan%C3%AD_%2820561438491%29.jpg/305px-Tepuy_Yuruan%C3%AD_%2820561438491%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Tepuy_Yuruan%C3%AD_%2820561438491%29.jpg/406px-Tepuy_Yuruan%C3%AD_%2820561438491%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5157" data-file-height="3438"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:183px;max-width:183px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:135px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Los_jacuzzis_m%C3%A1gicos.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Los_jacuzzis_m%C3%A1gicos.jpg/181px-Los_jacuzzis_m%C3%A1gicos.jpg" decoding="async" width="181" height="136" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Los_jacuzzis_m%C3%A1gicos.jpg/272px-Los_jacuzzis_m%C3%A1gicos.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Los_jacuzzis_m%C3%A1gicos.jpg/362px-Los_jacuzzis_m%C3%A1gicos.jpg 2x" data-file-width="960" data-file-height="720"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow" style="display:flex">
         <div class="thumbcaption">
          <a href="/wiki/Tepui" title="Tepui">Tepui</a> shrublands is an ecosystem that is considered almost endemic to Venezuela and currently classified <b><a href="/wiki/Least_Concern_(IUCN_Red_List_of_Ecosystems)" class="mw-redirect" title="Least Concern (IUCN Red List of Ecosystems)">Least Concern</a> (LC)</b> according to the <a href="/wiki/IUCN_Red_List_of_Ecosystems" title="IUCN Red List of Ecosystems">IUCN Red List of Ecosystems</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Foundations_166-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Foundations-166">[164]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[165]</a></sup>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Venezuela is one of the 10 most biodiverse countries on the planet, yet it is one of the leaders of deforestation due to economic and political factors. Each year, roughly 287,600 hectares of forest are permanently destroyed and other areas are degraded by mining, oil extraction, and logging. Between 1990 and 2005, Venezuela officially lost 8.3% of its forest cover, which is about 4.3&nbsp;million ha. In response, federal protections for critical habitat were implemented; for example, 20% to 33% of forested land is protected.<sup id="cite_ref-Bevilacqua_2002_160-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bevilacqua_2002-160">[158]</a></sup> Venezuela had a 2019 <a href="/wiki/Forest_Landscape_Integrity_Index" title="Forest Landscape Integrity Index">Forest Landscape Integrity Index</a> mean score of 8.78/10, ranking it 19th globally out of 172 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[166]</a></sup> The country's <a href="/wiki/Biosphere_reserve" class="mw-redirect" title="Biosphere reserve">biosphere reserve</a> is part of the <a href="/wiki/World_Network_of_Biosphere_Reserves" title="World Network of Biosphere Reserves">World Network of Biosphere Reserves</a>; five <a href="/wiki/Wetlands" class="mw-redirect" title="Wetlands">wetlands</a> are registered under the <a href="/wiki/Ramsar_Convention" title="Ramsar Convention">Ramsar Convention</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[167]</a></sup> In 2003, 70% of the nation's land was under conservation management in over 200 protected areas, including 43 national parks.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[168]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_parks_of_Venezuela" title="List of national parks of Venezuela">Venezuela's 43 national parks</a> include Canaima National Park, <a href="/wiki/Morrocoy_National_Park" title="Morrocoy National Park">Morrocoy National Park</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mochima_National_Park" title="Mochima National Park">Mochima National Park</a>. In the far south is a reserve for the country's Yanomami tribes. Covering 32,000 square miles (82,880 square kilometres), the area is off-limits to farmers, miners, and all non-Yanomami settlers. </p>
      <p>Venezuela was one of the few countries that did not enter an <a href="/wiki/Intended_Nationally_Determined_Contributions" class="mw-redirect" title="Intended Nationally Determined Contributions">INDC</a> at <a href="/wiki/COP21" class="mw-redirect" title="COP21">COP21</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[169]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[170]</a></sup> Many terrestrial ecosystems are considered <a href="/wiki/IUCN_Red_List_of_Ecosystems#Risk_Categories" title="IUCN Red List of Ecosystems">endangered</a>, specially the <a href="/wiki/Dry_forest" class="mw-redirect" title="Dry forest">dry forest</a> in the northern regions of the country and the <a href="/wiki/Coral_reef" title="Coral reef">coral reefs</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean" title="Caribbean">Caribbean</a> coast.<sup id="cite_ref-Foundations_166-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Foundations-166">[164]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[171]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[172]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Hydrography">Hydrography</span></h3> 
      <p>The country is made up of three river basins: the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean_Sea" title="Caribbean Sea">Caribbean Sea</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a> and Lake Valencia, which forms an endorheic basin.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[173]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On the Atlantic side it drains most of Venezuela's river waters. The largest basin in this area is the extensive Orinoco basin<sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[174]</a></sup> whose surface area, close to one million km<sup>2</sup>, is greater than that of the whole of Venezuela, although it has a presence of 65% in the country. The size of this basin - similar to that of the Danube - makes it the third largest in <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South America</a>, and it gives rise to a flow of some 33,000 m³/s, making the Orinoco the third largest in the world, and also one of the most valuable from the point of view of renewable natural resources. The Rio or Brazo Casiquiare is unique in the world, as it is a natural derivation of the <a href="/wiki/Orinoco_river" class="mw-redirect" title="Orinoco river">Orinoco</a> that, after some 500&nbsp;km in length, connects it to the Negro River, which in turn is a tributary of the <a href="/wiki/Amazon_River" title="Amazon River">Amazon</a>. The Orinoco receives directly or indirectly rivers such as the Ventuari, the Caura, the <a href="/wiki/Caron%C3%AD_River" title="Caroní River">Caroní</a>, the Meta, the <a href="/wiki/Arauca_River" title="Arauca River">Arauca</a>, the Apure and many others. Other Venezuelan rivers that empty into the Atlantic are the waters of the San Juan and Cuyuní basins. Finally, there is the Amazon River, which receives the Guainía, the Negro and others. Other basins are the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Paria" title="Gulf of Paria">Gulf of Paria</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Essequibo_River" title="Essequibo River">Esequibo River</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Cerro_Wahari-Amazonas.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Cerro_Wahari-Amazonas.jpg/220px-Cerro_Wahari-Amazonas.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Cerro_Wahari-Amazonas.jpg/330px-Cerro_Wahari-Amazonas.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Cerro_Wahari-Amazonas.jpg/440px-Cerro_Wahari-Amazonas.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1267" data-file-height="846"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Cerro_Wahari-Amazonas.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Autana River, Amazonas State
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The second most important watershed is the Caribbean Sea. The rivers of this region are usually short and of scarce and irregular flow, with some exceptions such as the <a href="/wiki/Catatumbo_River" title="Catatumbo River">Catatumbo</a>, which originates in <a href="/wiki/Colombia" title="Colombia">Colombia</a> and drains into the Maracaibo Lake basin. Among the rivers that reach the Maracaibo lake basin are the Chama, the Escalante, the Catatumbo, and the contributions of the smaller basins of the Tocuyo, Yaracuy, Neverí and Manzanares rivers. </p>
      <p>A minimum drains to the Lake Valencia basin.<sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[175]</a></sup> Of the total extension of the rivers, a total of 5400&nbsp;km are navigable. Other rivers worth mentioning are the Apure, Arauca, Caura, Meta, Barima, <a href="/wiki/Portuguesa_River" title="Portuguesa River">Portuguesa</a>, Ventuari and Zulia, among others. </p>
      <p>The country's main lakes are Lake Maracaibo<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[176]</a></sup> -the largest in South America- open to the sea through the natural channel, but with fresh water, and Lake Valencia with its endorheic system. Other noteworthy bodies of water are the <a href="/wiki/Guri_Reservoir" title="Guri Reservoir">Guri reservoir</a>, the Altagracia lagoon, the Camatagua reservoir and the Mucubají lagoon in the Andes. Navigation in Lake Maracaibo through the natural channel is useful for the mobilization of oil resources. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Relief">Relief</span></h3> 
      <p>The Venezuelan natural landscape is the product of the interaction of <a href="/wiki/Tectonic_plates" class="mw-redirect" title="Tectonic plates">tectonic plates</a> that since the Paleozoic have contributed to its current appearance. On the formed structures, seven physical-natural units have been modeled, differentiated in their relief and in their natural resources. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Flores_para_la_Nieve.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Flores_para_la_Nieve.JPG/220px-Flores_para_la_Nieve.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Flores_para_la_Nieve.JPG/330px-Flores_para_la_Nieve.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/44/Flores_para_la_Nieve.JPG/440px-Flores_para_la_Nieve.JPG 2x" data-file-width="4896" data-file-height="3672"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Flores_para_la_Nieve.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Bol%C3%ADvar_Peak" class="mw-redirect" title="Bolívar Peak">Bolívar Peak</a>, the highest mountain in Venezuela
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The relief of Venezuela has the following characteristics: coastline with several peninsulas and <a href="/wiki/Islands" class="mw-redirect" title="Islands">islands</a>, adenas of the Andes mountain range (north and northwest), Lake Maracaibo (between the chains, on the coast); Orinoco river delta, region of peneplains and plateaus (tepui, east of the Orinoco) that together form the Guyanas massif (plateaus, southeast of the country). </p>
      <p>The oldest rock formations in <a href="/wiki/South_America" title="South America">South America</a> are found in the complex basement of the Guyanas highlands and in the crystalline line of the Maritime and Cordillera massifs in Venezuela. The Venezuelan part of the Guyanas Altiplano consists of a large granite block of gneiss and other crystalline Archean rocks, with underlying layers of sandstone and shale clay. The core of granite and Cordillera is, to a large extent, flanked by sedimentary layers from the Cretaceous, folded in an anticline structure. Between these orographic systems there are plains covered with tertiary and quaternary layers of gravels, sands and clayey marls. The depression in which are lagoons and lakes, among which is that of Maracaibo, presents, on the surface, alluvial deposits from the <a href="/wiki/Quaternary" title="Quaternary">Quaternary</a>, on layers of the Cretaceous and Tertiary particularly important, because of them oil infiltrations emerge. </p> 
      <ul>
       <li>The coasts</li>
      </ul> 
      <p>They present a landscape with intermountain depressions (separated by mountains), mountainous areas, a massif and an island group. </p> 
      <ul>
       <li>Lara-Falcón-Yaracuy System</li>
      </ul> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Puesta_de_sol_dorada,_Los_Llanos,_Gu%C3%A1rico.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Puesta_de_sol_dorada%2C_Los_Llanos%2C_Gu%C3%A1rico.JPG/220px-Puesta_de_sol_dorada%2C_Los_Llanos%2C_Gu%C3%A1rico.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Puesta_de_sol_dorada%2C_Los_Llanos%2C_Gu%C3%A1rico.JPG/330px-Puesta_de_sol_dorada%2C_Los_Llanos%2C_Gu%C3%A1rico.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/Puesta_de_sol_dorada%2C_Los_Llanos%2C_Gu%C3%A1rico.JPG/440px-Puesta_de_sol_dorada%2C_Los_Llanos%2C_Gu%C3%A1rico.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3648" data-file-height="2736"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Puesta_de_sol_dorada,_Los_Llanos,_Gu%C3%A1rico.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Sunset in Los Llanos, <a href="/wiki/Gu%C3%A1rico_state" class="mw-redirect" title="Guárico state">Guárico state</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The reliefs of mountain ranges contrast with those of the <a href="/wiki/Peninsula" title="Peninsula">peninsula</a>, coastal plains and intermountain depressions. </p> 
      <ul>
       <li>Lake Maracaibo Basin</li>
      </ul> 
      <p>The basin of the lake and the plains of the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Venezuela" title="Gulf of Venezuela">Gulf of Venezuela</a> make up two plains: the northern one, drier, and the southern one, humid and with swamps.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[177]</a></sup> </p> 
      <ul>
       <li>The Andes</li>
      </ul> 
      <p>The corpulent volumes of mountain ranges and <a href="/wiki/Mountain_ranges" class="mw-redirect" title="Mountain ranges">mountain ranges</a> predominate, as well as intramontane valleys (located within the mountains). </p> 
      <ul>
       <li>The plains</li>
      </ul> 
      <p>They form extensive sedimentary basins, with a predominantly flat relief,<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[178]</a></sup> except the eastern <a href="/wiki/Llanos" title="Llanos">Llanos</a>, which show plateaus, and the Unare depression, formed by the erosion of the mesa. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Venezuelan_Coasts_(261805027).jpeg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Venezuelan_Coasts_%28261805027%29.jpeg/220px-Venezuelan_Coasts_%28261805027%29.jpeg" decoding="async" width="220" height="329" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Venezuelan_Coasts_%28261805027%29.jpeg/330px-Venezuelan_Coasts_%28261805027%29.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Venezuelan_Coasts_%28261805027%29.jpeg/440px-Venezuelan_Coasts_%28261805027%29.jpeg 2x" data-file-width="1371" data-file-height="2048"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Venezuelan_Coasts_(261805027).jpeg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Mountain ranges on the Caribbean Sea coast of Venezuela, <a href="/wiki/Carabobo_State" class="mw-redirect" title="Carabobo State">Carabobo State</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <ul>
       <li>Guiana Shield</li>
      </ul> 
      <p>It exhibits a varied relief, shaped by different rocks, orogenic events and erosion over millions of years. That is why here there are peneplains, mountain ranges, foothills and the characteristic <a href="/wiki/Tepuis" class="mw-redirect" title="Tepuis">tepuis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[179]</a></sup> </p> 
      <ul>
       <li>Orinoco Delta</li>
      </ul> 
      <p>With few contrasts, it builds a complex system of lands and waters, with varied sedimentary contributions and innumerable channels and islands.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[180]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The morphology of the Venezuelan relief has largely determined the distribution of human settlements. Ignorance of the factors associated with relief has been one of the most important causes of <a href="/wiki/Natural_disasters" class="mw-redirect" title="Natural disasters">natural disasters</a>. The continuous landslides linked to the location of houses in areas of steep slopes, as well as the seasonal <a href="/wiki/Flooding" class="mw-redirect" title="Flooding">flooding</a> of many human settlements located in the floodplains of the water courses are known. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Venezuela" title="Government of Venezuela">Government of Venezuela</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_Venezuela" title="Cabinet of Venezuela">Cabinet of Venezuela</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Venezuela" title="Politics of Venezuela">Politics of Venezuela</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:PalacioLegislativo2_fixed.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/PalacioLegislativo2_fixed.jpg/220px-PalacioLegislativo2_fixed.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="312" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/PalacioLegislativo2_fixed.jpg/330px-PalacioLegislativo2_fixed.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/PalacioLegislativo2_fixed.jpg/440px-PalacioLegislativo2_fixed.jpg 2x" data-file-width="471" data-file-height="667"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:PalacioLegislativo2_fixed.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_of_Venezuela" class="mw-redirect" title="National Assembly of Venezuela">National Assembly of Venezuela</a> <a href="/wiki/Palacio_Federal_Legislativo" title="Palacio Federal Legislativo">building</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Following the fall of Marcos Pérez Jiménez in 1958, Venezuelan politics were dominated by the <a href="/wiki/Third_Way" title="Third Way">Third Way</a> <a href="/wiki/Christian_democracy" title="Christian democracy">Christian democratic</a> COPEI and the center-left <a href="/wiki/Social_democracy" title="Social democracy">social democratic</a> Democratic Action (AD) parties; this <a href="/wiki/Two-party_system" title="Two-party system">two-party system</a> was formalized by the <i><a href="/wiki/Puntofijismo" class="mw-redirect" title="Puntofijismo">puntofijismo</a></i> arrangement. Economic crises in the 1980s and 1990s led to a political crisis which resulted in hundreds dead in the Caracazo riots of 1989, two attempted coups in 1992, and impeachment of President Carlos Andrés Pérez for corruption in 1993. A collapse in confidence in the existing parties saw the 1998 election of Hugo Chávez, who had led the first of the 1992 coup attempts, and the launch of a "Bolivarian Revolution", beginning with a 1999 Constituent Assembly to write a new Constitution of Venezuela. </p>
      <p>The opposition's attempts to unseat Chávez included the 2002 Venezuelan <i>coup d'état</i> attempt, the Venezuelan general strike of 2002–2003, and the Venezuelan recall referendum, 2004, all of which failed. Chávez was re-elected in December 2006 but suffered a significant defeat in 2007 with the narrow rejection of the <a href="/wiki/2007_Venezuelan_constitutional_referendum" title="2007 Venezuelan constitutional referendum">2007 Venezuelan constitutional referendum</a>, which had offered two packages of constitutional reforms aimed at deepening the Bolivarian Revolution. </p>
      <p>Two major blocs of <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_Venezuela" title="List of political parties in Venezuela">political parties</a> are in Venezuela: the incumbent leftist bloc United Socialist Party of Venezuela (PSUV), its major allies <a href="/wiki/Fatherland_for_All" title="Fatherland for All">Fatherland for All</a> (PPT) and the Communist Party of Venezuela (PCV), and the opposition bloc grouped into the electoral coalition <a href="/wiki/Mesa_de_la_Unidad_Democr%C3%A1tica" class="mw-redirect" title="Mesa de la Unidad Democrática">Mesa de la Unidad Democrática</a>. This includes <a href="/wiki/A_New_Era" title="A New Era">A New Era</a> (UNT) together with allied parties <a href="/wiki/Project_Venezuela" title="Project Venezuela">Project Venezuela</a>, <a href="/wiki/Justice_First" title="Justice First">Justice First</a>, <a href="/wiki/Movement_for_Socialism_(Venezuela)" title="Movement for Socialism (Venezuela)">Movement for Socialism</a> (MAS) and others. Hugo Chávez, the central figure of the Venezuelan political landscape since his election to the presidency in 1998 as a political outsider, died in office in early 2013, and was succeeded by Nicolás Maduro (initially as interim president, before narrowly winning the <a href="/wiki/2013_Venezuelan_presidential_election" title="2013 Venezuelan presidential election">2013 Venezuelan presidential election</a>). </p>
      <p>The Venezuelan president is elected by a vote, with direct and <a href="/wiki/Universal_suffrage" title="Universal suffrage">universal suffrage</a>, and is both <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a> and <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a>. The term of office is six years, and (as of 15 February 2009) a president may be re-elected an unlimited number of times. The president appoints the vice president and decides the size and composition of the cabinet and makes appointments to it with the involvement of the legislature. The president can ask the legislature to reconsider portions of laws he finds objectionable, but a simple parliamentary majority can override these objections. </p>
      <p>The president may ask the National Assembly to pass an <a href="/wiki/Enabling_act#In_Venezuela" title="Enabling act">enabling act</a> granting the ability to <a href="/wiki/Rule_by_decree" title="Rule by decree">rule by decree</a> in specified policy areas; this requires a two-thirds majority in the Assembly. Since 1959, six Venezuelan presidents have been granted such powers. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Unicameral" class="mw-redirect" title="Unicameral">unicameral</a> Venezuelan parliament is the <i>Asamblea Nacional</i> ("National Assembly"). The number of members is variable – each state and the Capital district elect three representatives plus the result of dividing the state population by 1.1% of the total population of the country.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[181]</a></sup> Three seats are reserved for representatives of Venezuela's indigenous peoples. For the 2011–2016 period the number of seats is 165.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[182]</a></sup> All deputies serve five-year terms. </p>
      <p>The voting age in Venezuela is 18 and older. Voting is not <a href="/wiki/Compulsory_voting" title="Compulsory voting">compulsory</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-TG_185-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TG-185">[183]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Venezuela" title="Law of Venezuela">legal system of Venezuela</a> belongs to the <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">Continental Law</a> tradition. The highest <a href="/wiki/Judiciary" title="Judiciary">judicial</a> body is the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Tribunal_of_Justice_(Venezuela)" title="Supreme Tribunal of Justice (Venezuela)">Supreme Tribunal of Justice</a> or <i>Tribunal Supremo de Justicia</i>, whose magistrates are elected by parliament for a single two-year term. The <a href="/wiki/National_Electoral_Council_(Venezuela)" title="National Electoral Council (Venezuela)">National Electoral Council</a> (<i>Consejo Nacional Electoral</i>, or <i>CNE</i>) is in charge of electoral processes; it is formed by five main directors elected by the National Assembly. Supreme Court president Luisa Estela Morales said in December 2009 that Venezuela had moved away from "a rigid division of powers" toward a system characterized by "intense coordination" between the branches of government. Morales clarified that each power must be independent adding that "one thing is separation of powers and another one is division".<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[184]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Suspension_of_constitutional_rights">Suspension of constitutional rights</span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Venezuela_protests_against_the_Nicolas_Maduro_government,_Altamira_Square_6.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Venezuela_protests_against_the_Nicolas_Maduro_government%2C_Altamira_Square_6.JPG/220px-Venezuela_protests_against_the_Nicolas_Maduro_government%2C_Altamira_Square_6.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Venezuela_protests_against_the_Nicolas_Maduro_government%2C_Altamira_Square_6.JPG/330px-Venezuela_protests_against_the_Nicolas_Maduro_government%2C_Altamira_Square_6.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Venezuela_protests_against_the_Nicolas_Maduro_government%2C_Altamira_Square_6.JPG/440px-Venezuela_protests_against_the_Nicolas_Maduro_government%2C_Altamira_Square_6.JPG 2x" data-file-width="4288" data-file-height="3216"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Venezuela_protests_against_the_Nicolas_Maduro_government,_Altamira_Square_6.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Protests in <a href="/wiki/Altamira_(Caracas)" class="mw-redirect" title="Altamira (Caracas)">Altamira</a>, Caracas (2014)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/2015_Venezuelan_parliamentary_election" title="2015 Venezuelan parliamentary election">2015 parliamentary elections</a> were held on 6 December 2015 to elect the 164 <a href="/wiki/Deputies" class="mw-redirect" title="Deputies">deputies</a> and three indigenous representatives of the National Assembly. In 2014, a series of protest and demonstrations began in Venezuela, attributed<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch"><span title="The material near this tag may use weasel words or too-vague attribution. (May 2019)">by whom?</span></a></i>]</sup> to inflation, violence and shortages in Venezuela. The government has accused the protest of being motivated by <a href="/wiki/Fascists" class="mw-redirect" title="Fascists">fascists</a>, opposition leaders, capitalism and foreign influence,<sup id="cite_ref-Milne_187-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Milne-187">[185]</a></sup> despite being largely peaceful.<sup id="cite_ref-SVCOprotestINFO_188-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SVCOprotestINFO-188">[186]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>President Maduro acknowledged <a href="/wiki/PSUV" class="mw-redirect" title="PSUV">PSUV</a> defeat, but attributed the opposition's victory to an intensification of an economic war. Despite this, Maduro said "I will stop by hook or by crook the opposition coming to power, whatever the costs, in any way".<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[187]</a></sup> In the following months, Maduro fulfilled his promise of preventing the democratically and constitutionally elected National Assembly from legislating. The first steps taken by PSUV and government were the substitution of the entire <a href="/wiki/Supreme_court" title="Supreme court">Supreme court</a> a day after the Parliamentary Elections<sup id="cite_ref-prodavinci.com_190-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-prodavinci.com-190">[188]</a></sup> contrary to the Constitution of Venezuela, acclaimed as a fraud by the majority of the Venezuelan and international press.<sup id="cite_ref-larazon.net_191-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-larazon.net-191">[189]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-el-nacional.com_192-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-el-nacional.com-192">[190]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bbc.com_193-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc.com-193">[191]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ntn24web.com_194-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ntn24web.com-194">[192]</a></sup> The <i>Financial Times</i> described the function of the Supreme Court in Venezuela as "rubber stamping executive whims and vetoing legislation".<sup id="cite_ref-:0_195-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-195">[193]</a></sup> The PSUV government used this violation to suspend several elected opponents,<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[194]</a></sup> ignoring again the Constitution of Venezuela. Maduro said that "the Amnesty law (approved by the Parliament) will not be executed" and asked the Supreme Court to declare it unconstitutional before the law was known.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[195]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On 16 January 2016, Maduro approved an unconstitutional economic emergency decree,<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[196]</a></sup> relegating to his own figure the legislative and executive powers, while also holding judiciary power through the fraudulent designation of judges the day after the election on 6 December 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-prodavinci.com_190-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-prodavinci.com-190">[188]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-larazon.net_191-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-larazon.net-191">[189]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-el-nacional.com_192-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-el-nacional.com-192">[190]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-bbc.com_193-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc.com-193">[191]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ntn24web.com_194-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ntn24web.com-194">[192]</a></sup> From these events, Maduro effectively controls all three branches of government. On 14 May 2016, constitutional guarantees were in fact suspended when Maduro decreed the extension of the economic emergency decree for another 60 days and declared a State of Emergency,<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[197]</a></sup> which is a clear violation of the Constitution of Venezuela<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[198]</a></sup> in the Article 338th: "The approval of the extension of States of emergency corresponds to the National Assembly." Thus, constitutional rights in Venezuela are considered suspended in fact by many publications<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[199]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[200]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[201]</a></sup> and public figures.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[202]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[203]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[204]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On 14 May 2016, the <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_American_States" title="Organization of American States">Organization of American States</a> was considering the application of the <a href="/wiki/Inter-American_Democratic_Charter" title="Inter-American Democratic Charter">Inter-American Democratic Charter</a><sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[205]</a></sup> sanctions for non-compliance to its own constitution. </p>
      <p>In March 2017, the Venezuelan Supreme Court took over law making powers from the National Assembly<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[206]</a></sup> but reversed its decision the following day.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[207]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Venezuela" title="Foreign relations of Venezuela">Foreign relations of Venezuela</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Guayana_Esequiba_(zona_completa).png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Guayana_Esequiba_%28zona_completa%29.png/220px-Guayana_Esequiba_%28zona_completa%29.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="220" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Guayana_Esequiba_%28zona_completa%29.png/330px-Guayana_Esequiba_%28zona_completa%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Guayana_Esequiba_%28zona_completa%29.png/440px-Guayana_Esequiba_%28zona_completa%29.png 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="800"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Guayana_Esequiba_(zona_completa).png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Guayana_Esequiba" title="Guayana Esequiba">Guayana Esequiba</a> claim area is a territory administered by <a href="/wiki/Guyana" title="Guyana">Guyana</a> and claimed by Venezuela.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Throughout most of the 20th century, Venezuela maintained friendly relations with most Latin American and Western nations. Relations between Venezuela and the United States government worsened in 2002, after the 2002 Venezuelan coup d'état attempt during which the U.S. government recognized the short-lived interim presidency of <a href="/wiki/Pedro_Carmona" title="Pedro Carmona">Pedro Carmona</a>. In 2015, Venezuela was declared a national security threat by U.S. president <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[208]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[209]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[210]</a></sup> Correspondingly, ties to various Latin American and Middle Eastern countries not allied to the U.S. have strengthened. For example, Palestinian foreign minister Riyad al-Maliki declared in 2015 that Venezuela was his country's "most important ally".<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[211]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Venezuela seeks alternative <a href="/wiki/Western_Hemisphere" title="Western Hemisphere">hemispheric</a> integration via such proposals as the <a href="/wiki/Bolivarian_Alternative_for_the_Americas" class="mw-redirect" title="Bolivarian Alternative for the Americas">Bolivarian Alternative for the Americas</a> trade proposal and the newly launched Latin American television network <a href="/wiki/TeleSUR" class="mw-redirect" title="TeleSUR">teleSUR</a>. Venezuela is one of five nations in the world—along with Russia, Nicaragua, Nauru, and Syria—to have recognized the independence of <a href="/wiki/International_recognition_of_Abkhazia_and_South_Ossetia" title="International recognition of Abkhazia and South Ossetia">Abkhazia and South Ossetia</a>.
