Venezuela was a proponent of <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_American_States" title="Organization of American States">OAS</a>'s decision to adopt its Anti-Corruption Convention<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[212]</a></sup> and is actively working in the <a href="/wiki/Mercosur" title="Mercosur">Mercosur</a> trade bloc to push increased trade and energy integration. Globally, it seeks a "<a href="/wiki/Polarity_in_international_relations" class="mw-redirect" title="Polarity in international relations">multi-polar</a>" world based on strengthened ties among undeveloped countries. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:XIV_cumbre_del_ALBA-TCP.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/XIV_cumbre_del_ALBA-TCP.jpg/220px-XIV_cumbre_del_ALBA-TCP.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="148" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/XIV_cumbre_del_ALBA-TCP.jpg/330px-XIV_cumbre_del_ALBA-TCP.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/XIV_cumbre_del_ALBA-TCP.jpg/440px-XIV_cumbre_del_ALBA-TCP.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5939" data-file-height="3989"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:XIV_cumbre_del_ALBA-TCP.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>President Maduro among other Latin American leaders participating in a 2017 <a href="/wiki/ALBA" title="ALBA">ALBA</a> gathering
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>On 26 April 2017, Venezuela announced its intention to withdraw from the OAS.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">[213]</a></sup> Venezuelan Foreign Minister <a href="/wiki/Delcy_Rodr%C3%ADguez" title="Delcy Rodríguez">Delcy Rodríguez</a> said that President <a href="/wiki/Nicol%C3%A1s_Maduro" title="Nicolás Maduro">Nicolás Maduro</a> plans to publicly renounce Venezuela's membership on 27 April 2017. It will take two years for the country to formally leave. During this period, the country does not plan on participating in the OAS.<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[214]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Venezuela is involved in a long-standing disagreement about the control of the <a href="/wiki/Guayana_Esequiba" title="Guayana Esequiba">Guayana Esequiba</a> area. </p>
      <p>Venezuela may suffer a deterioration of its power in international affairs if the global <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy_transition" title="Renewable energy transition">transition to renewable energy</a> is completed. It is ranked 151 out of 156 countries in the index of Geopolitical Gains and Losses after energy transition (GeGaLo).<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[215]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/National_Bolivarian_Armed_Forces_of_Venezuela" title="National Bolivarian Armed Forces of Venezuela">National Bolivarian Armed Forces of Venezuela</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Venezuelan_Air_Force_Sukhoi_SU-30MK2_AADPR-2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Venezuelan_Air_Force_Sukhoi_SU-30MK2_AADPR-2.jpg/220px-Venezuelan_Air_Force_Sukhoi_SU-30MK2_AADPR-2.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="155" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Venezuelan_Air_Force_Sukhoi_SU-30MK2_AADPR-2.jpg/330px-Venezuelan_Air_Force_Sukhoi_SU-30MK2_AADPR-2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Venezuelan_Air_Force_Sukhoi_SU-30MK2_AADPR-2.jpg/440px-Venezuelan_Air_Force_Sukhoi_SU-30MK2_AADPR-2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="721"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Venezuelan_Air_Force_Sukhoi_SU-30MK2_AADPR-2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A <a href="/wiki/Sukhoi_Su-30" title="Sukhoi Su-30">Sukhoi Su-30</a>MKV of the Venezuelan Air Force
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Bolivarian National Armed Forces of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela (Fuerza Armada Nacional Bolivariana, FANB) are the overall unified military forces of Venezuela. It includes over 320,150 men and women, under Article 328 of the Constitution, in 5 components of Ground, Sea and Air. The components of the Bolivarian National Armed Forces are: the <a href="/wiki/Venezuelan_Army" title="Venezuelan Army">Venezuelan Army</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Venezuelan_Navy" class="mw-redirect" title="Venezuelan Navy">Venezuelan Navy</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Venezuelan_Air_Force" class="mw-redirect" title="Venezuelan Air Force">Venezuelan Air Force</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Venezuelan_National_Guard" title="Venezuelan National Guard">Venezuelan National Guard</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Venezuelan_National_Militia" class="mw-redirect" title="Venezuelan National Militia">Venezuelan National Militia</a>. </p>
      <p>As of 2008<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Venezuela&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, a further 600,000 soldiers were incorporated into a new branch, known as the Armed Reserve. The president of Venezuela is the <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">commander-in-chief</a> of the national armed forces. The main roles of the armed forces are to defend the sovereign national territory of Venezuela, airspace, and islands, fight against drug trafficking, to search and rescue and, in the case of a natural disaster, civil protection. All male citizens of Venezuela have a constitutional duty to register for the military service at the age of 18, which is the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_majority" title="Age of majority">age of majority</a> in Venezuela. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_and_crime">Law and crime</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Venezuela" title="Law of Venezuela">Law of Venezuela</a> and <a href="/wiki/Crime_in_Venezuela" title="Crime in Venezuela">Crime in Venezuela</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:334px;max-width:334px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:332px;max-width:332px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:1998_to_2018_Venezuela_Murder_Rate.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/1998_to_2018_Venezuela_Murder_Rate.png/330px-1998_to_2018_Venezuela_Murder_Rate.png" decoding="async" width="330" height="229" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/1998_to_2018_Venezuela_Murder_Rate.png/495px-1998_to_2018_Venezuela_Murder_Rate.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/1998_to_2018_Venezuela_Murder_Rate.png/660px-1998_to_2018_Venezuela_Murder_Rate.png 2x" data-file-width="2200" data-file-height="1529"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Murder rate (murder per 100,000 citizens) from 1998 to 2018. 
           <br><b>Sources:</b> OVV,<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[216]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FUSIONmr_219-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FUSIONmr-219">[217]</a></sup> PROVEA,<sup id="cite_ref-UNODC2011_220-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNODC2011-220">[218]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-UNODC2014_221-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNODC2014-221">[219]</a></sup> UN<sup id="cite_ref-UNODC2011_220-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNODC2011-220">[218]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-UNODC2014_221-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNODC2014-221">[219]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-AFP2012_222-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AFP2012-222">[220]</a></sup>
           <br> <b>*</b> UN line between 2007 and 2012 is simulated missing data.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:332px;max-width:332px">
          <div class="thumbimage">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Number_of_kidnappings_in_Venezuela_1989_to_present_(Presidents).png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Number_of_kidnappings_in_Venezuela_1989_to_present_%28Presidents%29.png/330px-Number_of_kidnappings_in_Venezuela_1989_to_present_%28Presidents%29.png" decoding="async" width="330" height="205" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Number_of_kidnappings_in_Venezuela_1989_to_present_%28Presidents%29.png/495px-Number_of_kidnappings_in_Venezuela_1989_to_present_%28Presidents%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Number_of_kidnappings_in_Venezuela_1989_to_present_%28Presidents%29.png/660px-Number_of_kidnappings_in_Venezuela_1989_to_present_%28Presidents%29.png 2x" data-file-width="2250" data-file-height="1400"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           Number of kidnappings in Venezuela 1989–2011
           <br><b>Source:</b> <b><a href="/wiki/Cuerpo_de_Investigaciones_Cient%C3%ADficas,_Penales_y_Criminal%C3%ADsticas" title="Cuerpo de Investigaciones Científicas, Penales y Criminalísticas">CICPC</a></b><sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">[221]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CICPC2009_224-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CICPC2009-224">[222]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">[223]</a></sup>
           <br><b>*</b> <a href="/wiki/Express_kidnapping" title="Express kidnapping">Express kidnappings</a> may not be included in data
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In Venezuela, a person is murdered every 21 minutes.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[224]</a></sup> Violent crimes have been so prevalent in Venezuela that the government no longer produces the crime data.<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">[225]</a></sup> In 2013, the homicide rate was approximately 79 per 100,000, one of the world's highest, having quadrupled in the past 15 years with over 200,000 people murdered.<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[226]</a></sup> By 2015, it had risen to 90 per 100,000.<sup id="cite_ref-BBCVenezuela_229-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBCVenezuela-229">[227]</a></sup> The country's body count of the previous decade mimics that of the <a href="/wiki/Iraq_War" title="Iraq War">Iraq War</a> and in some instances had more civilian deaths even though the country is at <a href="/wiki/Peacetime" class="mw-redirect" title="Peacetime">peacetime</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">[228]</a></sup> The capital Caracas has one of the greatest homicide rates of any large city in the world, with 122 homicides per 100,000 residents.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[229]</a></sup> In 2008, polls indicated that crime was the number one concern of voters.<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[230]</a></sup> Attempts at fighting crime such as Operation Liberation of the People were implemented to crack down on gang-controlled areas<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[231]</a></sup> but, of reported criminal acts, less than 2% are prosecuted.<sup id="cite_ref-Finnegan_234-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Finnegan-234">[232]</a></sup> In 2017, the <i>Financial Times</i> noted that some of the arms procured by the government over the previous two decades had been diverted to paramilitary civilian groups and criminal syndicates.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_195-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-195">[193]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Venezuela is especially dangerous for foreign travelers and investors who are visiting. The <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_State" title="United States Department of State">United States Department of State</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Canada" title="Government of Canada">Government of Canada</a> have warned foreign visitors that they may be subjected to robbery, kidnapping for a ransom or sale to terrorist organizations<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[233]</a></sup> and murder, and that their own diplomatic travelers are required to travel in <a href="/wiki/Armored_vehicles" class="mw-redirect" title="Armored vehicles">armored vehicles</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">[234]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">[235]</a></sup> The United Kingdom's <a href="/wiki/Foreign_and_Commonwealth_Office" class="mw-redirect" title="Foreign and Commonwealth Office">Foreign and Commonwealth Office</a> has advised against all travel to Venezuela.<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[236]</a></sup> Visitors have been murdered during robberies and criminals do not discriminate among their victims. Former Miss Venezuela 2004 winner <a href="/wiki/M%C3%B3nica_Spear" title="Mónica Spear">Mónica Spear</a> and her ex-husband were murdered and their 5-year-old daughter was shot while vacationing in Venezuela, and an elderly German tourist was murdered only a few weeks later.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">[237]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[238]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There are approximately 33 prisons holding about 50,000 inmates.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[239]</a></sup> They include; El Rodeo outside of Caracas, Yare Prison in the northern state of Miranda, and several others. Venezuela's prison system is heavily overcrowded; its facilities have capacity for only 14,000 prisoners.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[240]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Human_rights">Human rights</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Venezuela" title="Human rights in Venezuela">Human rights in Venezuela</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Human rights organizations such as <a href="/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch" title="Human Rights Watch">Human Rights Watch</a> and <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">Amnesty International</a> have increasingly criticized Venezuela's human rights record, with the former organization noting in 2017 that the Chavez and subsequently the Maduro government have increasingly concentrated power in the executive branch, eroded constitutional human rights protections and allowed the government to persecute and repress its critics and opposition.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[241]</a></sup> Other persistent concerns as noted by the report included poor prison conditions, the continuous <a href="/wiki/Mass_media_in_Venezuela" title="Mass media in Venezuela">harassment of independent media</a> and human rights defenders by the government. In 2006, the <a href="/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit" title="Economist Intelligence Unit">Economist Intelligence Unit</a> rated Venezuela a "hybrid regime" and the third least democratic regime in Latin America on the <a href="/wiki/Democracy_Index" title="Democracy Index">Democracy Index</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[242]</a></sup> The Democracy index downgraded Venezuela to an authoritarian regime in 2017, citing continued increasingly dictatorial behaviors by the Maduro government.<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">[243]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Corruption">Corruption</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Venezuela" title="Corruption in Venezuela">Corruption in Venezuela</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Corrupt_Venezuelan_Regime.pdf" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Corrupt_Venezuelan_Regime.pdf/page1-220px-Corrupt_Venezuelan_Regime.pdf.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="170" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Corrupt_Venezuelan_Regime.pdf/page1-330px-Corrupt_Venezuelan_Regime.pdf.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/Corrupt_Venezuelan_Regime.pdf/page1-440px-Corrupt_Venezuelan_Regime.pdf.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1650" data-file-height="1275"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Corrupt_Venezuelan_Regime.pdf" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <i><a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Venezuela" title="Corruption in Venezuela">Corrupt Venezuelan Regime</a></i>, according to the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Justice" title="United States Department of Justice">United States Department of Justice</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Corruption_in_Venezuela" title="Corruption in Venezuela">Corruption in Venezuela</a> is high by world standards and was so for much of the 20th century. The discovery of oil had worsened political corruption,<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">[244]</a></sup> and by the late 1970s, <a href="/wiki/Juan_Pablo_P%C3%A9rez_Alfonso" class="mw-redirect" title="Juan Pablo Pérez Alfonso">Juan Pablo Pérez Alfonso</a>'s description of oil as "the Devil's excrement" had become a common expression in Venezuela.<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">[245]</a></sup> Venezuela has been ranked one of the most corrupt countries on the <a href="/wiki/Corruption_Perceptions_Index" title="Corruption Perceptions Index">Corruption Perceptions Index</a> since the survey started in 1995. The 2010 ranking placed Venezuela at number 164, out of 178 ranked countries in government transparency.<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248">[246]</a></sup> By 2016, the rank had increased to 166 out of 178.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">[247]</a></sup> Similarly, the <a href="/wiki/World_Justice_Project" title="World Justice Project">World Justice Project</a> ranked Venezuela 99th out of 99 countries surveyed in its 2014 Rule of Law Index.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">[248]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>This corruption is shown with Venezuela's significant involvement in <a href="/wiki/Illegal_drug_trade_in_Venezuela" title="Illegal drug trade in Venezuela">drug trafficking</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Colombian_cocaine" class="mw-redirect" title="Colombian cocaine">Colombian cocaine</a> and other drugs transiting Venezuela towards the United States and Europe. In the period 2003 - 2008 Venezuelan authorities seized the fifth largest total quantity of cocaine in the world, behind Colombia, the United States, Spain and <a href="/wiki/Panama" title="Panama">Panama</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">[249]</a></sup> In 2006, the government's agency for combating illegal drug trade in Venezuela, <i><a href="/wiki/National_Anti-Drug_Office" class="mw-redirect" title="National Anti-Drug Office">ONA</a></i>, was incorporated into the office of the vice-president of the country. However, many major government and military officials have been known for their involvement with drug trafficking; especially with the October 2013 incident of men from the Venezuelan National Guard placing 1.3 tons of <a href="/wiki/Cocaine" title="Cocaine">cocaine</a> on a Paris flight knowing they will not face charges.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">[250]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_Divisions">Administrative Divisions</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/States_of_Venezuela" title="States of Venezuela">States of Venezuela</a> and <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_Venezuela" title="Regions of Venezuela">Regions of Venezuela</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Localizador_Politico_de_Venezuela.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Localizador_Politico_de_Venezuela.svg/220px-Localizador_Politico_de_Venezuela.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="253" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Localizador_Politico_de_Venezuela.svg/330px-Localizador_Politico_de_Venezuela.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/Localizador_Politico_de_Venezuela.svg/440px-Localizador_Politico_de_Venezuela.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="534" data-file-height="614"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Localizador_Politico_de_Venezuela.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Map of the Venezuelan federation
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Venezuela is divided into 23 states (<i>estados</i>), a capital district (<i>distrito capital</i>) corresponding to the city of Caracas, and the Federal Dependencies (<i>Dependencias Federales</i>, a special territory). Venezuela is further subdivided into 335 municipalities (<i>municipios</i>); these are subdivided into over one thousand parishes (<i>parroquias</i>). The states are grouped into nine administrative regions (<i>regiones administrativas</i>), which were established in 1969 by presidential decree.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>The country can be further divided into ten geographical areas, some corresponding to climatic and biogeographical regions. In the north are the <a href="/wiki/Venezuelan_Andes" title="Venezuelan Andes">Venezuelan Andes</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Coro_region" title="Coro region">Coro region</a>, a mountainous tract in the northwest, holds several <a href="/wiki/Mountain_range" title="Mountain range">sierras</a> and valleys. East of it are lowlands abutting <a href="/wiki/Lake_Maracaibo" title="Lake Maracaibo">Lake Maracaibo</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Venezuela" title="Gulf of Venezuela">Gulf of Venezuela</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Cordillera_de_la_Costa_Central" title="Cordillera de la Costa Central">Central Range</a> runs parallel to the coast and includes the hills surrounding Caracas; the Eastern Range, separated from the Central Range by the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Cariaco" class="mw-redirect" title="Gulf of Cariaco">Gulf of Cariaco</a>, covers all of <a href="/wiki/Sucre_(state)" title="Sucre (state)">Sucre</a> and northern <a href="/wiki/Monagas" title="Monagas">Monagas</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Insular_Region_(Venezuela)" class="mw-redirect" title="Insular Region (Venezuela)">Insular Region</a> includes all of Venezuela's island possessions: <a href="/wiki/Nueva_Esparta" title="Nueva Esparta">Nueva Esparta</a> and the various <a href="/wiki/Federal_Dependencies" class="mw-redirect" title="Federal Dependencies">Federal Dependencies</a>. The Orinoco Delta, which forms a triangle covering <a href="/wiki/Delta_Amacuro" title="Delta Amacuro">Delta Amacuro</a>, projects northeast into the Atlantic Ocean.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Additionally, the country maintains a historical claim on the territory it calls Guyana Esequiba, which is equivalent to about 160,000 square kilometers and corresponds to all the territory administered by Guyana west of the Esequibo River. In 1966 the British and Venezuelan governments signed the Geneva Agreement to resolve the conflict peacefully. In addition to this agreement, the Port of Spain Protocol of 1970 set a deadline to try to resolve the issue, without success to date.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <table style="background:transparent;font-size: 11px;float: left">

            <b><a href="/wiki/Caribbean_Sea" title="Caribbean Sea"><span style="color:white; font-size: 1.3em">Caribbean Sea</span></a></b>
           </div> 
           <div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:399px; top:17px">

          </div>

           <br>

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Venezuela" title="Economy of Venezuela">Economy of Venezuela</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Venezuela_Export_Treemap.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Venezuela_Export_Treemap.png/220px-Venezuela_Export_Treemap.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="171" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Venezuela_Export_Treemap.png/330px-Venezuela_Export_Treemap.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Venezuela_Export_Treemap.png/440px-Venezuela_Export_Treemap.png 2x" data-file-width="961" data-file-height="749"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Venezuela_Export_Treemap.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Graphical depiction of Venezuela's product exports in 28 color-coded categories
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Venezuela has a market-based <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">mixed economy</a> dominated by the petroleum sector,<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[252]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">[253]</a></sup> which accounts for roughly a third of GDP, around 80% of exports, and more than half of government revenues. Per capita GDP for 2016 was estimated to be US$15,100, ranking 109th in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-CIA_66-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-66">[64]</a></sup> Venezuela has the <a href="/wiki/Gasoline_usage_and_pricing" class="mw-redirect" title="Gasoline usage and pricing">least expensive petrol</a> in the world because the consumer price of petrol is heavily subsidized. The private sector controls two-thirds of Venezuela's economy.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">[254]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Central_Bank_of_Venezuela" title="Central Bank of Venezuela">Central Bank of Venezuela</a> is responsible for developing <a href="/wiki/Monetary_policy" title="Monetary policy">monetary policy</a> for the <a href="/wiki/Venezuelan_bol%C3%ADvar" title="Venezuelan bolívar">Venezuelan bolívar</a> which is used as currency. The president of the Central Bank of Venezuela serves as the country's representative in the <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a>. The U.S.-based conservative think tank <a href="/wiki/The_Heritage_Foundation" title="The Heritage Foundation">The Heritage Foundation</a>, cited in <i><a href="/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal" title="The Wall Street Journal">The Wall Street Journal</a></i>, claims Venezuela has the weakest property rights in the world, scoring only 5.0 on a scale of 100; expropriation without compensation is not uncommon. </p>
      <p>As of 2011, more than 60% of Venezuela's international reserves was in gold, eight times more than the average for the region. Most of Venezuela's gold held abroad was located in London. On 25 November 2011, the first of US$11&nbsp;billion of repatriated gold bullion arrived in Caracas; Chávez called the repatriation of gold a "sovereign" step that will help protect the country's foreign reserves from the turmoil in the U.S. and Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257">[255]</a></sup> However government policies quickly spent down this returned gold and in 2013 the government was forced to add the dollar reserves of state owned companies to those of the national bank to reassure the international bond market.<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">[256]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright" style="">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px">
        <div class="thumbimage noresize" style="width:350px;"> 
         <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1017906329">@media all and (max-width:720px){body.skin-minerva .mw-parser-output .mw-graph{min-width:100%!important;max-width:100%;overflow-x:auto;overflow-y:visible}}.mw-parser-output .mw-graph-img{width:inherit;height:inherit}</style>
         <div class="mw-graph mw-graph-always mw-graph-nofallback" style="min-width:300px;min-height:230px" data-graph-id="b7e37717caa1b3eb1459d5e54d955241160f135e"></div>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         Annual variation of real GDP according to the Central Bank of Venezuela (2016 preliminary)<sup id="cite_ref-BCV2016_259-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BCV2016-259">[257]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">[258]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Manufacturing contributed 17% of GDP in 2006. Venezuela manufactures and exports heavy industry products such as steel, aluminium and cement, with production concentrated around <a href="/wiki/Ciudad_Guayana" title="Ciudad Guayana">Ciudad Guayana</a>, near the <a href="/wiki/Guri_Dam" title="Guri Dam">Guri Dam</a>, one of the largest in the world and the provider of about three-quarters of Venezuela's electricity. Other notable manufacturing includes <a href="/wiki/Electronics" title="Electronics">electronics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Automobiles" class="mw-redirect" title="Automobiles">automobiles</a>, as well as beverages, and <a href="/wiki/Foodstuff" class="mw-redirect" title="Foodstuff">foodstuffs</a>. <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Venezuela" title="Agriculture in Venezuela">Agriculture in Venezuela</a> accounts for approximately 3% of GDP, 10% of the labor force, and at least a quarter of Venezuela's land area. The country is not self-sufficient in most areas of agriculture. In 2012, total food consumption was over 26 million metric tonnes, a 94.8% increase from 2003.<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">[259]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Since the discovery of oil in the early 20th century, Venezuela has been one of the world's leading exporters of oil, and it is a founding member of <a href="/wiki/OPEC" title="OPEC">OPEC</a>. Previously an underdeveloped exporter of agricultural commodities such as coffee and cocoa, oil quickly came to dominate exports and government revenues. The 1980s oil glut led to an external debt crisis and a long-running economic crisis, which saw inflation peak at 100% in 1996 and poverty rates rise to 66% in 1995<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcCaughan200532_262-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCaughan200532-262">[260]</a></sup> as (by 1998) per capita GDP fell to the same level as 1963, down a third from its 1978 peak.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKellyPalma2006207_263-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKellyPalma2006207-263">[261]</a></sup> The 1990s also saw Venezuela experience a <a href="/wiki/Venezuelan_banking_crisis_of_1994" title="Venezuelan banking crisis of 1994">major banking crisis in 1994</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Centro_Empresarial_Sabana_Grande_y_Mc_Donald%27s_Vicente_Quintero.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Centro_Empresarial_Sabana_Grande_y_Mc_Donald%27s_Vicente_Quintero.jpg/220px-Centro_Empresarial_Sabana_Grande_y_Mc_Donald%27s_Vicente_Quintero.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="275" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Centro_Empresarial_Sabana_Grande_y_Mc_Donald%27s_Vicente_Quintero.jpg/330px-Centro_Empresarial_Sabana_Grande_y_Mc_Donald%27s_Vicente_Quintero.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Centro_Empresarial_Sabana_Grande_y_Mc_Donald%27s_Vicente_Quintero.jpg/440px-Centro_Empresarial_Sabana_Grande_y_Mc_Donald%27s_Vicente_Quintero.jpg 2x" data-file-width="864" data-file-height="1080"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Centro_Empresarial_Sabana_Grande_y_Mc_Donald%27s_Vicente_Quintero.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Business Center <a href="/wiki/Sabana_Grande,_Caracas" title="Sabana Grande, Caracas">Sabana Grande</a> (2018), headquarters of <a href="/wiki/Petrocaribe" title="Petrocaribe">Petrocaribe</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The recovery of oil prices after 2001 boosted the Venezuelan economy and facilitated social spending. With social programs such as the <a href="/wiki/Bolivarian_Missions" class="mw-redirect" title="Bolivarian Missions">Bolivarian Missions</a>, Venezuela initially made progress in social development in the 2000s, particularly in areas such as health, education, and poverty. Many of the social policies pursued by Chávez and his administration were jump-started by the <a href="/wiki/Millennium_Development_Goals" title="Millennium Development Goals">Millennium Development Goals</a>, eight goals that Venezuela and 188 other nations agreed to in September 2000.<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">[262]</a></sup> The sustainability of the Bolivarian Missions has been questioned due to the Bolivarian state's overspending on public works and because the Chávez government did not save funds for future economic hardships like other OPEC nations; with economic issues and poverty rising as a result of their policies in the 2010s.<sup id="cite_ref-ELPAISfeb2015_23-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ELPAISfeb2015-23">[21]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CSM25march_265-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CSM25march-265">[263]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FPdontblame_266-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FPdontblame-266">[264]</a></sup> In 2003 the government of Hugo Chávez implemented currency controls after capital flight led to a devaluation of the currency. This led to the development of a parallel market of dollars in the subsequent years. The fallout of the <a href="/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007%E2%80%932010" class="mw-redirect" title="Financial crisis of 2007–2010">2008 global financial crisis</a> saw a renewed economic downturn. Despite controversial data shared by the Venezuelan government showing that the country had halved malnutrition following one of the UN's Millennium Development Goals,<sup id="cite_ref-ECONeatCHAVISMO_115-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ECONeatCHAVISMO-115">[113]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">[265]</a></sup> shortages of staple goods began to occur in Venezuela and malnutrition began to increase.<sup id="cite_ref-ECONeatCHAVISMO_115-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ECONeatCHAVISMO-115">[113]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In early 2013, Venezuela devalued its currency due to growing shortages in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">[266]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">[267]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[268]</a></sup> The shortages included, and still include, necessities such as toilet paper, milk, and flour.<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">[269]</a></sup> Fears rose so high due to the toilet paper shortage that the government occupied a toilet paper factory, and continued further plans to nationalize other industrial aspects like food distribution.<sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">[270]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">[271]</a></sup> Venezuela's bond ratings have also decreased multiple times in 2013 due to decisions by the president Nicolás Maduro. One of his decisions was to force stores and their warehouses to sell all of their products, which led to even more shortages in the future.<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">[272]</a></sup> In 2016, consumer prices in Venezuela increased 800% and the economy declined by 18.6%, entering an <a href="/wiki/Economic_depression" title="Economic depression">economic depression</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">[273]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">[274]</a></sup> Venezuela's outlook was deemed negative by most bond-rating services in 2017.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">[275]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">[276]</a></sup> For 2018 an inflation rate of 1,000,000 percent was projected, putting Venezuela in a similar situation to that in Germany in 1923 or Zimbabwe in the late 2000s.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">[277]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Venezuela" title="Tourism in Venezuela">Tourism in Venezuela</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Cayo_Nordisqui,_los_roques_archipelago_Venezuela_2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Cayo_Nordisqui%2C_los_roques_archipelago_Venezuela_2.jpg/220px-Cayo_Nordisqui%2C_los_roques_archipelago_Venezuela_2.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Cayo_Nordisqui%2C_los_roques_archipelago_Venezuela_2.jpg/330px-Cayo_Nordisqui%2C_los_roques_archipelago_Venezuela_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Cayo_Nordisqui%2C_los_roques_archipelago_Venezuela_2.jpg/440px-Cayo_Nordisqui%2C_los_roques_archipelago_Venezuela_2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1080" data-file-height="810"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Cayo_Nordisqui,_los_roques_archipelago_Venezuela_2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Los Roques Archipelago
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Tourism has been developed considerably in recent decades, particularly because of its favorable geographical position, the variety of landscapes, the richness of plant and <a href="/wiki/Wildlife" title="Wildlife">wildlife</a>, the artistic expressions and the privileged tropical climate of the country, which affords each region (especially the beaches) throughout the year. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Margarita_Island" title="Margarita Island">Margarita Island</a> is one of the top tourist destinations for enjoyment and relaxation. It is an island with a modern infrastructure, bordered by beautiful beaches suitable for extreme sports, and features castles, fortresses and churches of great cultural value. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Los_Roques_Archipelago" class="mw-redirect" title="Los Roques Archipelago">Los Roques Archipelago</a> is made up of a set of islands and keys that constitute one of the main tourist attractions in the country. With exotic crystalline beaches, Morrocoy is a national park, formed by small keys very close to the mainland, which have grown rapidly as one of the greatest tourist attractions in the Venezuelan Caribbean.<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">[278]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Canaima_National_Park" title="Canaima National Park">Canaima National Park</a><sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">[279]</a></sup> extends over 30,000&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> to the border with Guyana and Brazil, due to its size it is considered the sixth largest national park in the world. About 65% of the park is occupied by rock plateaus called tepuis. These constitute a unique biological environment, also presenting great geological interest. Its steep cliffs and waterfalls (including Angel Falls, which is the highest waterfall in the world, at 1,002 m) form spectacular landscapes. </p>
      <p>The state of <a href="/wiki/M%C3%A9rida_(state)" title="Mérida (state)">Mérida</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282">[280]</a></sup> for the beauty of its Andean landscapes and its pleasant climate, is one of the main tourist centers of Venezuela. It has an extensive network of hotels not only in its capital city, but also throughout the state. Starting from the same city of Mérida, is the longest and highest cable car in the world, which reaches the Pico Espejo of 4,765 m. It is also necessary to recommend to travel through magnificent roads, the southern moors, where you can find good hotels and restaurants. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Shortages">Shortages</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Shortages_in_Venezuela" title="Shortages in Venezuela">Shortages in Venezuela</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Escasez_en_Venezuela,_Central_Madeirense_8.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Escasez_en_Venezuela%2C_Central_Madeirense_8.JPG/220px-Escasez_en_Venezuela%2C_Central_Madeirense_8.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Escasez_en_Venezuela%2C_Central_Madeirense_8.JPG/330px-Escasez_en_Venezuela%2C_Central_Madeirense_8.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Escasez_en_Venezuela%2C_Central_Madeirense_8.JPG/440px-Escasez_en_Venezuela%2C_Central_Madeirense_8.JPG 2x" data-file-width="4288" data-file-height="3216"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Escasez_en_Venezuela,_Central_Madeirense_8.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Empty shelves in a store in Venezuela due to shortages in 2014
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Shortages" class="mw-redirect" title="Shortages">Shortages</a> in Venezuela have been prevalent following the enactment of price controls and other policies during the <a href="/wiki/Economic_policy_of_the_Hugo_Ch%C3%A1vez_government" class="mw-redirect" title="Economic policy of the Hugo Chávez government">economic policy of the Hugo Chávez government</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-economist.com_283-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-economist.com-283">[281]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-qz.com_284-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-qz.com-284">[282]</a></sup> Under the <a href="/wiki/Economic_policy_of_the_Nicol%C3%A1s_Maduro_government" class="mw-redirect" title="Economic policy of the Nicolás Maduro government">economic policy of the Nicolás Maduro government</a>, greater shortages occurred due to the Venezuelan government's policy of withholding United States dollars from importers with price controls.<sup id="cite_ref-WSJseptDOWNGRADE_285-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WSJseptDOWNGRADE-285">[283]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Shortages occur in regulated products, such as milk, various types of meat, coffee, rice, oil, flour, butter, and other goods including basic necessities like toilet paper, personal hygiene products, and even medicine.<sup id="cite_ref-economist.com_283-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-economist.com-283">[281]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ACN_286-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ACN-286">[284]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-El_Nuevo_Herald_287-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-El_Nuevo_Herald-287">[285]</a></sup> As a result of the shortages, Venezuelans must search for food, wait in lines for hours and sometimes settle without having certain products.<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">[286]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-REUTjan2015_289-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-REUTjan2015-289">[287]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Venezuela" title="Government of Venezuela">Maduro's government</a> has blamed the shortages on "bourgeois criminals" hoarding goods.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">[288]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>A drought, combined with a lack of planning and maintenance, has caused a hydroelectricity shortage. To deal with lack of power supply, in April 2016 the Maduro government announced rolling blackouts<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">[289]</a></sup> and reduced the government <a href="/wiki/Workweek" class="mw-redirect" title="Workweek">workweek</a> to only Monday and Tuesday.<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">[290]</a></sup> A multi-university study found that, in 2016 alone, about 75% of Venezuelans lost weight due to hunger, with the average losing about 8.6&nbsp;kg (19&nbsp;lbs) due to the lack of food.<sup id="cite_ref-UPIfeb17_293-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UPIfeb17-293">[291]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>By late-2016 and into 2017, Venezuelans had to search for food on a daily basis, occasionally resorting to eating wild fruit or <a href="/wiki/Garbage" title="Garbage">garbage</a>, wait in lines for hours and sometimes settle without having certain products.<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">[292]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-REUTjan2015_289-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-REUTjan2015-289">[287]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">[293]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">[294]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">[295]</a></sup> By early 2017, priests began telling Venezuelans to label their garbage so needy individuals could feed on their refuse.<sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">[296]</a></sup> In March 2017, Venezuela, with the largest oil reserves in the world, began having shortages of gasoline in some regions with reports that fuel imports had begun.<sup id="cite_ref-EImar17_299-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EImar17-299">[297]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Petroleum_and_other_resources">Petroleum and other resources</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Venezuelan_oil_industry" title="History of the Venezuelan oil industry">History of the Venezuelan oil industry</a> and <a href="/wiki/Energy_policy_of_Venezuela" title="Energy policy of Venezuela">Energy policy of Venezuela</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:EEPPHOTO1.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/EEPPHOTO1.png/300px-EEPPHOTO1.png" decoding="async" width="300" height="212" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/EEPPHOTO1.png/450px-EEPPHOTO1.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/EEPPHOTO1.png/600px-EEPPHOTO1.png 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="564"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:EEPPHOTO1.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Figure depicting Venezuelan oil exports and the interdependence between the U.S. and Venezuela<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">[298]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Venezuela has the largest oil reserves, and the eighth largest natural gas reserves in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">[299]</a></sup> Compared to the preceding year another 40.4% in crude oil reserves were proven in 2010, allowing Venezuela to surpass Saudi Arabia as the country with the largest reserves of this type.<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">[300]</a></sup> The country's main petroleum deposits are located around and beneath Lake Maracaibo, the Gulf of Venezuela (both in <a href="/wiki/Zulia_State" class="mw-redirect" title="Zulia State">Zulia</a>), and in the Orinoco River basin (<a href="/wiki/Orinoco#Eastern_Venezuelan_Basin" title="Orinoco">eastern Venezuela</a>), where the country's largest reserve is located. Besides the largest conventional oil reserves and the second-largest natural gas reserves in the Western Hemisphere,<sup id="cite_ref-bbc_303-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-303">[301]</a></sup> Venezuela has non-conventional oil deposits (<a href="/wiki/Heavy_crude_oil" title="Heavy crude oil">extra-heavy crude oil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bitumen" class="mw-redirect" title="Bitumen">bitumen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tar_sands" class="mw-redirect" title="Tar sands">tar sands</a>) approximately equal to the world's reserves of conventional oil.<sup id="cite_ref-wec_304-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wec-304">[302]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Electricity_sector_in_Venezuela" title="Electricity sector in Venezuela">electricity sector in Venezuela</a> is one of the few to rely primarily on <a href="/wiki/Hydropower" title="Hydropower">hydropower</a>, and includes the Guri Dam, one of the largest in the world. </p>
      <p>In the first half of the 20th century, U.S. oil companies were heavily involved in Venezuela, initially interested only in purchasing concessions.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYergin1991233–236,_432_305-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYergin1991233–236,_432-305">[303]</a></sup> In 1943 a new government introduced a 50/50 split in profits between the government and the oil industry. In 1960, with a newly installed democratic government, Hydrocarbons Minister Juan Pablo Pérez Alfonso led the creation of OPEC, the consortium of oil-producing countries aiming to support the price of oil.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYergin1991510–513_306-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYergin1991510–513-306">[304]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Oil_Reserves_Updated.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Oil_Reserves_Updated.png/300px-Oil_Reserves_Updated.png" decoding="async" width="300" height="137" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Oil_Reserves_Updated.png/450px-Oil_Reserves_Updated.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Oil_Reserves_Updated.png/600px-Oil_Reserves_Updated.png 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="364"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Oil_Reserves_Updated.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A map of world <a href="/wiki/Oil_reserves" title="Oil reserves">oil reserves</a> according to OPEC, 2013. Venezuela has the world's largest oil reserves.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 1973, Venezuela voted to nationalize its oil industry outright, effective 1 January 1976, with <a href="/wiki/Petr%C3%B3leos_de_Venezuela" class="mw-redirect" title="Petróleos de Venezuela">Petróleos de Venezuela</a> (PDVSA) taking over and presiding over a number of holding companies; in subsequent years, Venezuela built a vast refining and marketing system in the U.S. and Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEYergin1991767_307-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEYergin1991767-307">[305]</a></sup> In the 1990s PDVSA became more independent from the government and presided over an <i>apertura</i> (opening) in which it invited in foreign investment. Under Hugo Chávez a 2001 law placed limits on foreign investment. </p>
      <p>The state oil company PDVSA played a key role in the December 2002 – February 2003 national strike which sought President Chávez' resignation. Managers and skilled highly paid technicians of PDVSA shut down the plants and left their posts, and by some reports sabotaged equipment, and petroleum production and refining by PDVSA almost ceased. Activities eventually were slowly restarted by returning and substitute oil workers. As a result of the strike, around 40% of the company's workforce (around 18,000 workers) were dismissed for "dereliction of duty" during the strike.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcCaughan2005128_308-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCaughan2005128-308">[306]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309">[307]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Venezuela" title="Transport in Venezuela">Transport in Venezuela</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Los_Jardines_(Caracas_metro).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Los_Jardines_%28Caracas_metro%29.jpg/220px-Los_Jardines_%28Caracas_metro%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Los_Jardines_%28Caracas_metro%29.jpg/330px-Los_Jardines_%28Caracas_metro%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Los_Jardines_%28Caracas_metro%29.jpg/440px-Los_Jardines_%28Caracas_metro%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2816" data-file-height="2112"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Los_Jardines_(Caracas_metro).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Caracas_Metro" title="Caracas Metro">Caracas Metro</a> in Los Jardines Station
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Venezuela is connected to the world primarily via air (<a href="/wiki/List_of_airports_in_Venezuela" title="List of airports in Venezuela">Venezuela's airports</a> include the <a href="/wiki/Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar_International_Airport_(Venezuela)" title="Simón Bolívar International Airport (Venezuela)">Simón Bolívar International Airport</a> in Maiquetía, near Caracas and <a href="/wiki/La_Chinita_International_Airport" title="La Chinita International Airport">La Chinita International Airport</a> near <a href="/wiki/Maracaibo" title="Maracaibo">Maracaibo</a>) and sea (with major sea ports at La Guaira, Maracaibo and <a href="/wiki/Puerto_Cabello" title="Puerto Cabello">Puerto Cabello</a>). In the south and east the Amazon rainforest region has limited cross-border transport; in the west, there is a mountainous border of over 2,213 kilometres (1,375&nbsp;mi) shared with Colombia. The <a href="/wiki/Orinoco" title="Orinoco">Orinoco</a> River is navigable by oceangoing vessels up to 400 kilometres (250&nbsp;mi) inland, and connects the major industrial city of Ciudad Guayana to the Atlantic Ocean. </p>
      <p>Venezuela has a limited <a href="/wiki/Instituto_de_Ferrocarriles_del_Estado" class="mw-redirect" title="Instituto de Ferrocarriles del Estado">national railway system</a>, which has no active rail connections to other countries. The government of Hugo Chávez tried to invest in expanding it, but Venezuela's rail project is on hold due to Venezuela not being able to pay the $7.5&nbsp;billion<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (April 2017)">clarification needed</span></a></i>]</sup> and owing <a href="/wiki/China_Railway" title="China Railway">China Railway</a> nearly $500&nbsp;million.<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">[308]</a></sup> Several major cities have metro systems; the Caracas Metro has been operating since 1983. The <a href="/wiki/Maracaibo_Metro" title="Maracaibo Metro">Maracaibo Metro</a> and <a href="/wiki/Valencia_Metro_(Venezuela)" title="Valencia Metro (Venezuela)">Valencia Metro</a> were opened more recently. Venezuela has a road network of nearly 100,000 kilometres (62,000&nbsp;mi) in length, placing the country <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_road_network_size" title="List of countries by road network size">around 45th in the world</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">[309]</a></sup> around a third of roads are paved. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Venezuela" title="Demographics of Venezuela">Demographics of Venezuela</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/List_of_metropolitan_areas_in_Venezuela" title="List of metropolitan areas in Venezuela">List of metropolitan areas in Venezuela</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Venezuelan_diaspora_map.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Venezuelan_diaspora_map.svg/300px-Venezuelan_diaspora_map.svg.png" decoding="async" width="300" height="132" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Venezuelan_diaspora_map.svg/450px-Venezuelan_diaspora_map.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Venezuelan_diaspora_map.svg/600px-Venezuelan_diaspora_map.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="914" data-file-height="403"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Venezuelan_diaspora_map.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Venezuelans in the world
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Venezuela is among the most urbanized countries in Latin America;<sup id="cite_ref-encartaSA_16-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-encartaSA-16">[14]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-UNpopstats_17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UNpopstats-17">[15]</a></sup> the vast majority of Venezuelans live in the cities of the north, especially in the capital Caracas, which is also the largest city. About 93% of the population lives in urban areas in northern Venezuela; 73% live less than 100 kilometres (62&nbsp;mi) from the coastline.<sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">[310]</a></sup> Though almost half of Venezuela's land area lies south of the Orinoco, only 5% of Venezuelans live there. The largest and most important city south of the Orinoco is <a href="/wiki/Ciudad_Guayana" title="Ciudad Guayana">Ciudad Guayana</a>, which is the sixth most populous <a href="/wiki/Conurbation" title="Conurbation">conurbation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">[311]</a></sup> Other major cities include <a href="/wiki/Barquisimeto" title="Barquisimeto">Barquisimeto</a>, <a href="/wiki/Valencia,_Carabobo" title="Valencia, Carabobo">Valencia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maracay" title="Maracay">Maracay</a>, Maracaibo, <a href="/wiki/Barcelona-Puerto_La_Cruz" title="Barcelona-Puerto La Cruz">Barcelona-Puerto La Cruz</a>, <a href="/wiki/M%C3%A9rida,_M%C3%A9rida" title="Mérida, Mérida">Mérida</a> and <a href="/wiki/San_Crist%C3%B3bal,_T%C3%A1chira" title="San Cristóbal, Táchira">San Cristóbal</a>. </p>
      <p>According to a 2014 study by sociologists of the <a href="/wiki/Central_University_of_Venezuela" title="Central University of Venezuela">Central University of Venezuela</a>, over 1.5&nbsp;million Venezuelans, or about 4% to 6% of the country's population, have left Venezuela since 1999 following the Bolivarian Revolution.<sup id="cite_ref-ENHaug28_314-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ENHaug28-314">[312]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Elimpulso23AUG_315-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Elimpulso23AUG-315">[313]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnic_groups">Ethnic groups</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Venezuelan_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Venezuelan people">Venezuelan people</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mestizo_Venezuelan" class="mw-redirect" title="Mestizo Venezuelan">Mestizo Venezuelan</a>, <a href="/wiki/White_Venezuelan" class="mw-redirect" title="White Venezuelan">White Venezuelan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Afro-Venezuelan" class="mw-redirect" title="Afro-Venezuelan">Afro-Venezuelan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italo-Venezuelan" class="mw-redirect" title="Italo-Venezuelan">Italo-Venezuelan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Venezuelan" class="mw-redirect" title="Portuguese Venezuelan">Portuguese Venezuelan</a>, <a href="/wiki/German_Venezuelan" class="mw-redirect" title="German Venezuelan">German Venezuelan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arab_Venezuelan" class="mw-redirect" title="Arab Venezuelan">Arab Venezuelan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Chinese_Venezuelan" class="mw-redirect" title="Chinese Venezuelan">Chinese Venezuelan</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="barbox tleft" style="overflow-x: auto;"> 
       <div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:auto; background: white;"> 
        <table style="text-align:left; border-collapse:collapse; width:100%;"> 
         <tbody>
          <tr style="background:none">
           <th style="text-align:center;" colspan="5">Racial and Ethnic Composition (2011 Census)<sup id="cite_ref-Census-ethnics_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Census-ethnics-1">[1]</a></sup></th>
          </tr> 
          <tr style="font-size:88%; height:4px;"> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding:0 4px; text-align:left;"><b>Race/Ethnicity</b></td> 
           <td style="width:100px; text-align:left;"></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding:0 4px; width:1em; text-align:right;"></td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Mestizos_in_Venezuela" class="mw-redirect" title="Mestizos in Venezuela">Mestizo</a></td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:violet; width:51.6%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">51.6%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Venezuelan_of_European_descent" class="mw-redirect" title="Venezuelan of European descent">White</a></td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:blue; width:43.6%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">43.6%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Afro-Venezuelan" class="mw-redirect" title="Afro-Venezuelan">Black</a></td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:Brown; width:2.9%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">2.9%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Afro-descendant</td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:Black; width:0.7%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">0.7%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;"><a href="/wiki/Venezuelan_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Venezuelan people">Other races</a></td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:red; width:1.2%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">1.2%</td> 
          </tr> 
         </tbody>
        </table> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>The people of Venezuela come from a variety of ancestries. It is estimated that the majority of the population is of <a href="/wiki/Mestizos_in_Venezuela" class="mw-redirect" title="Mestizos in Venezuela">mestizo</a>, or mixed, ethnic ancestry. Nevertheless, in the 2011 census, which Venezuelans were asked to identify themselves according to their customs and ancestry, the term <i>mestizo</i> was excluded from the answers. The majority claimed to be mestizo or <a href="/wiki/White_Venezuelan" class="mw-redirect" title="White Venezuelan">white</a>—51.6% and 43.6%, respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-Census-ethnics_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Census-ethnics-1">[1]</a></sup> Practically half of the population claimed to be <i><a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/moreno" class="extiw" title="wikt:moreno">moreno</a></i>, a term used throughout Ibero-America that in this case means "dark-skinned" or "brown-skinned", as opposed to having a <a href="/wiki/Light_skin" title="Light skin">lighter skin</a> (this term connotes <a href="/wiki/Human_skin_colour" class="mw-redirect" title="Human skin colour">skin color or tone</a>, rather than <a href="/wiki/Facial_feature" class="mw-redirect" title="Facial feature">facial features</a> or descent). </p>
      <p>Ethnic minorities in Venezuela consist of groups that descend mainly from African or indigenous peoples; 2.8% identified themselves as "black" and 0.7% as <i>afrodescendiente</i> (Afro-descendant), 2.6% claimed to belong to indigenous peoples, and 1.2% answered "other races".<sup id="cite_ref-Census-ethnics_1-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Census-ethnics-1">[1]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Among indigenous people, 58% were <a href="/wiki/Way%C3%BAu" class="mw-redirect" title="Wayúu">Wayúu</a>, 7% <a href="/wiki/Warao_people" title="Warao people">Warao</a>, 5% <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kari%C3%B1a&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kariña (page does not exist)">Kariña</a>, 4% <a href="/wiki/Pemon" title="Pemon">Pemón</a>, 3% <a href="/wiki/Piaroa" class="mw-redirect" title="Piaroa">Piaroa</a>, 3% <a href="/wiki/Jivi" class="mw-redirect" title="Jivi">Jivi</a>, 3% <a href="/wiki/A%C3%B1u" class="mw-redirect" title="Añu">Añu</a>, 3% <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cuman%C3%A1goto&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cumanágoto (page does not exist)">Cumanágoto</a>, 2% <a href="/wiki/Yukpa" class="mw-redirect" title="Yukpa">Yukpa</a>, 2% <a href="/wiki/Chaima" title="Chaima">Chaima</a> and 1% <a href="/wiki/Yanomami" title="Yanomami">Yanomami</a>; the remaining 9% consisted of other indigenous nations.<sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316">[314]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to an autosomal DNA genetic study conducted in 2008 by the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Bras%C3%ADlia" title="University of Brasília">University of Brasília</a> (UNB), the composition of Venezuela's population is 60.60% of European contribution, 23% of indigenous contribution, and 16.30% of African contribution.<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">[315]</a></sup> </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:392px;max-width:392px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:194px;max-width:194px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:159px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Venezuela_2011_Moreno_(Brown)_population_proportion_map.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Venezuela_2011_Moreno_%28Brown%29_population_proportion_map.png/192px-Venezuela_2011_Moreno_%28Brown%29_population_proportion_map.png" decoding="async" width="192" height="160" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Venezuela_2011_Moreno_%28Brown%29_population_proportion_map.png/288px-Venezuela_2011_Moreno_%28Brown%29_population_proportion_map.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Venezuela_2011_Moreno_%28Brown%29_population_proportion_map.png/384px-Venezuela_2011_Moreno_%28Brown%29_population_proportion_map.png 2x" data-file-width="4484" data-file-height="3729"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Mestizos_in_Venezuela" class="mw-redirect" title="Mestizos in Venezuela">Moreno (Mestizo)</a> population of Venezuela in 2011
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:194px;max-width:194px">
