           <a href="/wiki/File:Venezuela_2011_White_population_proportion_map.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Venezuela_2011_White_population_proportion_map.png/192px-Venezuela_2011_White_population_proportion_map.png" decoding="async" width="192" height="160" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Venezuela_2011_White_population_proportion_map.png/288px-Venezuela_2011_White_population_proportion_map.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Venezuela_2011_White_population_proportion_map.png/384px-Venezuela_2011_White_population_proportion_map.png 2x" data-file-width="4453" data-file-height="3708"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/White_Venezuelan" class="mw-redirect" title="White Venezuelan">White</a> population of Venezuela in 2011
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:195px;max-width:195px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:158px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Venezuela_2011_Ameridian_population_proportion_map.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Venezuela_2011_Ameridian_population_proportion_map.png/193px-Venezuela_2011_Ameridian_population_proportion_map.png" decoding="async" width="193" height="159" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Venezuela_2011_Ameridian_population_proportion_map.png/290px-Venezuela_2011_Ameridian_population_proportion_map.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Venezuela_2011_Ameridian_population_proportion_map.png/386px-Venezuela_2011_Ameridian_population_proportion_map.png 2x" data-file-width="4546" data-file-height="3750"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_in_Venezuela" title="Indigenous peoples in Venezuela">Amerindian</a> population of Venezuela in 2011
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:193px;max-width:193px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:158px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Venezuela_2011_Black_and_Afrodescendant_population_proportion_map.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Venezuela_2011_Black_and_Afrodescendant_population_proportion_map.png/191px-Venezuela_2011_Black_and_Afrodescendant_population_proportion_map.png" decoding="async" width="191" height="159" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Venezuela_2011_Black_and_Afrodescendant_population_proportion_map.png/287px-Venezuela_2011_Black_and_Afrodescendant_population_proportion_map.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/Venezuela_2011_Black_and_Afrodescendant_population_proportion_map.png/382px-Venezuela_2011_Black_and_Afrodescendant_population_proportion_map.png 2x" data-file-width="4431" data-file-height="3682"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Black_Venezuelan" class="mw-redirect" title="Black Venezuelan">Black and Afrodescendant</a> population of Venezuela in 2011
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>During the colonial period and until after the Second World War, many of the European immigrants to Venezuela came from the <a href="/wiki/Canary_Islands" title="Canary Islands">Canary Islands</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">[316]</a></sup> which had a significant cultural impact on the cuisine and customs of Venezuela.<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">[317]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">[318]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">[319]</a></sup> These influences on Venezuela have led to the nation being called the 8th island of the Canaries.<sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">[320]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323">[321]</a></sup> With the start of oil exploitation in the early 20th century, companies from the United States began establishing operations in Venezuela, bringing with them U.S. citizens. Later, during and after the war, new waves of immigrants from other parts of Europe, the Middle East, and China began; many were encouraged by government-established <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_Venezuela" title="Immigration to Venezuela">immigration programs</a> and lenient immigration policies.<sup id="cite_ref-Romero2010_324-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Romero2010-324">[322]</a></sup> During the 20th century, Venezuela, along with the rest of Latin America, received millions of immigrants from Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-Levinson1994_325-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Levinson1994-325">[323]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-PadillaPeixoto2007_326-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PadillaPeixoto2007-326">[324]</a></sup> This was especially true post-World War II, as a consequence of war-ridden Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-Levinson1994_325-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Levinson1994-325">[323]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-PadillaPeixoto2007_326-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PadillaPeixoto2007-326">[324]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Brooke1992_327-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brooke1992-327">[325]</a></sup> During the 1970s, while experiencing an oil-export boom, Venezuela received millions of immigrants from Ecuador, Colombia, and the Dominican Republic.<sup id="cite_ref-Brooke1992_327-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brooke1992-327">[325]</a></sup> Due to the belief that this immigration influx depressed wages, some Venezuelans opposed European immigration.<sup id="cite_ref-Brooke1992_327-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Brooke1992-327">[325]</a></sup> The Venezuelan government, however, were actively recruiting immigrants from Eastern Europe to fill a need for engineers.<sup id="cite_ref-Levinson1994_325-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Levinson1994-325">[323]</a></sup> Millions of Colombians, as well as Middle Eastern and Haitian populations would continue immigrating to Venezuela into the early 21st century.<sup id="cite_ref-Romero2010_324-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Romero2010-324">[322]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to the <i>World Refugee Survey 2008</i>, published by the U.S. Committee for Refugees and Immigrants, Venezuela hosted a population of <a href="/wiki/Refugee" title="Refugee">refugee</a> and asylum seekers from Colombia numbering 252,200 in 2007, and 10,600 new asylum seekers entered Venezuela in 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-World_Refugee_Survey_2008_328-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-World_Refugee_Survey_2008-328">[326]</a></sup> Between 500,000 and one million <a href="/wiki/Illegal_immigrant" class="mw-redirect" title="Illegal immigrant">illegal immigrants</a> are estimated to be living in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329">[327]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The total indigenous population of the country is estimated at about 500 thousand people (2.8% of the total), distributed among 40 indigenous peoples.<sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330">[328]</a></sup> There are three <a href="/wiki/Uncontacted_peoples" title="Uncontacted peoples">uncontacted tribes</a> living in Venezuela. The Constitution recognizes the multi-ethnic, pluri-cultural, and multilingual character of the country and includes a chapter devoted to indigenous peoples' rights, which opened up spaces for their political inclusion at national and local level in 1999. Most indigenous peoples are concentrated in eight states along Venezuela's borders with Brazil, Guyana, and Colombia, and the majority groups are the <a href="/wiki/Wayuu_people" title="Wayuu people">Wayuu (west)</a>, the Warao (east), the Yanomami (south), and the Pemon (southeast). </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Venezuela" title="Languages of Venezuela">Languages of Venezuela</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Although most residents are monolingual Spanish speakers, many languages are spoken in Venezuela. In addition to Spanish, the Constitution recognizes more than thirty indigenous languages, including Wayuu, Warao, Pemón, and many others for the official use of the indigenous peoples, mostly with few speakers – less than 1% of the total population. <a href="/wiki/Wayuu_language" title="Wayuu language">Wayuu</a> is the most spoken indigenous language with 170,000 speakers.<sup id="cite_ref-Ethnologue_331-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ethnologue-331">[329]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Immigrants, in addition to Spanish, speak their own languages. Chinese (400,000), <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_language" title="Portuguese language">Portuguese</a> (254,000),<sup id="cite_ref-Ethnologue_331-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Ethnologue-331">[329]</a></sup> and Italian (200,000)<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">[330]</a></sup> are the most spoken languages in Venezuela after the official language of Spanish. Arabic is spoken by Lebanese and Syrian colonies on Isla de Margarita, Maracaibo, Punto Fijo, Puerto la Cruz, El Tigre, Maracay, and Caracas. Portuguese is spoken not only by the Portuguese community in Santa Elena de Uairén but also by much of the population due to its proximity to Brazil.<sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333">[331]</a></sup> The German community speaks their native language, while the people of <a href="/wiki/Colonia_Tovar" title="Colonia Tovar">Colonia Tovar</a> speak mostly an <a href="/wiki/Alemannic_German" title="Alemannic German">Alemannic</a> dialect of German called <a href="/wiki/Colonia_Tovar_dialect" title="Colonia Tovar dialect"><i>alemán coloniero</i></a>. </p>
      <p>English is the most widely used foreign language in demand and is spoken by many professionals, academics, and members of the upper and middle classes as a result of the oil exploration done by foreign companies, in addition to its acceptance as a <a href="/wiki/Lingua_franca" title="Lingua franca">lingua franca</a>. Culturally, English is common in southern towns like <a href="/wiki/El_Callao_Municipality" title="El Callao Municipality">El Callao</a>, and the native English-speaking influence is evident in folk and calypso songs from the region. English was brought to Venezuela by <a href="/wiki/Trinidadian" class="mw-redirect" title="Trinidadian">Trinidadian</a> and other <a href="/wiki/British_West_Indies" title="British West Indies">British West Indies</a> immigrants.<sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334">[332]</a></sup> A variety of <a href="/wiki/Antillean_Creole" title="Antillean Creole">Antillean Creole</a> is spoken by a small community in El Callao and <a href="/wiki/Paria_Peninsula" title="Paria Peninsula">Paria</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335">[333]</a></sup> Italian language teaching is guaranteed by the presence of a consistent number of private Venezuelan schools and institutions, where Italian language courses and Italian literature are active. Other languages spoken by large communities in the country are <a href="/wiki/Basque_language" title="Basque language">Basque</a> and <a href="/wiki/Galician_language" title="Galician language">Galician</a>, among others. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Venezuela" title="Religion in Venezuela">Religion in Venezuela</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="PieChartTemplate thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px"> 
        <div style="background-color:white;margin:auto;position:relative;width:200px;height:200px;overflow:hidden;border-radius:100px;border:1px solid black"> 
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 1589.4544843865px; border-left-color:white"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:white"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:white"></div>
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 791.58150883059px; border-left-color:yellow"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:yellow"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:yellow"></div>
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 307.76835371753px; border-left-color:LightGray"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:LightGray"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:LightGray"></div>
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 106.48918403248px; border-left-color:DodgerBlue"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:DodgerBlue"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:DodgerBlue"></div>
         <div style="border:solid transparent;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;right:100px; top:100px; border-width:96.858316112863px 24.868988716485px 0 0; border-top-color:Blue"></div> 
         <div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Blue"></div> 
        </div> 
        <div class="thumbcaption"> 
         <p>Religion in Venezuela (2011)<sup id="cite_ref-grumilla_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-grumilla-2">[2]</a></sup> </p> 
         <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style>
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:Blue; color:white;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholicism">Catholic</a> (71%)
         </div>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:DodgerBlue; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Protestant" class="mw-redirect" title="Protestant">Protestant</a> (17%)
         </div>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:LightGray; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;Agnostic/<a href="/wiki/Atheist" class="mw-redirect" title="Atheist">Atheist</a> (7%)
         </div>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:yellow; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;Other religion (3%)
         </div>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:white; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;No answer (1%)
         </div> 
        </div> 
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>According to a 2011 poll (GIS XXI), 88% of the population is Christian, primarily <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholic">Roman Catholic</a> (71%), and the remaining 17% <a href="/wiki/Protestant" class="mw-redirect" title="Protestant">Protestant</a>, primarily <a href="/wiki/Evangelicals" class="mw-redirect" title="Evangelicals">Evangelicals</a> (in Latin America Protestants are usually called <i>"evangelicos"</i>). 8% of Venezuelans are irreligious (<a href="/wiki/Atheist" class="mw-redirect" title="Atheist">atheist</a> 2% and agnostic and 6% indifferent). Almost 3% of the population follow another religion (1% of these people practice <a href="/wiki/Santer%C3%ADa" title="Santería">Santería</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-grumilla_2-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-grumilla-2">[2]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There are small but influential <a href="/wiki/Muslim" class="mw-redirect" title="Muslim">Muslim</a>, <a href="/wiki/Druze" title="Druze">Druze</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Khalifa_2013_loc=6-7_336-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Khalifa_2013_loc=6-7-336">[334]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337">[335]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Buddhist" class="mw-redirect" title="Buddhist">Buddhist</a>, and Jewish communities. The Muslim community of more than 100,000 is concentrated among persons of <a href="/wiki/Lebanese_people" title="Lebanese people">Lebanese</a> and <a href="/wiki/Syrian_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Syrian people">Syrian</a> descent living in <a href="/wiki/Nueva_Esparta" title="Nueva Esparta">Nueva Esparta</a> State, <a href="/wiki/Punto_Fijo" title="Punto Fijo">Punto Fijo</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Caracas" title="Caracas">Caracas</a> area. The <a href="/wiki/Druze" title="Druze">Druze</a> community are estimated around 60,000 and concentrated among persons of <a href="/wiki/Lebanese_people" title="Lebanese people">Lebanese</a> and <a href="/wiki/Syrian_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Syrian people">Syrian</a> descent (a <a href="/wiki/Tareck_El_Aissami" title="Tareck El Aissami">former</a> <a href="/wiki/Vice_President_of_Venezuela" title="Vice President of Venezuela">vice president</a> is Druze, showing the small group's influence).<sup id="cite_ref-338" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-338">[336]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Khalifa_2013_loc=6-7_336-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Khalifa_2013_loc=6-7-336">[334]</a></sup> Buddhism in Venezuela is practiced by over 52,000 people. The Buddhist community is made up mainly of Chinese, Japanese, and Korean people. There are Buddhist centers in Caracas, Maracay, Mérida, Puerto Ordáz, San Felipe, and Valencia. </p>
      <p>The Jewish community has shrunk in recent years due to rising economic pressures and <a href="/wiki/Antisemitism_in_Venezuela" title="Antisemitism in Venezuela">antisemitism in Venezuela</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Hurricane_339-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hurricane-339">[337]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-SRI_340-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SRI-340">[338]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">[339]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342">[340]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343">[341]</a></sup> with the population declining from 22,000 in 1999<sup id="cite_ref-TOERaid_344-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TOERaid-344">[342]</a></sup> to less than 7,000 in 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-AJjan2015_345-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AJjan2015-345">[343]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Health_care_in_Venezuela" title="Health care in Venezuela">Health care in Venezuela</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mission_Barrio_Adentro" title="Mission Barrio Adentro">Mission Barrio Adentro</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft" style="">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px">
        <div class="thumbimage noresize" style="width:350px;"> 
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1017906329">
         <div class="mw-graph mw-graph-always mw-graph-nofallback" style="min-width:270px;min-height:190px" data-graph-id="50c411dfdee0f090cedf34195bd2196d9957fd4f"></div>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         Cases of malaria in Venezuela according to the Ministry of Popular Power for Health<sup id="cite_ref-boletinepid07-16_346-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-boletinepid07-16-346">[344]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft" style="">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px">
        <div class="thumbimage noresize" style="width:350px;"> 
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1017906329">
         <div class="mw-graph mw-graph-always mw-graph-nofallback" style="min-width:270px;min-height:120px" data-graph-id="c7590f59f573ba0cd0540d562af3ac623d7b45b9"></div>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         Deaths of children under one year in Venezuela according to the Ministry of Popular Power for Health<sup id="cite_ref-boletinepid07-16_346-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-boletinepid07-16-346">[344]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Venezuela has a national <a href="/wiki/Universal_health_care" title="Universal health care">universal health care</a> system. The current government has created a program to expand access to health care known as <a href="/wiki/Mission_Barrio_Adentro" title="Mission Barrio Adentro">Misión Barrio Adentro</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Venezuela_Information_Office_347-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Venezuela_Information_Office-347">[345]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348">[346]</a></sup> although its efficiency and work conditions have been criticized.<sup id="cite_ref-MBAeu_349-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MBAeu-349">[347]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-350" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-350">[348]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ABCnov2014_351-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ABCnov2014-351">[349]</a></sup> It has been reported that many Misión Barrio Adentro clinics have been closed, and (as of December 2014) it is estimated that 80% of Barrio Adentro establishments in Venezuela are abandoned.<sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352">[350]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-LPdec2014_353-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LPdec2014-353">[351]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Infant_mortality" title="Infant mortality">Infant mortality</a> in Venezuela was 19 deaths per 1,000 births for 2014 which was lower than the South American average (To compare: The U.S. figure was 6 deaths per 1,000 births in 2013 and the Canadian figure was 4.5 deaths per 1,000 live births).<sup id="cite_ref-The_World_Factbook_354-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_World_Factbook-354">[352]</a></sup> Child <a href="/wiki/Malnutrition" title="Malnutrition">malnutrition</a> (defined as stunting or wasting in children under the age of five) was 17%. <a href="/wiki/Delta_Amacuro" title="Delta Amacuro">Delta Amacuro</a> and <a href="/wiki/Amazonas_(Venezuelan_state)" title="Amazonas (Venezuelan state)">Amazonas</a> had the nation's highest rates.<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355">[353]</a></sup> According to the United Nations, 32% of Venezuelans lacked adequate sanitation, primarily those living in rural areas.<sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356">[354]</a></sup> Diseases ranging from <a href="/wiki/Diphtheria" title="Diphtheria">diphtheria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Plague_(disease)" title="Plague (disease)">plague</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malaria" title="Malaria">malaria</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Finnegan_234-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Finnegan-234">[232]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Typhoid" class="mw-redirect" title="Typhoid">typhoid</a> fever, <a href="/wiki/Yellow_fever" title="Yellow fever">yellow fever</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cholera" title="Cholera">cholera</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hepatitis_A" title="Hepatitis A">hepatitis A</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hepatitis_B" title="Hepatitis B">hepatitis B</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hepatitis_D" title="Hepatitis D">hepatitis D</a> were present in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-guardian1_357-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-guardian1-357">[355]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Obesity" title="Obesity">Obesity</a> was prevalent in approximately 30% of the adult population in Venezuela.<sup id="cite_ref-The_World_Factbook_354-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_World_Factbook-354">[352]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Venezuela had a total of 150 <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Venezuela" title="Water supply and sanitation in Venezuela">sewage treatment plants</a>; however, 13% of the population lacked access to drinking water, but this number had been dropping.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChávez_Frías2004_358-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChávez_Frías2004-358">[356]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>During the economic crisis observed under President Maduro's presidency, medical professionals were forced to perform outdated treatments on patients.<sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359">[357]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Venezuela" title="Education in Venezuela">Education in Venezuela</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Illiteracy_in_Venezuela.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Illiteracy_in_Venezuela.svg/220px-Illiteracy_in_Venezuela.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="181" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Illiteracy_in_Venezuela.svg/330px-Illiteracy_in_Venezuela.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Illiteracy_in_Venezuela.svg/440px-Illiteracy_in_Venezuela.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="443" data-file-height="365"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Illiteracy_in_Venezuela.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Illiteracy rate in Venezuela based on data from UNESCO<sup id="cite_ref-unesco1988_360-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unesco1988-360">[358]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-unesco-uis_361-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-unesco-uis-361">[359]</a></sup> and the Instituto Nacional de Estadística (INE) of Venezuela<sup id="cite_ref-ortega_362-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ortega-362">[360]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The literacy rate of the adult population was already at 91.1% by 1998.<sup id="cite_ref-363" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-363">[361]</a></sup> In 2008, 95.2% of the adult population was literate.<sup id="cite_ref-hdrstats.undp.org_364-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hdrstats.undp.org-364">[362]</a></sup> The net primary school enrollment rate was at 91% and the net secondary school enrollment rate was at 63% in 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-hdrstats.undp.org_364-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hdrstats.undp.org-364">[362]</a></sup> Venezuela has a number of universities, of which the most prestigious are the <a href="/wiki/Central_University_of_Venezuela" title="Central University of Venezuela">Central University of Venezuela</a> (UCV) founded in <a href="/wiki/Caracas" title="Caracas">Caracas</a> in 1721, the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Zulia" title="University of Zulia">University of Zulia</a> (LUZ) founded in 1891, the <a href="/wiki/University_of_the_Andes_(Venezuela)" title="University of the Andes (Venezuela)">University of the Andes</a> (ULA) founded in <a href="/wiki/M%C3%A9rida_(state)" title="Mérida (state)">Mérida State</a> in 1810, the <a href="/wiki/Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar_University_(Venezuela)" title="Simón Bolívar University (Venezuela)">Simón Bolívar University</a> (USB) founded in <a href="/wiki/Miranda_(state)" title="Miranda (state)">Miranda State</a> in 1967, and the <a href="/wiki/Universidad_de_Oriente" title="Universidad de Oriente">University of the East</a> (UDO) founded in <a href="/wiki/Sucre_(state)" title="Sucre (state)">Sucre State</a> in 1958. </p>
      <p>Currently, many Venezuelan graduates seek a future abroad because of the country's troubled economy and heavy crime rate. In a study titled "Venezolana Community Abroad: A New Method of Exile" by Thomas Páez, Mercedes Vivas, and Juan Rafael Pulido of the <a href="/wiki/Central_University_of_Venezuela" title="Central University of Venezuela">Central University of Venezuela</a>, over 1.35 million Venezuelan college graduates have left the country since the beginning of the <a href="/wiki/Bolivarian_Revolution" title="Bolivarian Revolution">Bolivarian Revolution</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ENHaug28_314-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ENHaug28-314">[312]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Elimpulso23AUG_315-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Elimpulso23AUG-315">[313]</a></sup> It is believed that nearly 12% of Venezuelans live abroad, with Ireland becoming a popular destination for students.<sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365">[363]</a></sup> According to Claudio Bifano, president of the Venezuelan Academy of Physical, Mathematical, and Natural Sciences, more than half of all medical graduates had left Venezuela in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366">[364]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>By 2018, over half of all Venezuelan children had <a href="/wiki/Dropped_out" class="mw-redirect" title="Dropped out">dropped out</a> of school, with 58% of students quitting nationwide while areas near bordering countries saw more than 80% of their students leave.<sup id="cite_ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367">[365]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:2_368-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-368">[366]</a></sup> Nationwide, about 93% of schools do not meet the minimum requirements to operate and 77% do not have utilities such as food, water or electricity.<sup id="cite_ref-:2_368-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-368">[366]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Venezuela" title="Culture of Venezuela">Culture of Venezuela</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Joropo_foto.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Joropo_foto.jpg/220px-Joropo_foto.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="211" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Joropo_foto.jpg/330px-Joropo_foto.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/5e/Joropo_foto.jpg 2x" data-file-width="365" data-file-height="350"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Joropo_foto.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <i>joropo</i>, as depicted in a 1912 drawing by <a href="/wiki/Eloy_Palacios" title="Eloy Palacios">Eloy Palacios</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The culture of Venezuela is a melting pot made up of three main groups: The Indigenous Venezuelans, the Africans, and the Spanish. The first two cultures were in turn differentiated according to their tribes. Acculturation and assimilation, typical of a cultural syncretism, led to the Venezuelan culture of the present day, which is similar in many ways to the culture of the rest of Latin America, but still has its own unique characteristics. </p>
      <p>The indigenous and African influence is limited to a few words, food names, and place names. However, the Africans also brought in many musical influences, especially introduction of the drum. The Spanish influence predominantes due to the colonization process and the socioeconomic structure it created, and in particular came from the regions of <a href="/wiki/Andalusia" title="Andalusia">Andalusia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Extremadura" title="Extremadura">Extremadura</a> (the places of origin of most of the settlers in the Caribbean during the colonial era). Spanish influences can be seen in the country's architecture, music, religion, and language. </p>
      <p>Spanish influences can also be seen in the bullfights that take place in Venezuela, and in certain gastronomical features. Venezuela was also enriched by immigration streams of Indian and European origin in the 19th century, especially from France. Most recently, immigration from the United States, Spain, Italy, and Portugal has further enriched the already complex cultural mosaic (especially in large oil-producing cities)<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Carlos_Ra%C3%BAl_Villanueva" title="Carlos Raúl Villanueva">Carlos Raúl Villanueva</a> was the most important Venezuelan architect of the modern era; he designed the Central University of Venezuela, (a <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Site</a>) and its Aula Magna. Other notable architectural works include the Capitolio, the <a href="/wiki/Baralt_Theatre" title="Baralt Theatre">Baralt Theatre</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Teresa_Carre%C3%B1o_Cultural_Complex" title="Teresa Carreño Cultural Complex">Teresa Carreño Cultural Complex</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/General_Rafael_Urdaneta_Bridge" title="General Rafael Urdaneta Bridge">General Rafael Urdaneta Bridge</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Art">Art</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Venezuelan_art" title="Venezuelan art">Venezuelan art</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Antonio_Herrera_Toro_Autoretrato_1880.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Antonio_Herrera_Toro_Autoretrato_1880.JPG/170px-Antonio_Herrera_Toro_Autoretrato_1880.JPG" decoding="async" width="170" height="214" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Antonio_Herrera_Toro_Autoretrato_1880.JPG/255px-Antonio_Herrera_Toro_Autoretrato_1880.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Antonio_Herrera_Toro_Autoretrato_1880.JPG/340px-Antonio_Herrera_Toro_Autoretrato_1880.JPG 2x" data-file-width="438" data-file-height="551"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Antonio_Herrera_Toro_Autoretrato_1880.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Antonio_Herrera_Toro" title="Antonio Herrera Toro">Antonio Herrera Toro</a>, self portrait 1880
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Venezuelan_art" title="Venezuelan art">Venezuelan art</a> was initially dominated by religious motifs. However, in the late 19th century, artists began emphasizing historical and heroic representations of the country's struggle for independence.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENg200431_369-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENg200431-369">[367]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAponte200845_370-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAponte200845-370">[368]</a></sup> This move was led by <a href="/wiki/Mart%C3%ADn_Tovar_y_Tovar" title="Martín Tovar y Tovar">Martín Tovar y Tovar</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAponte200845_370-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAponte200845-370">[368]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETarverFrederick200610_371-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETarverFrederick200610-371">[369]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Modernism" title="Modernism">Modernism</a> took over in the 20th century.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETarverFrederick200610_371-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETarverFrederick200610-371">[369]</a></sup> Notable <a href="/wiki/List_of_Venezuelan_artists" title="List of Venezuelan artists">Venezuelan artists</a> include <a href="/wiki/Arturo_Michelena" title="Arturo Michelena">Arturo Michelena</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crist%C3%B3bal_Rojas_(artist)" title="Cristóbal Rojas (artist)">Cristóbal Rojas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Armando_Rever%C3%B3n" title="Armando Reverón">Armando Reverón</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manuel_Cabr%C3%A9" title="Manuel Cabré">Manuel Cabré</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Kinetic_art" title="Kinetic art">kinetic artists</a> <a href="/wiki/Jes%C3%BAs-Rafael_Soto" class="mw-redirect" title="Jesús-Rafael Soto">Jesús Soto</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gego" title="Gego">Gego</a> and <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Cruz-Diez" title="Carlos Cruz-Diez">Carlos Cruz-Diez</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETarverFrederick200610_371-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETarverFrederick200610-371">[369]</a></sup> and contemporary artists such as <a href="/wiki/Marisol_Escobar" title="Marisol Escobar">Marisol</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yucef_Merhi" title="Yucef Merhi">Yucef Merhi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFichner-Ratus2012519_372-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFichner-Ratus2012519-372">[370]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373">[371]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Venezuelan_literature" title="Venezuelan literature">Venezuelan literature</a>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Venezuelan_literature" title="Venezuelan literature">Venezuelan literature</a> originated soon after the Spanish conquest of the mostly pre-literate indigenous societies.<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">[372]</a></sup> It was originally dominated by <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Spain" title="Culture of Spain">Spanish influences</a>. Following the rise of political literature during the Venezuelan War of Independence, Venezuelan <a href="/wiki/Romanticism" title="Romanticism">Romanticism</a>, notably expounded by Juan Vicente González, emerged as the first important genre in the region. Although mainly focused on narrative writing, Venezuelan literature was advanced by poets such as <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9s_Eloy_Blanco" title="Andrés Eloy Blanco">Andrés Eloy Blanco</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ferm%C3%ADn_Toro" title="Fermín Toro">Fermín Toro</a>. </p>
      <p>Major writers and novelists include <a href="/wiki/R%C3%B3mulo_Gallegos" title="Rómulo Gallegos">Rómulo Gallegos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Teresa_de_la_Parra" title="Teresa de la Parra">Teresa de la Parra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arturo_Uslar_Pietri" title="Arturo Uslar Pietri">Arturo Uslar Pietri</a>, <a href="/wiki/Adriano_Gonz%C3%A1lez_Le%C3%B3n" title="Adriano González León">Adriano González León</a>, <a href="/wiki/Miguel_Otero_Silva" title="Miguel Otero Silva">Miguel Otero Silva</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mariano_Pic%C3%B3n_Salas" title="Mariano Picón Salas">Mariano Picón Salas</a>. The great poet and humanist <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9s_Bello" title="Andrés Bello">Andrés Bello</a> was also an educator and intellectual (He was also a childhood tutor and mentor of <a href="/wiki/Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar" title="Simón Bolívar">Simón Bolívar</a>). Others, such as <a href="/wiki/Laureano_Vallenilla_Lanz" title="Laureano Vallenilla Lanz">Laureano Vallenilla Lanz</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Gil_Fortoul" title="José Gil Fortoul">José Gil Fortoul</a>, contributed to Venezuelan <a href="/wiki/Positivism" title="Positivism">Positivism</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Venezuela" title="Music of Venezuela">Music of Venezuela</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:2952-Danzas_Guanaguanare_de_Venezuela_no_Festival_folclorico_da_Coru%C3%B1a._(8200095256).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/2952-Danzas_Guanaguanare_de_Venezuela_no_Festival_folclorico_da_Coru%C3%B1a._%288200095256%29.jpg/220px-2952-Danzas_Guanaguanare_de_Venezuela_no_Festival_folclorico_da_Coru%C3%B1a._%288200095256%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="173" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/2952-Danzas_Guanaguanare_de_Venezuela_no_Festival_folclorico_da_Coru%C3%B1a._%288200095256%29.jpg/330px-2952-Danzas_Guanaguanare_de_Venezuela_no_Festival_folclorico_da_Coru%C3%B1a._%288200095256%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/2952-Danzas_Guanaguanare_de_Venezuela_no_Festival_folclorico_da_Coru%C3%B1a._%288200095256%29.jpg/440px-2952-Danzas_Guanaguanare_de_Venezuela_no_Festival_folclorico_da_Coru%C3%B1a._%288200095256%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1824" data-file-height="1432"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:2952-Danzas_Guanaguanare_de_Venezuela_no_Festival_folclorico_da_Coru%C3%B1a._(8200095256).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The Guanaguanare dance, a popular dance in <a href="/wiki/Portuguesa_(state)" title="Portuguesa (state)">Portuguesa State</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The indigenous musical styles of Venezuela are exemplified by groups like Un Sólo Pueblo and <a href="/wiki/Serenata_Guayanesa" title="Serenata Guayanesa">Serenata Guayanesa</a>. The national musical instrument is the <a href="/wiki/Cuatro_(Venezuela)" title="Cuatro (Venezuela)">cuatro</a>. Traditional musical styles and songs mainly emerged in and around the <i>llanos</i> region, including, "Alma llanera" (by <a href="/wiki/Pedro_El%C3%ADas_Guti%C3%A9rrez" title="Pedro Elías Gutiérrez">Pedro Elías Gutiérrez</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rafael_Bol%C3%ADvar_Coronado" title="Rafael Bolívar Coronado">Rafael Bolívar Coronado</a>), "Florentino y el diablo" (by <a href="/wiki/Alberto_Arvelo_Torrealba" title="Alberto Arvelo Torrealba">Alberto Arvelo Torrealba</a>), "Concierto en la llanura" by <a href="/wiki/Juan_Vicente_Torrealba" title="Juan Vicente Torrealba">Juan Vicente Torrealba</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Caballo_Viejo" title="Caballo Viejo">"Caballo viejo"</a> (by <a href="/wiki/Sim%C3%B3n_D%C3%ADaz" title="Simón Díaz">Simón Díaz</a>). </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Gaita_zuliana" title="Gaita zuliana">Zulian gaita</a> is also a very popular genre, generally performed during Christmas. The national dance is the <a href="/wiki/Joropo" title="Joropo">joropo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECortés20132134_375-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECortés20132134-375">[373]</a></sup> Venezuela has always been a melting pot of cultures and this can be seen in the richness and variety of its musical styles and dances: <a href="/wiki/Calypso_music" title="Calypso music">calipso</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bambuco" title="Bambuco">bambuco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ful%C3%ADa" title="Fulía">fulía</a>, cantos de pilado de maíz, cantos de lavanderas, sebucán, and maremare.<sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376">[374]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Teresa_Carre%C3%B1o" title="Teresa Carreño">Teresa Carreño</a> was a world-famous 19th century piano virtuoso. Recently, great classical music performances have come out of Venezuela. The <a href="/wiki/Sim%C3%B3n_Bol%C3%ADvar_Youth_Orchestra" class="mw-redirect" title="Simón Bolívar Youth Orchestra">Simón Bolívar Youth Orchestra</a>, under the leadership of its principal conductor <a href="/wiki/Gustavo_Dudamel" title="Gustavo Dudamel">Gustavo Dudamel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Antonio_Abreu" title="José Antonio Abreu">José Antonio Abreu</a>, has hosted a number of excellent concerts in many European concert halls, most notably at the 2007 London <a href="/wiki/The_Proms" title="The Proms">Proms</a>, and has received several honors. The orchestra is the pinnacle of <a href="/wiki/El_Sistema" title="El Sistema">El Sistema</a>, a publicly financed, voluntary music education program now being emulated in other countries. </p>
      <p>In the early 21st century, a movement known as "Movida Acústica Urbana" featured musicians trying to save some national traditions, creating their own original songs but using traditional instruments.<sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">[375]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-378" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-378">[376]</a></sup> Some groups following this movement are Tambor Urbano,<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">[377]</a></sup> Los Sinverguenzas, C4Trío, and Orozco Jam.<sup id="cite_ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380">[378]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Afro-Venezuelan musical traditions are most intimately related to the festivals of the "black folk saints" San Juan and <a href="/wiki/Benedict_the_Moor" title="Benedict the Moor">St. Benedict the Moor</a>. Specific songs are related to the different stages of their festivals and processions, when the saints start their yearly "<i>paseo"</i> – stroll – through the community to dance with their people. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sport">Sport</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Venezuela" title="Sport in Venezuela">Sport in Venezuela</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Baseball_in_Venezuela" title="Baseball in Venezuela">Baseball in Venezuela</a> and <a href="/wiki/Football_in_Venezuela" title="Football in Venezuela">Football in Venezuela</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Venezuela_national_baseball_team_on_November_7,_2015.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Venezuela_national_baseball_team_on_November_7%2C_2015.jpg/220px-Venezuela_national_baseball_team_on_November_7%2C_2015.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="148" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Venezuela_national_baseball_team_on_November_7%2C_2015.jpg/330px-Venezuela_national_baseball_team_on_November_7%2C_2015.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Venezuela_national_baseball_team_on_November_7%2C_2015.jpg/440px-Venezuela_national_baseball_team_on_November_7%2C_2015.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2600" data-file-height="1750"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Venezuela_national_baseball_team_on_November_7,_2015.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Venezuela_national_baseball_team" title="Venezuela national baseball team">Venezuela national baseball team</a> in 2015
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The origins of baseball in Venezuela are unclear, although it is known that the sport was being played in the country by the late 19th century.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENicholsMorse2010306_381-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENicholsMorse2010306-381">[379]</a></sup> In the early 20th century, North American immigrants who came to Venezuela to work in the nation's oil industry helped to popularize the sport in Venezuela.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWardrope200337_382-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWardrope200337-382">[380]</a></sup> During the 1930s, baseball's popularity continued to rise in the country, leading to the foundation of the <a href="/wiki/Venezuelan_Professional_Baseball_League" title="Venezuelan Professional Baseball League">Venezuelan Professional Baseball League</a> (LVBP) in 1945, and the sport would soon become the nation's most popular.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJozsa_Jr.201312_383-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJozsa_Jr.201312-383">[381]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGibson200618_384-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGibson200618-384">[382]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The immense popularity of baseball in the country makes Venezuela a rarity among its South American neighbors—association football is the dominant sport in the continent.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWardrope200337_382-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWardrope200337-382">[380]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGibson200618_384-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGibson200618-384">[382]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENicholsMorse2010307_385-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENicholsMorse2010307-385">[383]</a></sup> However, football, as well as <a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">basketball</a>, are among the more popular sports played in Venezuela.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAalgaard200454_386-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAalgaard200454-386">[384]</a></sup> Venezuela hosted the <a href="/wiki/2012_FIBA_World_Olympic_Qualifying_Tournament_for_Men" title="2012 FIBA World Olympic Qualifying Tournament for Men">2012 Basketball World Olympic Qualifying Tournament</a> and the <a href="/wiki/FIBA_Americas_Championship" class="mw-redirect" title="FIBA Americas Championship">2013 FIBA Basketball Americas Championship</a>, which took place in the <a href="/wiki/Poliedro_de_Caracas" title="Poliedro de Caracas">Poliedro de Caracas</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Venezuela-guinea_cropped.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Venezuela-guinea_cropped.jpg/220px-Venezuela-guinea_cropped.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="123" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Venezuela-guinea_cropped.jpg/330px-Venezuela-guinea_cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Venezuela-guinea_cropped.jpg/440px-Venezuela-guinea_cropped.jpg 2x" data-file-width="770" data-file-height="429"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Venezuela-guinea_cropped.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Venezuela_national_football_team" title="Venezuela national football team">Venezuela national football team</a>, popularly known as the "Vinotinto"
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Although not as popular in Venezuela as the rest of South America, football, spearheaded by the <a href="/wiki/Venezuela_national_football_team" title="Venezuela national football team">Venezuela national football team</a> is gaining popularity as well. The sport is also noted for having an increased focus during the World Cup.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAalgaard200454_386-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAalgaard200454-386">[384]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/CONMEBOL" title="CONMEBOL">CONMEBOL</a> alphabetical rotation policy established in 2011, Venezuela is scheduled to host the <a href="/wiki/Copa_Am%C3%A9rica" title="Copa América">Copa América</a> every 40 years.<sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387">[385]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Venezuela is also home to former <a href="/wiki/Formula_1" class="mw-redirect" title="Formula 1">Formula 1</a> driver, <a href="/wiki/Pastor_Maldonado" title="Pastor Maldonado">Pastor Maldonado</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Strickland2015_388-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Strickland2015-388">[386]</a></sup> At the <a href="/wiki/2012_Spanish_Grand_Prix" title="2012 Spanish Grand Prix">2012 Spanish Grand Prix</a>, he claimed his first pole and victory, and became the first and only Venezuelan to have done so in Formula 1 history.<sup id="cite_ref-Strickland2015_388-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Strickland2015-388">[386]</a></sup> Maldonado has increased the reception of Formula 1 in Venezuela, helping to popularize the sport in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389">[387]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics" title="2012 Summer Olympics">2012 Summer Olympics</a>, Venezuelan <a href="/wiki/Rub%C3%A9n_Limardo" title="Rubén Limardo">Rubén Limardo</a> won a gold medal in <a href="/wiki/Fencing_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics" title="Fencing at the 2012 Summer Olympics">fencing</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390">[388]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Venezuelan_cuisine" title="Venezuelan cuisine">Venezuelan cuisine</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="excerpt-block">
       <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r952607947">.mw-parser-output .excerpt .selflink{font-weight:normal}.mw-parser-output .excerpt-indicator{border-left:3px solid #c8ccd1;margin:1em 0;padding-left:1em}</style>
       <div class="excerpt"> <a href="/wiki/Venezuelan_cuisine" title="Venezuelan cuisine">Venezuelan cuisine</a> is influenced by its European (<a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spain" title="Spain">Spanish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Portugal" title="Portugal">Portuguese</a>, and <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">French</a>), West African, and Native American traditions. Venezuelan cuisine varies greatly from one region to another. <a href="/wiki/Food_staple" class="mw-redirect" title="Food staple">Food staples</a> include <a href="/wiki/Maize" title="Maize">corn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rice" title="Rice">rice</a>, <a href="/wiki/Plantain_(cooking)" class="mw-redirect" title="Plantain (cooking)">plantains</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yam_(vegetable)" title="Yam (vegetable)">yams</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bean" title="Bean">beans</a> and several meats. Potatoes, tomatoes, <a href="/wiki/Onion" title="Onion">onions</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eggplant" title="Eggplant">eggplants</a>, <a href="/wiki/Squash_(plant)" class="mw-redirect" title="Squash (plant)">squashes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spinach" title="Spinach">spinach</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zucchini" title="Zucchini">zucchini</a> are also common sides in the Venezuelan diet. <a href="/wiki/Aj%C3%AD_dulce" title="Ají dulce">Ají dulce</a> and <a href="/wiki/Papel%C3%B3n" class="mw-redirect" title="Papelón">papelón</a> are found in most recipes. <a href="/wiki/Worcestershire_sauce" title="Worcestershire sauce">Worcestershire sauce</a> is also used a frequently in stews. Venezuela is also characterized for having large variety of white cheese (<a href="/wiki/Queso_blanco" title="Queso blanco">queso blanco</a>), usually name by geographical region.
       </div>
      </div> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r936637989">.mw-parser-output .portal{border:solid #aaa 1px;padding:0}.mw-parser-output .portal.tleft{margin:0.5em 1em 0.5em 0}.mw-parser-output .portal.tright{margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul{display:table;box-sizing:border-box;padding:0.1em;max-width:175px;background:#f9f9f9;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li{display:table-row}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li>span:first-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .portal>ul>li>span:last-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle}</style>
      <div role="navigation" aria-label="Portals" class="noprint portal plainlist tright"> 
       <ul> 
        <li><span><img alt="flag" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Flag_of_Venezuela.svg/32px-Flag_of_Venezuela.svg.png" decoding="async" width="32" height="21" class="noviewer thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Flag_of_Venezuela.svg/48px-Flag_of_Venezuela.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Flag_of_Venezuela.svg/64px-Flag_of_Venezuela.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="600"></span><span><a href="/wiki/Portal:Venezuela" title="Portal:Venezuela">Venezuela portal</a></span></li> 
        <li><span><img alt="map" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Latin_America_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/28px-Latin_America_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png" decoding="async" width="28" height="28" class="noviewer" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Latin_America_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/42px-Latin_America_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Latin_America_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg/56px-Latin_America_%28orthographic_projection%29.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="550" data-file-height="550"></span><span><a href="/wiki/Portal:Latin_America" title="Portal:Latin America">Latin America portal</a></span></li>
       </ul>
      </div> 
      <ul>
       <li><a href="/wiki/Index_of_Venezuela-related_articles" title="Index of Venezuela-related articles">Index of Venezuela-related articles</a></li> 
       <li><a href="/wiki/Outline_of_Venezuela" title="Outline of Venezuela">Outline of Venezuela</a></li>
      </ul> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style>
      <div class="reflist"> 
       <div class="mw-references-wrap">
        <ol class="references"> 
         <li id="cite_note-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-4">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Recognized as president by the <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_(Venezuela)" title="National Assembly (Venezuela)">National Assembly</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Tribunal_of_Justice_(Venezuela)" title="Supreme Tribunal of Justice (Venezuela)">Supreme Tribunal of Justice</a>, the <a href="/wiki/National_Electoral_Council_(Venezuela)" title="National Electoral Council (Venezuela)">National Electoral Council</a>, <a href="/wiki/National_Bolivarian_Armed_Forces_of_Venezuela" title="National Bolivarian Armed Forces of Venezuela">National Bolivarian Armed Forces</a> and the United Nations.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-5">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Recognized as president by the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Tribunal_of_Justice_of_Venezuela_in_exile" title="Supreme Tribunal of Justice of Venezuela in exile">Supreme Tribunal in Exile</a>.</span> </li> 
        </ol>
       </div>
      </div>

         <li id="cite_note-imf2-11"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-imf2_11-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-imf2_11-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-imf2_11-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-19"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-19">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFSmilde2017" class="citation journal cs1">Smilde, David (14 September 2017). "Crime and Revolution in Venezuela". <i><a href="/wiki/NACLA_Report_on_the_Americas" title="NACLA Report on the Americas">NACLA Report on the Americas</a></i>. <b>49</b> (3): 303–308. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1080%2F10714839.2017.1373956">10.1080/10714839.2017.1373956</a>. <a href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a>&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/1071-4839">1071-4839</a>. <a href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a>&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:158528940">158528940</a>. <q>Finally, it is important to realize that the reductions in poverty and inequality during the Chávez years were real, but somewhat superficial. While indicators of income and consumption showed clear progress, the harder-to-change characteristics of structural poverty and inequality, such as the quality of housing, neighborhoods, education, and employment, remained largely unchanged.</q></cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=NACLA+Report+on+the+Americas&amp;rft.atitle=Crime+and+Revolution+in+Venezuela&amp;rft.volume=49&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.pages=303-308&amp;rft.date=2017-09-14&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A158528940%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft.issn=1071-4839&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1080%2F10714839.2017.1373956&amp;rft.aulast=Smilde&amp;rft.aufirst=David&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AVenezuela" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-20"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-20">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">&nbsp;• <a href="#CITEREFHeritage2002">Heritage 2002</a>, pp.&nbsp;618–621.<br>&nbsp;• Kevin Voigt (6 March 2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://edition.cnn.com/2013/03/06/business/venezuela-chavez-oil-economy/">Chavez leaves Venezuelan economy more equal, less stable</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/CNN" title="CNN">CNN</a>.</i> Retrieved 5 April 2014.<br>&nbsp;• Dan Beeton and Joe Sammut (6 December 2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.cepr.net/index.php/blogs/the-americas-blog/venezuela-leads-region-in-poverty-reduction-in-2012-eclac-says">Venezuela Leads Region in Poverty Reduction in 2012, ECLAC Says</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Center_for_Economic_and_Policy_Research" title="Center for Economic and Policy Research">Center for Economic and Policy Research</a></i>. Retrieved 5 April 2014.<br>&nbsp;• <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.worldbank.org/en/country/venezuela/overview">Venezuela Overview</a>. The World Bank. Last updated 17 November 2014. "Economic growth and the redistribution of resources associated with these missions have led to an important decline in moderate poverty, from 50% in 1998 to about 30% in 2012. Likewise, inequality has decreased, reducing the Gini Index from 0.49 in 1998 to 0.39 in 2012, which is among the lowest in the region."</span> </li>

         <li id="cite_note-22"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-22">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.chinadialogue.net/article/show/single/en/8768-Fuel-subsidies-have-contributed-to-Venezuela-s-economic-crisis-">"Fuel subsidies have contributed to Venezuela's economic crisis"</a>. <i>www.chinadialogue.net</i>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=www.chinadialogue.net&amp;rft.atitle=Fuel+subsidies+have+contributed+to+Venezuela%27s+economic+crisis&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.chinadialogue.net%2Farticle%2Fshow%2Fsingle%2Fen%2F8768-Fuel-subsidies-have-contributed-to-Venezuela-s-economic-crisis-&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AVenezuela" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-ELPAISfeb2015-23"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-ELPAISfeb2015_23-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-ELPAISfeb2015_23-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFScharfenberg2015" class="citation news cs1">Scharfenberg, Ewald (1 February 2015). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://internacional.elpais.com/internacional/2015/01/30/actualidad/1422646346_475356.html">"Volver a ser pobre en Venezuela"</a>.          <li id="cite_note-48"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-48">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-:132-67"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-:132_67-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-:132_67-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-:132_67-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFPalma2013" class="citation journal cs1">Palma, Pedro (2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20180405154137/http://ance.msinfo.info/bases/biblo/texto/NE/NE.18.01.pdf">"La política cambiaria en Venezuela"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>Boletín de la Academia Nacional de Ciencias Económicas</i>.          <li id="cite_note-Geografía_–_Clima-153"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Geografía_–_Clima_153-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20060303153257/http://www.gobiernoenlinea.ve/venezuela/perfil_geografia4.html">"Gobierno en Línea: Geografía, Clima"</a>. gobiernoenlinea.ve. 2009.          <li id="cite_note-257"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-257">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

Retrieved <span class="nowrap">28 August</span> 2014</span>.</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.atitle=El+90%25+de+los+venezolanos+que+se+van+tienen+formaci%C3%B3n+universitaria&amp;rft.date=2014-08-23&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Felimpulso.com%2Farticulo%2Fel-90-de-los-venezolanos-que-se-van-tienen-formacion-universitaria%23&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AVenezuela" class="Z3988"></span></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-316"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-316">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFBenítez,_Deivis2011" class="citation news cs1">Benítez, Deivis (2011) [Updated 13 August 2012]. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130116234901/http://www.minpi.gob.ve/minpi/es/noticias/1548-np1428">"Poblaciones Indígenas en aumento según censo poblacional 2011"</a> (in Spanish). PRENSA MINPPPI. Archived from <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.minpi.gob.ve/minpi/es/noticias/1548-np1428">the original</a> on 16 January 2013<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">10 October</span> 2012</span>, article text:</cite><span title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.atitle=Poblaciones+Ind%C3%ADgenas+en+aumento+seg%C3%BAn+censo+poblacional+2011&amp;rft.date=2011&amp;rft.au=Ben%C3%ADtez%2C+Deivis&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.minpi.gob.ve%2Fminpi%2Fes%2Fnoticias%2F1548-np1428&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AVenezuela" class="Z3988"></span><span class="cs1-maint citation-comment">CS1 maint: postscript (<a href="/wiki/Category:CS1_maint:_postscript" title="Category:CS1 maint: postscript">link</a>)</span>
           <div class="mw-collapsible mw-collapsed" style="box-sizing:border-box;width:100%;font-size:95%;padding:4px;border:none;">
            <div style="font-size:100%;line-height:1.6;font-weight:bold;background:transparent;text-align:center;;"></div>
            <div class="mw-collapsible-content" style="background:transparent;text-align:left;;"> <i>Los resultados arrojados por el censo poblacional realizado por el Instituto Nacional de Estadísticas en el 2011 demuestra que las poblaciones indígenas ha aumentado progresivamente con respecto al censo del año 2001.</i>
             <br>Según los datos estadísticos publicados por el INE, el total de población que se declaró indígena por sexo, arrojó un resultado de 50,46% hombre y 49,54% mujeres representando 365.920 hombres y 359.208 mujeres para un total de 725.148 personas que se declararon indígenas de Venezuela.
             <br>Así mismo, se tomó el porcentaje de población por entidad donde el estado Zulia es la entidad con más indígenas con un 61%, seguido del estado Amazonas con 10%, Bolívar con un 8%, Delta Amacuro con 6%, Anzoátegui 5%, Sucre 3%, Apure y Monagas 2% mientras que en otras entidades existe un 3% de población indígena.
             <br>Entre tanto, los pueblos indígenas con mayor población se encuentran los Wayuu 58%, Warao 7%, Kariña 5%, Pemón 4%, Piaroa, Jivi, Añu, Cumanágoto 3%, Yukpa, Chaima 2%, el pueblo Yanomami 1% y otros pueblos con un 9%.
            </div>
           </div></span> </li> 
         <li id="cite_note-317"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-317">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">

         <li id="cite_note-332"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-332">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">
           <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r999302996"><cite id="CITEREFBernasconi2012" class="citation journal cs1">Bernasconi, Giulia (2012). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.openaire.eu/search/publication?articleId=doajarticles::e2c6e2d8ae5915079007d321c21defb0">"L'ITALIANO IN VENEZUELA"</a>. <i>Italiano LinguaDue</i> (in Italian). <b>3</b> (2): 20. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.13130%2F2037-3597%2F1921">10.13130/2037-3597/1921</a><span class="reference-accessdate">.       <p><b>Talks and interviews</b> </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1011217839">
      <div class="refbegin" style=""> 
       <ul>
        <li>

             <li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:World_Heritage_Sites_in_Venezuela" title="Template:World Heritage Sites in Venezuela"><abbr title="View this template" style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;box-shadow:none;padding:0;">v</abbr></a></li>

             <li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:World_Heritage_Sites_in_Venezuela&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template" style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;box-shadow:none;padding:0;">e</abbr></a></li>
            </ul>
           </div>
           <div id="23x15px&amp;#124;border_&amp;#124;alt=Venezuela&amp;#124;link=Venezuela_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Venezuela" style="font-size:114%;margin:0 4em">
            <span class="flagicon"><a href="/wiki/Venezuela" title="Venezuela"><img alt="Venezuela" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Flag_of_Venezuela.svg/23px-Flag_of_Venezuela.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="15" class="thumbborder" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Flag_of_Venezuela.svg/35px-Flag_of_Venezuela.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Flag_of_Venezuela.svg/45px-Flag_of_Venezuela.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="600"></a></span> <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">World Heritage Sites</a> in <a class="mw-selflink selflink">Venezuela</a>
           </div></th>
         </tr>
         <tr>
          <td colspan="2" class="navbox-list navbox-odd hlist" style="width:100%;padding:0px">
           <div style="padding:0em 0.25em"> 
            <ul>
             <li><a href="/wiki/Canaima_National_Park" title="Canaima National Park">Canaima National Park</a> <span style="font-size:85%;">(includes <a href="/wiki/Gran_Sabana" title="Gran Sabana">Gran Sabana</a> and <a href="/wiki/Angel_Falls" title="Angel Falls">Angel Falls</a>)</span></li> 
             <li><a href="/wiki/University_City_of_Caracas" title="University City of Caracas">University City of Caracas</a></li> 
             <li><a href="/wiki/Santa_Ana_de_Coro" class="mw-redirect" title="Santa Ana de Coro">Coro and its Port</a></li>
            </ul> 
           </div></td>
         </tr>
        </tbody>
       </table>
      </div>

                    <th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%"><a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_the_Arab_League" title="Member states of the Arab League">Members</a></th>

                      <ul>

     <div class="vector-menu-content">
